### *Section Overview*

Paul and his colleagues return to a thankful recollection of how the Thessalonians embraced the truth of God's gospel and also imitated the Christian conduct of

other churches. This even entailed suffering, likely in part due to Jewish opposition to the Christian message. Such opposition prompts comment from Paul, who, in ways similar to the OT prophets, expresses frustration that most of his Jewish countrymen have rejected the messianic good news.

### *Section Outline*

III.B. How the Thessalonians Responded and Endured (2:13–16)

- 1. The Thessalonians Respond (2:13–14a)
- 2. Jewish Opposition to the Gospel (2:14b–16)

<span id="page-279-2"></span>2:13 Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy again proclaim their thanksgiving to God for the Thessalonian church, returning to themes from the beginning of the letter (esp. 1:6–10). Such thanksgiving is made "without ceasing" (ESV mg.; cf. 1:2 ESV mg.). Paul refers to the gospel as the "word of God" (Rom. 9:6; Col. 1:25; 2 Tim. 2:9; Titus 2:5). He thus contrasts any message of human origin ("word of men") with the gospel, which originated from God. Though God makes his gospel known through human agents, the message itself is firmly rooted in God's own revelation in Christ.

<span id="page-279-9"></span><span id="page-279-6"></span>In Greek, the concluding relative clause in 1 Thessalonians 2:13 ("which is at work in you believers") could refer either to the "word" of God (thus translated "*which* is at work . . .") or to God himself ("*who* is at work . . ."). The question of whether "God" works or his "word" does rests on a fine distinction, since clearly God works through his word in the lives of believers. The mention of "believers" here is certainly intentional. Paul is renowned for his focus on faith as the proper response to God's grace, which brings someone into true Christian fellowship with God. Thus "believers" are those to whom God has given faith in Christ, which leads them to trust him in all of life (also 1 Thess. 1:7; 2:10).

<span id="page-279-7"></span><span id="page-279-5"></span><span id="page-279-4"></span><span id="page-279-3"></span>2:14 Paul alludes again to a central theme in his Christian ethics: imitation. Christians are to imitate Christ, but they also learn how to follow Christ from observing how other Christians imitate Christ (cf. comments on 1:6–7). Paul earlier commended the Thessalonians for serving as a model for other churches (1:7–10). Here the Thessalonians, as they follow Christ amid suffering and persecution, are said to imitate believers in Judea, the very birthplace of Christian faith.

<span id="page-279-8"></span>Paul has heard a report from Timothy that the persecuted Thessalonians are standing fast, which gives him cause for thanksgiving (cf. 1 Thess. 3:8–9). Here in chapter 2, Paul specifically mentions that the church's sufferings are at the hands of their "own countrymen," indicating a concerted local opposition to the church.

<span id="page-279-1"></span><span id="page-279-0"></span>Paul compares their suffering to the Jewish persecution of the Judean church. Notably, Jewish persecution was evident also at the founding of the Thessalonian church, when synagogue leaders out of jealousy raised a rabble to attack Paul (Acts 17:5–9). This mob failed to catch Paul, but they ransacked the house of Jason, dragging him and other Christians before the city authorities. Even after Paul and his company slipped away from Thessalonica to Berea, Thessalonian Jews pursued Paul, forcing him to leave the province of Macedonia altogether (Acts 17:13–14).

It seems likely that such opponents of the gospel in Thessalonica, not content with Paul's dismissal, would have continued to oppose the church that Paul left behind.

<span id="page-280-20"></span><span id="page-280-15"></span><span id="page-280-14"></span><span id="page-280-8"></span><span id="page-280-5"></span>2:15–16 Paul speaks further of Jewish opposition to the gospel, both in Judea and elsewhere. Paul's concerns here do not spring from anti-Semitism, especially since Paul elsewhere identifies with, and shows compassion and concern for, his fellow Jewish countrymen (e.g., Rom. 11:1–2). Even though Paul self-identified as the "apostle to the Gentiles" (Rom. 11:13; also Gal. 2:8–9; 1 Tim. 2:7), he typically went first to the synagogue in each city he visited (Acts 13:14; 14:1; 17:1–3, 10, 17; 18:4, 19; 19:8). In the synagogue Paul proclaimed the Messiah Jesus in keeping with his statement that the gospel is "to the Jew first" (Rom. 1:16). Paul desired that the success of his Gentile ministry might call his Jewish countrymen to worship Jesus the Messiah (Rom. 11:13–16). Indeed, Gentile believers are "grafted in" to Israel as God's people (Rom. 11:17), and it is this renewed Israel of believing Jews and Gentiles that will be saved (Rom. 11:17–32).

<span id="page-280-18"></span><span id="page-280-17"></span><span id="page-280-16"></span><span id="page-280-13"></span><span id="page-280-11"></span><span id="page-280-10"></span><span id="page-280-9"></span><span id="page-280-7"></span><span id="page-280-6"></span>However, Paul also remembers that, on virtually every occasion when he delivered the messianic good news in these synagogues, he eventually faced great opposition (in Pisidian Antioch [Acts 13:45–51]; in Iconium [14:2–6]; in Lystra [14:19]; in Thessalonica [17:5]; in Berea [17:13–14]; in Corinth [18:6, 12–17]; and later in Ephesus [19:9]). Eventually this culminated in Paul's imprisonment and in Jewish attempts to have him put to death (Acts 21–25). Paul invariably met with a mixed response among his Jewish countrymen, with some believing in Jesus but others refusing to do so (e.g., Acts 28:24). Such a negative reception reminds Paul of how Judah and Israel responded to the OT prophets. Amid the prophets' calls for Israel to repent, those prophets typically experienced social ostracism and even death (cf. Acts 28:25–28; Rom. 11:7–10). Jesus himself warned that the church would be persecuted, much in the way the OT prophets had been (e.g., Matt. 5:11–12; 23:29–39). The Messiah himself was rejected by his own people (e.g., Luke 23:13–24; 24:20; Acts 2:23; 13:27–28; cf. John 1:11). In Acts, the young Saul (later Paul) heard Stephen utter a message about Jewish persecution of the OT prophets and of Christ's followers (Acts 7:39–43; 7:51–8:1). Moreover, Paul remembers a time when, prior to God's gracious intervention, he too was a persecutor of the church (Acts 8:3; Gal. 1:13–14; Phil. 3:6).

<span id="page-280-19"></span><span id="page-280-12"></span><span id="page-280-4"></span><span id="page-280-3"></span><span id="page-280-2"></span><span id="page-280-1"></span><span id="page-280-0"></span>All of this serves as the background to Paul's strong statements of condemnation of his fellow Jewish countrymen in 1 Thessalonians 2:14–16. Paul's denunciation follows the pattern of an OT prophet, who would censure his people even while longing for their repentance and return to the Lord. By condemning the Lord Messiah to death and opposing his agents, unbelieving Jews have invoked divine displeasure. In attempting to thwart Paul in his role as apostle to the Gentiles, they "oppose all mankind" by hindering the word of salvation from coming to all humanity. In this way, Paul concludes they are "[filling up] the measure of their sins" through disavowal of God's messengers, just as their forefathers had done to the OT prophets (2:16; cf. Matt. 23:32).

<span id="page-281-6"></span><span id="page-281-5"></span>Such opposition to the Messiah of God rightly deserves God's wrath (cf. also 2 Thess. 1:5–10), and Paul recognizes that this indeed is the result, so he exclaims, "But wrath has come upon them at last!" (1 Thess. 2:16). The tense of this verb ("has come") has led commentators to speculate concerning which specific moment of "wrath" Paul references. Were there certain events in Paul's day, prior to the writing of this letter, to which Paul was referring? Since the Roman suppression of the First Jewish Revolt occurred later (AD 66–73), some suggest Paul alludes to an earlier humiliation of the Jews—perhaps through some imperial edict (such as Claudius's expulsion of Jews from Rome just prior to the writing of this letter; cf. Acts 18:2) or some local judgment of the Jews in Thessalonica or Corinth (e.g., Acts 18:14–17). However, the Greek aorist tense can at times be used to refer with extra certainty to the prophetic future, and Paul's mention of "at last" in verse 16 may refer to wrath at the final judgment (1 Thess. 1:10; 5:9; also Rom. 2:5; Eph. 5:6; Col. 3:6). Regardless of whether "wrath" here refers to the prophetic future or to a particular event in Paul's day, Paul reminds the Thessalonians that God brings justice in the end.

<span id="page-281-4"></span><span id="page-281-3"></span><span id="page-281-2"></span><span id="page-281-1"></span><span id="page-281-0"></span>Throughout this discourse in 1 Thessalonians 2:14–16, Paul identifies with the Thessalonians' emotions in times of persecution. He assures them that in the end the Lord will deal out just retribution to their opponents. He provides a broader context for Jewish opposition to the gospel, illustrating that such responses have long been encountered in the history of God's dealings with Israel. And he acts as an OT prophet, indicting his own people while nonetheless desiring their repentance and salvation. Thus Paul helps Thessalonian Jewish believers in Christ (as well as the Gentile Christians among them) better to understand the opposition they face as they continue to follow the Messiah.

### *Response*

Paul here commends the ready acceptance of the Christian good news as the very word of God. He indirectly encourages churches to imitate one another as each seeks to honor Christ while enduring opposition in this present age. He also locates the sufferings of the church in a broader tableau of all who have followed God in the past. Since our forerunners in the OT and NT faced suffering, and indeed since Christ himself encountered death at the agency of his own people, we should be prepared to persevere in a world that is in opposition to the things of God. The salvation message is worth every bit of energy and commitment from Christ's followers. And our endurance can serve as a model to others who cling to the Word of God in such an age.

For you yourselves know that we are destined for this. **4**For when we were with you, we kept telling you beforehand that we were to suffer affliction, just as it has come to pass, and just as you know. **5**For this reason, when I could bear it no longer, I sent to learn about your faith, for fear that somehow the tempter had tempted you and our labor would be in vain.

1Some manuscripts *servant*

### *Section Overview*

Paul and his team continue to speak of their affection for the Thessalonians. Since Paul had been forced to flee Thessalonica, he had longed to return to this fledgling church—out of love for the believers and with a desire to instruct and encourage them further. He had also feared that persecution could weaken the church's resolve. Because Paul was prevented from returning, he had sent Timothy, whose good report back provided much cause for thanksgiving. This affectionate narrative serves to further unite these missionaries with the church and indirectly provides another opportunity for Paul to encourage the church to persevere amid persecution.

### *Section Outline*

III.C. Paul's Longing for News (2:17–3:5)

- 1. Paul's Return to Thessalonica Hindered (2:17–20)
- 2. Timothy Sent to Encourage the Thessalonians (3:1–5)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-282-1"></span><span id="page-282-0"></span>2:17–18 Local opposition in Thessalonica compelled the church to send Paul away from the city much earlier than he had wished (Acts 17:5), so Paul and his colleagues were concerned about how the church was faring amid difficulty. Paul refers to this separation in verse 17 as his having been "torn away," metaphorically employing the Greek word (*aporphanizō*) referring to an orphaned child's being separated from his parents. Paul thus expresses a deep feeling of loss at his departure. Yet he also hastens to assure the church that this separation will be short-lived. He speaks of their distance as being "in person" (the Gk. is literally "in face") and not "in heart" (cf. 1 Cor. 5:3; Col. 2:5).

<span id="page-283-14"></span><span id="page-283-4"></span>Paul and his colleagues were eager to see the Thessalonians again. They are quite emphatic in this regard, and Paul notes that they endeavored "more eagerly" and "with great desire" to see the Thessalonians in person (cf. 1 Thess. 3:10). Note that Paul chooses this moment to switch to the first-person singular ("I" rather than "we"), highlighting his personal efforts "again and again" to return to the church.

<span id="page-283-2"></span><span id="page-283-1"></span><span id="page-283-0"></span>Concerning his failure to return to Thessalonica, Paul attributes this to satanic spiritual opposition. Satan is the Greek transliteration of a Hebrew name (meaning "accuser") that appears in a few key OT episodes in which this sinful angelic being falsely accuses God's people (Job 1:6–2:10; Zech. 3:1–2). The Gospels and Acts mention Satan by name in several places in the roles of tempting Jesus (Matt. 4:1–11), appearing as an enemy in Jesus' teaching (Mark 3:22–30; 4:15; Luke 10:18; 13:16; 22:31), luring Judas into betraying Jesus (Luke 22:3; John 13:2, 27), and tempting Ananias to lie to the church (Acts 5:3). Paul mentions Satan in connection with temptation (1 Cor. 7:5; 1 Tim. 5:15), eschatological opposition to the church (2 Thess. 2:9), and the church's victory over Satan (Rom. 16:20; also Eph. 4:27; 6:11). In 1 Thessalonians, Paul does not specify just how he knows Satan hindered him from traveling to Thessalonica.

<span id="page-283-11"></span><span id="page-283-9"></span><span id="page-283-8"></span><span id="page-283-5"></span><span id="page-283-3"></span>Paul provides multiple reasons for desiring to return to Thessalonica: the believers there are his "glory and joy" (1 Thess. 2:20); he feels longing, compassion, and affection for them (2:17; 3:6); he knows they need to be further established in the faith (3:2, 10); and he is concerned that the persecutions and afflictions they face may have dissuaded them from following Christ (3:3–5).

<span id="page-283-13"></span><span id="page-283-12"></span>Paul wants the church to be assured of his affection. The Thessalonians may well have felt "orphaned," even as Paul felt "torn away" from them. Paul and his team all along had been concerned about these believers' welfare, and they were praying, seeking avenues of return, and longing for news. Even at the time he writes this letter, Paul is continuing to seek opportunities to be personally present again with the church (3:10–11).

<span id="page-283-15"></span><span id="page-283-10"></span>2:19–20 Imagine how happy a child feels when his mom declares that she is "proud of him," or when a father tells his daughter that she is his "joy." We should understand verses 19–20 in similar ways. Paul and his colleagues call the church their "joy," their "crown of boasting," and their "glory." This language conveys both a real eschatological truth for Paul and an encouragement for the church.

<span id="page-283-16"></span><span id="page-283-7"></span><span id="page-283-6"></span>At Christ's appearing (cf. comment on 4:15), Paul believes his legacy before the Lord will especially be the people to whom he has ministered (Phil. 2:16; also 1 Cor. 9:15–18; 2 Cor. 10:13–18). Such "boasting" is a two-way street; thus Paul can say <span id="page-284-9"></span>of the church in Corinth, "On the day of our Lord Jesus you will boast of us as we will boast of you" (2 Cor. 1:14). Paul refers to the church as his "crown" (also Phil. 4:1), much as an athlete in antiquity received a crown for victory (cf. 2 Tim. 2:5; 4:8).

<span id="page-284-12"></span><span id="page-284-6"></span><span id="page-284-4"></span>While "boasting" can often designate sinful pride (e.g., 1 Cor. 1:28–31), Paul affirms an appropriate kind of boasting. The distinction concerns in what one "boasts." For example, Paul forbids anyone to boast in his or her meritorious works, as if such works garnered salvation (e.g., Rom. 2:23; 3:27; 4:2; Eph. 2:9). On the other hand, Paul takes appropriate confidence in the way he behaves among the churches, and boasts of such things (2 Cor. 1:12). He willingly boasts in his weakness, since it leads to Christ's glory shining through his witness (2 Cor. 11:21–12:10; cf. also Rom. 15:17–21). Paul even boasts of particular churches in his communications with other churches (e.g., 2 Cor. 7:14; 8:24; 9:2–3).

<span id="page-284-10"></span><span id="page-284-8"></span><span id="page-284-5"></span>Paul addresses his joy and pride in the Thessalonian church especially as a means of encouraging them. Such expressions should be seen in light of the deep affection he repeatedly expresses throughout the letter. Thus when Paul and his colleagues remind the church of their joy in them, we should expect that the church too would rejoice in the profound news that they have brought joy to their spiritual fathers in the Lord, who had first conveyed the gospel to them and who have expressed such affection for them. When Paul calls them his "crown of boasting," this would indeed be akin to children's witnessing their parents' beaming with pride.

<span id="page-284-17"></span><span id="page-284-16"></span><span id="page-284-15"></span><span id="page-284-14"></span>3:1–3a Though Paul was hindered from traveling to Thessalonica (2:18), Timothy was able to go. Paul wants the church to see Timothy's visit as an affectionate effort to encourage them and to learn of their welfare (3:2). Paul hoped Timothy's work would help prevent the church from being "moved" by their afflictions (3:3a), since Paul was concerned that Satan was utilizing persecution to attack the church's faith (3:5; cf. comment on 2:14).

<span id="page-284-13"></span><span id="page-284-7"></span>Paul refers to Timothy as his "brother" and "God's coworker," and says that the church should therefore receive him as Paul's honored apostolic delegate (cf. 2 Cor. 1:1; Col. 1:1; Philem. 1). Paul had specially invited Timothy to join his mission (Acts 16:3), and Timothy later served as Paul's delegate to other churches, including Philippi (Phil. 2:19–23) and Ephesus (1 Tim. 1:2–3).

<span id="page-284-11"></span><span id="page-284-3"></span><span id="page-284-2"></span><span id="page-284-1"></span><span id="page-284-0"></span>Timothy voyaged to Thessalonica around AD 49–50, while Paul was in Athens (Acts 17:15–34). The full sequence of events is not entirely clear, but the broad outline appears to be this: Paul and Silas were compelled to flee Thessalonica (Acts 17:10), and then later Paul had to escape from Berea to Athens, while Silas and Timothy remained in Berea (Acts 17:14). Paul then requested that Silas and Timothy join him in Athens (Acts 17:15). It is possible that once Timothy arrived in Athens, Paul directed him to travel back to Thessalonica. Others have postulated instead that Paul sent a second directive to Timothy (subsequent to the one mentioned in Acts 17:15) to go to Thessalonica even before Timothy had arrived in Athens.

<span id="page-285-9"></span><span id="page-285-3"></span><span id="page-285-2"></span><span id="page-285-1"></span>3:3b–5 Paul and his colleagues remind the church that affliction and suffering are part of Christian testimony. Jesus himself spoke of how the church would be persecuted (e.g., Matt. 5:10–12; 10:16–23). If Jesus suffered opposition in this world, then his followers should expect much the same (e.g., Matt. 10:24–25; John 15:18–25). Paul, having previously been a persecutor of the church, well understands both sides of this reality. In electing Paul as his chosen instrument, Jesus even declares that Paul will be shown "how much he must suffer for the sake of my name" (Acts 9:15–16). Paul fully expects hostility against the gospel (e.g., Col. 1:24; 2 Thess. 1:4; 2 Tim. 3:12).

<span id="page-285-6"></span><span id="page-285-4"></span>Paul emphatically reminds the church that they had been forewarned that persecution was imminent ("you yourselves know," and "we kept telling you beforehand"), underscoring that such difficult circumstances are in keeping with his theology, witness, and expectations.

<span id="page-285-8"></span><span id="page-285-0"></span>Paul specifically says that he had delegated Timothy to "learn about [their] faith." Timothy approached the Thessalonians to encourage them (1 Thess. 3:2), but he was also to report on their condition. Paul vocalizes his fear: the Tempter may have tempted them away from the faith. The Tempter is Satan (cf. comment on 2:17–18; cf. Matt. 4:3; 1 Cor. 7:5). Paul expresses the fear any missionary may feel who has had to leave the field too quickly: what will happen to the faith of those left behind? Paul is also concerned lest their labor among the Thessalonians (1 Thess. 2:9) show itself ultimately to be without fruit or result (cf. Gal. 4:11; Phil. 2:16).

### <span id="page-285-7"></span><span id="page-285-5"></span>*Response*

As we consider modern responses to these verses, we can envision the perspectives both of ministers and of the church. Since all Christians serve as ministers in our own ways (though only some of us in that formal role), we can all learn from Paul's ministerial practice. He recognizes the spiritual challenges to young believers who have not yet gained proper grounding in the faith. Even when it became impossible to stay in Thessalonica and instruct the church in their new faith, Paul eagerly found ways to remain in contact and to provide encouragement from afar. Such an approach springs from an earnest love and affection for believers. Furthermore, Paul does not hesitate to share his parental pride and joy in these believers. In all this, Paul's ministerial example is worth imitating.

The church is also challenged to remember that every believer may well endure suffering and persecution in this age. Persecution is not to be sought out by any church. However, we should be prepared in our theology and practice to encounter times of suffering as opportunities to follow our crucified Lord and bring glory to him.

### <span id="page-286-4"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 3:6–10

**<sup>6</sup>**But now that Timothy has come to us from you, and has brought us the good news of your faith and love and reported that you always remember us kindly and long to see us, as we long to see you— **<sup>7</sup>** for this reason, brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* in all our distress and affliction we have been comforted about you through your faith. **8**For now we live, if you are standing fast in the Lord. **9**For what thanksgiving can we return to God for you, for all the joy that we feel for your sake before our God, **<sup>10</sup>** as we pray most earnestly night and day that we may see you face to face and supply what is lacking in your faith?

1Or *brothers and sisters*

### *Section Overview*

Timothy has returned with the good report that the Thessalonians are thriving in their Christian faith and love. Paul expresses the joy, comfort, and thanksgiving that he finds in this news. This permits him another opportunity to affirm and encourage the Thessalonians in their steadfast faith, and he again mentions his desire to see them face-to-face.

### *Section Outline*

III.D. Joy at Timothy's Encouraging Report (3:6–10)

- 1. The Comfort of Timothy's News (3:6–7)
- 2. Contentment That the Church Remains Steadfast (3:8)
- <span id="page-286-0"></span>3. Joyful Thanksgiving and Prayer (3:9–10)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-286-3"></span>3:6–7 The narrative of Paul's longing for the Thessalonians (2:17–3:5) now achieves its climax. Paul has heard news from Timothy, and he rejoices greatly to learn that the Thessalonians are thriving in the Lord. The Greek of 3:6–10 forms one sentence, with verse 7 providing the main verb ("we have been comforted").

<span id="page-286-5"></span><span id="page-286-2"></span><span id="page-286-1"></span>In verse 6 we learn that Timothy has returned from his trip to Thessalonica. The Greek verb translated "brought us . . . good news" (*euangelizō*) is the same word Paul often employs for bringing the gospel to others; it refers to a herald's bringing good tidings. Paul highlights three items from Timothy's report: the Thessalonians' faith, their love, and their fond remembrance of Paul and his team (3:6). From a distance, Paul had been concerned about whether their newfound Christian faith had remained intact (3:5), and now Timothy testifies they are indeed well-founded

<span id="page-287-14"></span><span id="page-287-9"></span><span id="page-287-5"></span>in their faith (v. 8). Paul also rejoices to hear about their love (cf. 1:3; 4:9; 5:8, 13). Paul will soon pray for their love for one another to continue to increase (3:12), indicating that verse 6 also likely focuses on the Thessalonians' love for their Christian brothers and sisters. Finally, just as Paul has repeatedly announced his longing to visit the Thessalonians again in person (2:17–18; 3:5), so the church warmly remembers Paul and his colleagues and desires eagerly to see them again.

<span id="page-287-8"></span>Although Paul continues to find himself amid the distress and affliction of ministry, he has found comfort in such a good report. He gladly shares his joy and thanksgiving, knowing that such expressions will encourage the Thessalonian believers to persevere all the more.

<span id="page-287-12"></span><span id="page-287-2"></span><span id="page-287-1"></span>3:8 Paul employs the metaphor of "life" to express his elation at the news. The continued faith of the Thessalonians brings life to the apostle. Paul notes that they "stand" in the Lord—a common Pauline metaphor (e.g., 1 Cor. 16:13; Gal. 5:1; Phil. 1:27; 4:1; 2 Thess. 2:15) providing a key image of endurance and perseverance. Through the Lord's strength (Rom. 14:4), the church endures.

<span id="page-287-13"></span><span id="page-287-7"></span><span id="page-287-4"></span><span id="page-287-0"></span>3:9–10 Having been comforted by Timothy's report, Paul expresses thanksgiving to God, overflowing with joy that the church stands fast in the Lord (cf. 1:2–10; 2:13–14). Paul articulates his thanksgiving in terms of a rhetorical question. The question hinges on whether one can ever fully "return to" (or "repay," Gk. *antapodidōmi* ) God with thanksgiving. The assumption is that such "repayment" is beyond Paul's ability, and thus his thanksgiving can hardly equal the joy he feels.

<span id="page-287-6"></span><span id="page-287-3"></span>As they rejoice, Paul and his colleagues continue to pray for opportunity to return to Thessalonica (3:10). Their prayer, like their thanksgiving (1:2; 2:13), is a constant refrain in these missionaries' lives ("night and day"; 2:9). Paul and his colleagues desire to be personally present with the Thessalonians (literally "to see your face"; cf. comment on 2:17–18) and to strengthen their faith further. Paul readily acknowledges that, despite the enduring faith of the church (3:6–7), there remains more growth ahead for them. All this continues to remind the Thessalonians of Paul's affection for them.

### *Response*

Paul and his colleagues continue to model a wonderful approach to missions. They rejoice at how God sustains the church in this world. Moreover, they engage in public thanksgiving in order to encourage the church. Even amid the trials of ministry (cf. 3:7), a church is enlivened by how its leaders and servants reflect an attitude of joy and thanksgiving, publicly celebrating all that God is doing.

<span id="page-287-11"></span><span id="page-287-10"></span>Yet there will always be challenges in this world. Thus God's people must remain faithful, loving, and steadfast (qualities all lauded in 3:6–8), and all of us are in continual need of growth, encouragement, and further instruction in following Christ (v. 10).

### <span id="page-288-6"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 3:11–13

**<sup>11</sup>**Now may our God and Father himself, and our Lord Jesus, direct our way to you, **<sup>12</sup>** and may the Lord make you increase and abound in love for one another and for all, as we do for you, **<sup>13</sup>** so that he may establish your hearts blameless in holiness before our God and Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus with all his saints.

### *Section Overview*

Paul prayerfully invokes God's blessing on the Thessalonians. He specifically refers to God the Father and Jesus working together in the Godhead for the benefit of the church. In addition to asking again for God to provide a way for Paul to return to Thessalonica, Paul and his colleagues pray for the church to grow in love, since this will further root them in holiness as they await the return of Jesus.

### *Section Outline*

### III.E. The Pauline Benediction (3:11–13)

- 1. May God Grant Paul Opportunity to Return to Thessalonica (3:11)
- 2. May God Further Increase the Thessalonians' Love (3:12–13)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-288-5"></span><span id="page-288-4"></span>3:11 Having just acknowledged that Paul and his colleagues are still praying to return to Thessalonica (3:10), Paul now delivers a benediction that begins with petition to God.

<span id="page-288-3"></span><span id="page-288-2"></span><span id="page-288-1"></span><span id="page-288-0"></span>Nearly two thousand years later, it seems unexceptional that Paul directed his prayers to both "our God and Father" and "our Lord Jesus" (cf. 1:1; 3:13; also, e.g., Rom. 1:7; 1 Cor. 1:3; 2 Thess. 2:16). However, this would have been shocking in Paul's day among Jews and Gentiles outside the church. In fact, there is much theology implicit in Paul's wording. First, he intimately associates Jesus with God the Father, calling Jesus "Lord" (a common OT title for God) and praying to the Lord Jesus alongside God the Father. This implies a very high Christology, affirming Jesus' deity. It also displaces the Roman emperor and all other "lords," whose claims for deity were rejected by Jews and Christians. Second, God is called "our . . . Father," reminding us that through Jesus' atoning work, Christians have been adopted into communion with God (Rom. 8:15; Gal. 4:6–7). Jesus himself taught his followers to call God "Father" (e.g., Matt. 5:16, 45; 6:6, 9; 23:9; Mark 14:36).

This benediction contains two specific petitions, both employing the Greek optative mood in order to convey a prayerful request. In the first petition, Paul asks God the Father and the Lord Jesus to "direct our way to you." Paul's desire to return to the Thessalonians, which has been a theme of many preceding verses (esp. 2:17–18; 3:1–2, 5, 10), culminates with this entreaty.

<span id="page-289-11"></span><span id="page-289-9"></span><span id="page-289-8"></span><span id="page-289-7"></span>3:12 This verse introduces Paul's second petition, namely, that the Thessalonians would grow further in love for others. Paul has already lauded the Thessalonians for their love (3:6). By combining two optative verbs with overlapping meaning ("increase and abound"), Paul stresses the church's need for continued growth in love while acknowledging that such love is already present (cf. comments on 4:9– 12). When Paul mentions "love for one another and for all," he certainly includes loving other churches and likely also invites them to serve as loving witnesses to everyone in their circle of acquaintances (cf. 1 Thess. 5:15; Gal. 6:10). Paul caps this discussion with a reminder that he and his colleagues love the Thessalonians ("as we do for you"), inviting them to love others in the way such love had been modeled to them.

<span id="page-289-12"></span><span id="page-289-5"></span><span id="page-289-2"></span><span id="page-289-1"></span><span id="page-289-0"></span>The reader would rightly associate loving one another with the OT commandment to love our neighbors (Lev. 19:18, 34; Deut. 10:19), with Jesus' strong emphasis on loving others (e.g., Matt. 5:43–48; 22:37–40; Luke 10:25–37; John 13:34–35; 15:12–17), and with broader NT theology (e.g., Heb. 13:1; James 2:8; 1 Pet. 1:22). Paul also emphasizes love for others throughout his epistles (e.g., Rom. 12:9–10; 13:8–10; 1 Cor. 16:14; Gal. 5:14; Eph. 5:2), noting that love is the greatest Christian virtue (1 Cor. 13:1–13).

<span id="page-289-10"></span><span id="page-289-4"></span><span id="page-289-3"></span>3:13 Such love for others has a purposeful intent: Christian holiness. Drawing on OT vocabulary of purity and sanctification, Paul looks for the congregation's hearts to be established as "blameless" and holy. The route toward holy living that Paul emphasizes here is through loving others.

As Paul concludes this brief benedictory prayer, he again mentions (as an *inclusio* with 3:11) God the Father and the Lord Jesus. Paul prays for the sanctification of the Thessalonian believers, rooted in love, to be established so that it will stand firm in the judgment at Christ's return. This reference to the future return of Christ with his saints signals a topic that will soon be addressed (4:13–5:11; cf. also 1:10).

### <span id="page-289-6"></span>*Response*

As before, we can learn both from how Paul conducts ministry and from how he intended the church to respond to his words. Paul models good ministerial practice here in multiple ways. Having just reported to the Thessalonians that he prays for them, he immediately engages in supplication on their behalf. By reminding them repeatedly of the lordship of Christ and the fatherhood of God, he invites them to live with the knowledge that God has adopted them and that Jesus is their Lord. Furthermore, Paul provides us an example of missionary prayer, prompting us to petition God regularly for Christian love to increase within our churches.

Finally, we should observe how Paul's own love serves as an excellent model for the churches; in similar ways, ministers should be known for their love of others.

Indeed, all Christians should ask the Lord to increase our love for everyone in our churches, our neighborhoods, and the world around us. God desires our sanctification in response to his grace, and holiness cannot be found apart from love.

### OVERVIEW OF

### <span id="page-290-2"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 4:1–5:22

Paul and his colleagues have spent over half of the letter giving thanks for the Thessalonians and admiring their steadfast faith and love. They now shift to specific admonitions and instructions that connect to the church's ethical and theological challenges.

<span id="page-290-1"></span>They first address one particular aspect of sanctification: sexual fidelity (1 Thess. 4:1–8). The Roman world was awash with sexual immorality, and Paul seeks to instill a Christian sexual ethic. He then proceeds to exhort them further in love for one another (4:9–10; cf. 3:6, 12) and to encourage a proper public witness through Christian work (4:11–12).

<span id="page-290-4"></span><span id="page-290-3"></span><span id="page-290-0"></span>The central section of Paul's instruction focuses on the return of Christ (4:13– 5:11). Paul addresses two key questions: (1) What will happen to the Christian dead? (2) When will Christ return?

<span id="page-290-5"></span>The final paragraph (5:12–22) brings together a series of Pauline admonitions about proper church conduct.

### 1 THESSALONIANS 4:1–8

4 Finally, then, brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* we ask and urge you in the Lord Jesus, that as you received from us how you ought to walk and to please God, just as you are doing, that you do so more and more. **2**For you know what instructions we gave you through the Lord Jesus. **3**For this is the will of God, your sanctification:*<sup>2</sup>* that you abstain from sexual immorality; **<sup>4</sup>** that each one of you know how to control his own body*<sup>3</sup>* in holiness and honor, **5**not in the passion of lust like the Gentiles who do not know God; **<sup>6</sup>** that no one transgress and wrong his brother in this matter, because the Lord is an avenger in all these things, as we told you beforehand and

solemnly warned you. **7**For God has not called us for impurity, but in holiness. **8**Therefore whoever disregards this, disregards not man but God, who gives his Holy Spirit to you.

1Or *brothers and sisters*; also verses 10, 13 2Or *your holiness* 3Or *how to take a wife for himself*; Greek *how to possess his own vessel*

### *Section Overview*

Paul encourages the Thessalonians to grow in the pattern of holy living that they received from him and his colleagues. He focuses especially on their sexual purity and holiness, given the pervasive impact of sexual immorality in the Roman world.

### *Section Outline*

- IV. How Christians Walk and Please God (4:1–5:22)
	- A. God's Call to Purity and Holiness (4:1–8)
		- 1. Pleasing God All the More (4:1–2)
		- 2. Avoiding Sexual Immorality (4:3–8)

### *Comment*

4:1 The letter transitions from Paul's joy at the good news of the Thessalonians' steadfast faith and love. Paul now encourages them to continue to grow in their faithful Christian walk.

<span id="page-291-3"></span><span id="page-291-2"></span>Strikingly, Paul employs the word "finally," although two chapters remain in the epistle. Elsewhere Paul uses "finally" to highlight the instruction that follows (2 Cor. 13:11; Eph. 6:10; Phil. 4:8), even when he has substantially more to say (Phil. 3:1; 2 Thess. 3:1). This functions as a transition to the instruction in chapters 4–5. The urgency of what follows is also accentuated by overlapping verbs of communication ("we ask and urge"), words spoken solemnly "in the Lord Jesus."

<span id="page-291-7"></span><span id="page-291-5"></span>Paul and his colleagues remind the Thessalonians that they had "received" similar instruction before. Although they already know how to walk before God, every believer must be reminded continually of proper Christian conduct in order to live out those principles in a world resistant to Christ. As noted earlier (cf. comment on 2:11–12), "walking" is a common Pauline metaphor, emphasizing the ongoing daily endurance required in following Christ. Paul also directs churches regularly to "please" God (e.g., 1 Cor. 7:32; Gal. 1:10; 1 Thess. 2:4; cf. 2 Tim. 2:4). "Pleasing" does not refer to an attempt to win salvation from God by our actions (Rom. 8:8), but it does indicate that, as those saved by grace, our proper response is to live in Spirit-empowered sanctification, which is pleasant (1 Thess. 4:1) to the God who has redeemed us.

<span id="page-291-8"></span><span id="page-291-6"></span><span id="page-291-4"></span><span id="page-291-1"></span><span id="page-291-0"></span>Paul acknowledges yet again (cf. 1:6–10; 2:13–14; 3:6–8) that the Thessalonians are already walking according the Christian pattern they have received, further encouraging them to abound in this holy manner of life (cf. also 3:12–13).

<span id="page-292-14"></span><span id="page-292-13"></span><span id="page-292-12"></span>4:2 Throughout this epistle, Paul often reminds the Thessalonians of what they already "know" from his previous work among them (e.g., 1 Thess. 1:5; 2:1, 2, 5, 11; 3:3–4; 5:2). Often Christian discipleship does not hinge on studying new and deeper truths; it instead entails growth in proper Christian habits in order to live out truths already learned.

<span id="page-292-15"></span><span id="page-292-10"></span><span id="page-292-8"></span>4:3 Paul and his colleagues highlight one particular dimension of Christian sanctification: maintaining sexual purity before the Lord. Sanctification elsewhere in Paul's letters involves many other aspects of holiness as well (e.g., Rom. 6:22; 1 Cor. 1:30; 1 Thess. 5:23), but the Greek here clearly directs the reader to apply sanctification to sexual fidelity (also in 4:4, 7). Significantly, Paul calls this the "will of God" (cf. 1 Pet. 4:1–6; 1 John 2:15–17).

<span id="page-292-19"></span><span id="page-292-16"></span>Roman sexual mores famously endorsed behavior that Paul knew to be sexually immoral. Even though marital fidelity was commonly expected from Roman matrons, their husbands might regularly participate in dinner parties that included slave-consorts. Young men were often encouraged to be sexually active prior to marriage. Ancient Roman literature contains numerous stories of adulterous males, and in some tales even married women would pursue lovers. Homosexuality was widely practiced, especially among the Greeks, including forms of pederasty. Cities were famous for their prostitutes, especially cities on major trade routes (such as Thessalonica). Amid such widespread licentiousness, the church's pagan neighbors likely thought these Christians strange to refuse such behavior. Indeed, some members of the church, having participated in such Roman sensuality prior to coming to Christ, likely still felt the addictive pull of such temptations.

<span id="page-292-5"></span><span id="page-292-4"></span><span id="page-292-3"></span><span id="page-292-2"></span><span id="page-292-1"></span><span id="page-292-0"></span>God's plan for sex, rooted in the creational joys of marriage (e.g., Gen. 1:26–28; 2:24–25), had long been revealed. Paul knew well both the seventh commandment prohibiting adultery (Ex. 20:14; Deut. 5:18; Rom. 13:9) and the various OT laws condemning fornication, adultery, homosexuality, incest, bestiality, and other forms of sexual immorality (e.g., Lev. 18:6–23; 20:10–21; Deut. 22:13–30). Paul would also have studied the OT proverbial and prophetic pronouncements against such sexual sins (e.g., Prov. 2:16–19; 6:32; 7:1–27; Jer. 7:9; 29:23; Hos. 4:2; Mal. 3:5). The early church also knew Jesus' teaching on such matters (e.g., Matt. 5:27–32; 15:19; 19:9, 18). The Jerusalem council, cognizant of the Roman practices surrounding them, directed Gentile believers to abstain from sexual immorality (Acts 15:20, 29; cf. also Heb. 13:4; Rev. 2:14; 22:15). Thus it is not surprising that Paul frequently instructs believers throughout the Roman Empire to practice sex only in the context of marriage (e.g., Rom. 13:13; 1 Cor. 5:1–13; 6:9–20; Gal. 5:19; Eph. 5:3, 5; Col. 3:5; 1 Tim. 1:10).

<span id="page-292-18"></span><span id="page-292-17"></span><span id="page-292-11"></span><span id="page-292-9"></span><span id="page-292-7"></span><span id="page-292-6"></span>4:4–5 Commentators debate the meaning of the word "body" in verse 4. As the ESV footnote mentions, the Greek speaks literally of "possessing" one's own "vessel" in holiness and honor. Because this is contrasted with the "passion of lust" in 4:5 and falls immediately after the admonition to "abstain from sexual immorality" (v. 3), the context favors an interpretation tied to the sexuality themes in this passage.

In that regard, it is best to understand (as does the ESV) the "possessing of one's own vessel" as referring to controlling one's body by avoiding sexual promiscuity.

<span id="page-293-11"></span><span id="page-293-10"></span><span id="page-293-2"></span>Paul contrasts controlling one's body "in holiness and honor" (4:4) with giving the body over to the "passion of lust" (v. 5). In context, "lust" constitutes a desire for passions that transgress the bounds of righteousness (cf. Rom. 1:26–27). Paul here overtly associates such lustful passions with the Roman milieu of Gentiles "who do not know God." The Thessalonian believers, including those who as Gentiles formerly followed pagan sexual behavior, are to look different from their culture on this matter (Eph. 2:1–3; 4:17; Col. 3:5–9).

<span id="page-293-12"></span><span id="page-293-5"></span>4:6 Paul warns that giving in to lustful passions injures others, and the God of justice will avenge the oppressed. Paul supplies two verbs here to indicate that sexual immorality "transgresses" and "wrongs" another; the first verb refers to crossing boundaries (e.g., LXX Mic. 7:18; Jer. 5:22).

<span id="page-293-9"></span><span id="page-293-4"></span><span id="page-293-0"></span>The particular nature of "wrong[ing] his brother" has overtones in Greek of greed and taking advantage of others (Gk. *pleonektein*; cf. 2 Cor. 2:11; 7:2; 12:17–18). Some interpreters understand such greed as that which defrauds others, perhaps implying that Paul has shifted topics here to business relations. However, the context concerns sexual sin, and verses 3–6 form a single sentence, implying that the subject matter has not changed. The greed of *pleonektein* and its cognate nouns appear elsewhere in contexts of sexual immorality as well (Eph. 4:19; 5:3, 5; also Mark 7:22), and thus this word can refer to the greed of lustful passions.

<span id="page-293-7"></span><span id="page-293-1"></span>In committing sexual sin, those who do so transgress the boundaries of others as their covetousness injures their brother. At a minimum, Paul observes that adultery injures the spouse of the adulterer. Yet we could well extend his thought to observe that many are trespassed against anytime someone pursues their lustful desires—certainly one's spouse and children (whether present or future), but also the other person in the sexual act and all of their own family relations, and even Christians in the community among which they worship.

God, who mandates that we love our brothers and neighbors and not injure them, commanded long ago not to engage in illicit sexual encounters. Every such event creates injury, whether or not the perpetrator is cognizant of this fact. God avenges those who are injured and judges those who transgress his righteous law. Thus Paul warns the Thessalonians of the dire consequences of failing to abide by God's precepts concerning sex. In marriage, sex is a joyful gift. Outside the marriage of husband and wife, sex brings injury to others as well as judgment. Paul closes this verse by yet again emphasizing solemnly that he has already taught the Thessalonians on this matter.

<span id="page-293-13"></span><span id="page-293-8"></span><span id="page-293-6"></span><span id="page-293-3"></span>4:7 God calls the believer both to salvation and to sanctification (e.g., 1 Thess. 2:12; 5:23–24; Eph. 4:1). Drawing on OT imagery, Paul here emphasizes the call unto holiness and sanctification. He contrasts holiness with "impurity" (Gk. *akatharsia*), a metaphorical reference to uncleanness. Although Paul can apply "impurity" to a general propensity to sin (Rom. 6:19; 1 Thess. 2:3), he often associates this term

<span id="page-294-3"></span><span id="page-294-0"></span>with sexual impurity specifically (Rom. 1:24; 2 Cor. 12:21; Gal. 5:19; Eph. 4:19; Col. 3:5). Sexual immorality renders the culprit unclean before God.

4:8 In one last emphatic statement, Paul reminds his readers that the call to sexual purity originates not from mere human teaching (whether from Paul or others) but from the God who created, called, saved, and sanctifies these believers (cf. 2:13).

<span id="page-294-4"></span><span id="page-294-1"></span>God the Father has sent his Holy Spirit to fill and indwell believers (e.g., Rom. 8:9–11; Gal. 5:22–23; 2 Tim. 1:14). Paul does not explain fully here the import of the Father's identity as he "who gives his Holy Spirit to you." Yet in 1 Corinthians, Paul argues that believers must live a holy life and especially avoid sexual immorality, lest they take their bodies, the temple dwelling place of the Holy Spirit, and join them in sinful relationship to another (1 Cor. 6:15–20; also 3:16–17).

<span id="page-294-8"></span><span id="page-294-7"></span><span id="page-294-6"></span><span id="page-294-2"></span>In sum, sexual immorality injures others (1 Thess. 4:6), deserves the Lord's vengeance (v. 6), contravenes the holy calling and instruction of God (vv. 7–8), and associates the dwelling place of the Holy Spirit with impurity and transgression (v. 8).

### *Response*

Christian believers have been granted the great privileges of salvation and ongoing sanctification in Christ through the power of the Holy Spirit. Christians seek to live in a way that pleases the God who has already redeemed them, and Christian sanctification especially applies to how we conduct ourselves sexually.

This is as true today as it was two thousand years ago. In both cases, the culture has set itself adrift from God's good plan for sex between husband and wife. In modern culture, sexual relations between consenting adults are assumed to be private matters, consisting of individual moral decisions that have no effect on others. Paul certainly would not agree, since this overlooks the many others who are injured when we misuse sex. Contemporary interest in alternative sexualities, including homosexual and transgender behavior, was widespread in the Roman Empire and was condemned by the apostles. Even the modern prevalence of pornography has analogues in antiquity.

Sadly, many have forgotten that God will certainly judge such activity, especially in the church, since such actions among Christians injure brothers and sisters in the Lord. Licentiousness brings the very dwelling place of the Holy Spirit into sinful disrepute. Paul's word here would be to "control our bodies" (cf. 4:4) and to live as pure and holy in this world.

<span id="page-294-5"></span>Positively, there is much more that can be said about sex. Sex is a wonderful gift from God to humanity to be enjoyed to his glory. It unites husband and wife in lifelong deep and precious ways. To the unmarried, it is of inestimable value to remain chaste unto the Lord's glory. And to the married, marital fidelity expresses a faithfulness in our callings both to our spouses and to God. In a society awash in impure and unholy beliefs about sex, God's people can indeed shine as those who have given over every sphere of their lives in order to walk in a way pleasing to the Lord.

### <span id="page-295-5"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 4:9–12

**<sup>9</sup>**Now concerning brotherly love you have no need for anyone to write to you, for you yourselves have been taught by God to love one another, **<sup>10</sup>** for that indeed is what you are doing to all the brothers throughout Macedonia. But we urge you, brothers, to do this more and more, **<sup>11</sup>** and to aspire to live quietly, and to mind your own affairs, and to work with your hands, as we instructed you, **<sup>12</sup>** so that you may walk properly before outsiders and be dependent on no one.

### *Section Overview*

Paul and his colleagues now shift to two new topics: Christian love and diligent work. Paul commends the believers for their love of one another in the Christian community (both in Thessalonica and throughout their region) and encourages them all the more to love their brothers and sisters in the church. He then exhorts the Thessalonians to work diligently in their own vocations without meddling in the affairs of others. Paul desires to increase the church's self-reliance and their witness to the watching world.

### *Section Outline*

IV.B. Concerning Love and Work (4:9–12)

- 1. The Church Taught by God to Love One Another (4:9–10a)
- <span id="page-295-3"></span>2. Urged to Abound in Love and Diligent Work (4:10b–12)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-295-0"></span>4:9 Paul and his colleagues switch topics to brotherly love, signaling this shift in their discourse using the words "now concerning." Paul employs the term for "brotherly love" (Gk. *philadelphia*) also in Romans 12:10. This connects clearly with the OT concept of "love of neighbor" (Lev. 19:18, 34; Deut. 10:19) and with Jesus' many instructions to love others, especially within the Christian community (e.g., John 13:34–35; 15:12–17; cf. also Matt. 19:17–19; 22:37–40). The church already knows the importance of loving one another, since they have been "taught by God"—combining in one Greek word (*theodidaktos*) this notion found elsewhere in Scripture (e.g., Isa. 54:13; John 6:45; 1 Cor. 2:13).

<span id="page-295-4"></span><span id="page-295-2"></span><span id="page-295-1"></span>As observed above, Paul calls all in the Christian faith (men and women alike) "brothers" in order to emphasize the familial relationship that exists in the church (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 1:4). All believers have been adopted by God into this <span id="page-296-0"></span>new family (Rom. 8:14–23; Gal. 4:4–7; Eph. 1:5). As members of the same family, we are to love one another.

<span id="page-296-7"></span><span id="page-296-6"></span>4:10–12 The ESV accurately reflects the structure of the single Greek sentence that encompasses verses 10b–12. Paul "urges" four particular ethical responses from the church (each response appearing as an infinitive). The first response ("to do this more and more") is found in verse 10; the next three appear in verse 11 ("to aspire to live quietly," "to mind your own affairs," and "to work with your hands"). Verse 12 then depicts the consequence of such action.

<span id="page-296-4"></span><span id="page-296-3"></span>In 4:10, Paul affirms again that the Thessalonians already love their fellow Christians (cf. 3:6), and he urges them to abound in such love all the more (as he prayed in 3:12). Paul especially highlights the Thessalonians' renowned love for their brothers and sisters in Macedonia, the Roman province containing Thessalonica (cf. 1:7–8).

<span id="page-296-14"></span><span id="page-296-8"></span><span id="page-296-1"></span>In 4:11, the Thessalonians are to "aspire to live quietly." In a Roman society that prizes honor and glory, the church is to set their ambition instead on a "quiet" life. Paul urges similar goals elsewhere: to "work quietly" (2 Thess. 3:12) and to "lead a peaceful and quiet life" (1 Tim. 2:2). The overall thrust in 1 Thessalonians 4:11 likely involves not disturbing others through meddling in their affairs, laboring earnestly instead. Paul hopes here, as elsewhere, that this will lead to godly dignity (1 Tim. 2:2), provision for the needs of life (2 Thess. 3:12), and godly witness to the watching world (1 Thess. 4:12).

<span id="page-296-13"></span><span id="page-296-9"></span>The Thessalonians are also instructed to "mind your own affairs." The Greek more literally directs the readers to "do your own things": they are to perform the work that is theirs in front of them. This also likely implies not meddling as busybodies in others' work (2 Thess. 3:11; cf. 1 Tim. 5:13; 1 Pet. 4:15). It is possible that Paul is addressing a particular issue in Thessalonica, perhaps among certain busybodies or flatterers seeking patron-client relationships, but Paul does not specify such a problem, so scholars can only conjecture.

<span id="page-296-11"></span><span id="page-296-10"></span><span id="page-296-5"></span>In the fourth and final admonition (connected with "urge," from 1 Thess. 4:10), Paul commands the Thessalonians to "work with your hands." Paul returns briefly to this theme at the end of 1 Thessalonians (5:14), where he directs the church to "admonish the idle." Paul anticipates a problem with laziness, one he addresses more strongly in his second epistle (cf. comments on 2 Thess. 3:6–12). In contrast to any charges of laziness or greed, Paul has already reminded the readers that "we worked night and day, that we might not be a burden to any of you" (1 Thess. 2:9). In 2 Thessalonians Paul connects his team's laboring for a living—even while conducting their ministry—to the need for others to work diligently as well (2 Thess. 3:7–8).

<span id="page-296-12"></span><span id="page-296-2"></span>Several commentators have connected the problem of laziness at Thessalonica with their mistaken eschatological views. However, neither epistle to the Thessalonians draws any explicit link between their laziness and their eschatology, and Paul has already taught the Thessalonians in person about working diligently, <span id="page-297-7"></span>even prior to any eschatological error that may have developed after Paul left (note "as we instructed you" in 1 Thess. 4:11; cf. 2 Thess. 3:6–7, 10).

<span id="page-297-5"></span><span id="page-297-4"></span><span id="page-297-2"></span>Paul especially focuses on "work[ing] with your hands" (also 1 Cor. 4:12; Eph. 4:28), implying that the church includes many physical laborers. Paul himself was a tentmaker (Acts 18:3). The Romans tended to demean manual labor, so Paul may be reinstating its importance as a corrective. However, the primary reference to "work[ing] with your hands" simply emphasizes the diligence of the laborer.

We should observe that the three admonitions in 1 Thessalonians 4:11 ("aspire to live quietly," "mind your own affairs," and "work with your hands") all overlap conceptually. They direct the Thessalonians to labor diligently on the tasks at hand without meddling in others' affairs or complaining (cf. 2 Thess. 3:10–12).

<span id="page-297-9"></span><span id="page-297-8"></span><span id="page-297-6"></span>In 1 Thessalonians 4:12 Paul envisions two results flowing from such labor: witness and financial sufficiency. Concerned about the public witness of the church, Paul directs them to "walk properly before outsiders." Nonbelievers will observe the diligent labor and good lives of the Christians and will learn to respect them; hence the believers' proper public conduct serves as a testimony to Christ (cf. Col. 4:5). Some scholars suggest that Paul advocates being "dependent on no one" (1 Thess. 4:12) in order to set the church free from the obligations of patron-client relationships or unwarranted debts to (unbelieving) family members. This is conceivable, but it is certainly the case that, whenever possible, Paul desires believers to seek to "earn their own living" (2 Thess. 3:12). The beneficence of the church should be directed toward those who have no family to care for them and who cannot work due to age, disability, or special circumstances (e.g., 1 Tim. 5:3–16; cf. also, e.g., Rom. 12:13; 2 Cor. 9:1–15; Eph. 4:28; 1 Tim. 6:18–19).

### <span id="page-297-11"></span><span id="page-297-10"></span><span id="page-297-3"></span>*Response*

These verses articulate a vital approach to conducting life in church and society. The call to love one another is fundamental to Christian fellowship. This command remains consistent in both OT and NT instruction. Even among loving churches, we can grow further in our love for one another. Thus, following Paul's example, we ought constantly to remind ourselves of this central tenet of Christian ethics.

Our Christian commitments also determine our approach to work: so far as we are able, we should labor diligently on the work God has placed before us, with a calm and quiet demeanor. Such an approach to our vocations offers a witness to Christ before a watching world and serves as a means through which God provides for our financial need.

<span id="page-297-1"></span><span id="page-297-0"></span>In this modern era, Christians do well to reflect on the theology of work. We can briefly begin such theological reflection with the vital observation that, from the very creation of humanity in the garden (Gen. 1:26–28; 2:5–25; esp. 2:15), we have been given the opportunity to image God in the way we care for his creation through diligent exertion, following the model of God's own work and rest. With the rebellious fall of mankind, our labor became more burdensome (Gen. 3:17–19).

<span id="page-298-0"></span>However, we as Christians are called to reclaim the world of labor for God's glory and our good, treating others with love and serving our employers industriously. Such an appreciation for the God-imaging glory of work informs Paul's awareness of the Christian call to work heartily as unto the Lord.

### <span id="page-298-1"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 4:13–18

**<sup>13</sup>**But we do not want you to be uninformed, brothers, about those who are asleep, that you may not grieve as others do who have no hope. **<sup>14</sup>**For since we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so, through Jesus, God will bring with him those who have fallen asleep. **15**For this we declare to you by a word from the Lord,*<sup>1</sup>* that we who are alive, who are left until the coming of the Lord, will not precede those who have fallen asleep. **16**For the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a cry of command, with the voice of an archangel, and with the sound of the trumpet of God. And the dead in Christ will rise first. **17**Then we who are alive, who are left, will be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air, and so we will always be with the Lord. **18**Therefore encourage one another with these words.

1Or *by the word of the Lord*

### *Section Overview*

While many approach this passage desiring to know the exact sequence of Christ's return, such knowledge is not Paul's principal concern. Rather, he encourages the Thessalonians that Christians who have died will be raised when Christ returns. They shall again see their loved ones in Christ on that day. Thus they ought not grieve in the same manner as their pagan neighbors do.

<span id="page-298-2"></span>In the process of assuring the church that the Christian dead will be raised, Paul does provide a brief outline of future events (1 Thess. 4:15–17), following the eschatological teaching of Jesus. When the Lord descends from heaven, everyone will know what is happening, for voices and instruments shall loudly declare his arrival. The Christian dead will be raised first, and the living will join the risen saints in meeting the Lord.

<span id="page-298-3"></span>As one approaches these end-time sections in 1 and 2 Thessalonians, it is helpful to keep at least four observations in mind: (1) Often Paul is answering different questions than modern interpreters ask, and thus we should be aware that, in the providence of God, we may not be able from Paul's words to reach satisfactory answers to all of our modern theological ponderings. (2) Paul has lived previously in Thessalonica, and he has taught the church about eschatology, so in this epistle <span id="page-299-14"></span>he often omits full discussion of concepts the Thessalonians already know; this makes interpretation challenging, requiring humility from modern exegetes (cf. comments on 2 Thess. 2:5–6). (3) Paul repeatedly displays dependence on Jesus' teaching, and this should influence our approach to interpreting his words. (4) Paul is concerned primarily with encouraging the church in his day (rather than with informing their eschatological speculation); in particular, he seeks to reassure Christians in the midst of grief (1 Thess. 4:13–18) and to remind them always to be prepared for Christ's return (1 Thess. 5:1–11).

### <span id="page-299-13"></span>*Section Outline*

IV.C. Will the Christian Dead Be Raised? (4:13–18)

- 1. The Hope of the Resurrection of the Dead (4:13–14)
- 2. The Dead in Christ Are Raised First (4:15–17)
- 3. Christian Encouragement in This Truth (4:18)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-299-11"></span><span id="page-299-8"></span><span id="page-299-5"></span>4:13 Paul introduces this new topic by stating, "we do not want you to be uninformed," in order to accentuate the following discussion (cf. 1 Cor. 10:1; also Rom. 1:13; 11:25; 1 Cor. 12:1; 2 Cor. 1:8). Paul desires the Thessalonians to be informed appropriately about "those who are asleep."

<span id="page-299-9"></span><span id="page-299-0"></span>Sleep serves as a common NT metaphor for death (e.g., 1 Cor. 15:6, 18, 20; also Matt. 27:52; Acts 7:60; 13:36). This sleep metaphor often appears in contexts in which the future resurrection of believers is discussed. Sleep is thus a particularly apt symbol. The dead in Christ have merely fallen asleep, awaiting their awakening in the coming resurrection (e.g., John 11:11; Eph. 5:14). This need not imply a lack of conscious awareness in the intermediate state between death and resurrection (e.g., Luke 16:19–31; 23:43; Phil. 1:21–23; Rev. 4:4; 7:1–17).

<span id="page-299-4"></span><span id="page-299-2"></span><span id="page-299-1"></span>Paul discusses this issue in order that "you may not grieve as others do who have no hope." Some assume mistakenly that this verse implies that Christians should never grieve at all. However, even our Lord grieved the death of his friend Lazarus and wept for the pain of separation that Lazarus's death caused his family and friends (John 11:33–36; cf. Acts 9:37–39). Paul elsewhere encourages believers to weep together amid the travails of life (Rom. 12:15; 1 Cor. 12:26). For believers, death does not have the final word, but it does cause a separation between us and those we love, which naturally produces grief.

<span id="page-299-10"></span><span id="page-299-7"></span>Nevertheless, Paul encourages believers to have a different kind of grief from unbelievers—"not . . . as others do who have no hope" (cf. Eph. 2:12). Christians grieve while still living hopeful of the future regathering of believers at the resurrection (John 11:25–26).

<span id="page-299-12"></span><span id="page-299-6"></span><span id="page-299-3"></span>4:14 Paul heralds the basis for Christian hope: Jesus "died and rose again" (cf. 1 Cor. 15:1–11; Rom. 6:1–5; 1 Thess. 5:10). Jesus' resurrection confirms his victory over sin and death and displays the pattern of resurrection life that he will grant his

<span id="page-300-11"></span>followers at his return (cf. 1 Cor. 15:12–58; Phil. 3:20–21). Thus, in Jesus' resurrection the church has confidence that God will raise their dead brothers and sisters in Christ. Indeed, these risen believers will be an integral part of his second coming.

<span id="page-300-10"></span><span id="page-300-3"></span>4:15 Paul repeats a truth that he comprehends "by a word from the Lord." Paul knows Jesus' instructions to his disciples concerning eschatology, though possibly he has also received prophetic revelation from Jesus. Much of what follows clearly parallels Jesus' teaching found in the Olivet Discourse (Matthew 24–25; Mark 13; Luke 21; cf. also comment on 1 Thess. 1:8–10). This includes the return of the Son of Man on the clouds of heaven (Matt. 24:30), the trumpet call (Matt. 24:31), the gathering of the elect from the ends of the earth and heaven (Mark 13:27), the inability to know the day of the Lord's return (Matt. 24:42), and Jesus' return being likened to a thief in the night (Matt. 24:43).

<span id="page-300-9"></span><span id="page-300-7"></span><span id="page-300-6"></span><span id="page-300-4"></span>Key to the next few verses is Paul's division between those Christians who die prior to Christ's return ("those who have fallen asleep" or "the dead in Christ") and those who are still living on earth when Jesus appears ("we who are alive" or those "left until the coming of the Lord"). Paul demonstrates that the dead in Christ are indeed raised at the Lord's return, even prior to the still-living believers' welcoming Christ.

<span id="page-300-14"></span><span id="page-300-13"></span>Indeed, the dead in Christ are raised "first" (1 Thess. 4:16). Or, as Paul puts it in verse 15, "We who are alive, who are left until the coming of the Lord, will not precede those who have fallen asleep." The "coming [Gk. *parousia*] of the Lord" is a common NT phrase designating Christ's return in order to establish his eternal kingdom and rule (cf. comment on 2 Thess. 2:1).

<span id="page-300-16"></span>4:16 In the next two verses, Paul provides a basic order of events at Jesus' return, emphasizing that the dead in Christ experience resurrection glory. This sequence of events follows the contours of Jesus' own eschatological instruction (esp. Matt. 24:30–31; Mark 13:26–27; Luke 21:27).

<span id="page-300-8"></span><span id="page-300-5"></span><span id="page-300-1"></span>First, the Lord "will descend from heaven." As Jesus mentions (quoting Dan. 7:13), the Son of Man will come "on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory" (Matt. 24:30; cf. Mark 13:26; Luke 21:27). Many images in Revelation overlap here, but especially the coming from heaven of Jesus as the rider on the white horse, escorted by angelic armies, while an angel cries out in a loud voice (Rev. 19:11–21).

<span id="page-300-17"></span><span id="page-300-15"></span><span id="page-300-2"></span>This appearance is accompanied by three sounds: "a cry of command," "the voice of the archangel," and "the sound of the trumpet of God." Paul elsewhere describes Jesus' being "revealed from heaven with his mighty angels" (2 Thess. 1:7; for angels, cf. Matt. 13:41, 49; 16:27; 24:31; 25:31). The sounding of a "loud trumpet" is also mentioned explicitly in Matthew 24:31 (cf. 1 Cor. 15:52). The blowing of trumpets during the eschatological return of the people of God is known in the OT (e.g., Isa. 27:13), and trumpets are featured in the book of Revelation as well (esp. chs. 8–11).

<span id="page-300-12"></span><span id="page-300-0"></span>Central to Paul's argument are the words, "the dead in Christ will rise first." Although the resurrection of the believing dead receives frequent mention in <span id="page-301-7"></span>the NT (e.g., 1 Cor. 15:23, 52; also Luke 14:14; Rev. 20:4–5), Jesus' own eschatological teaching in the Gospels does not directly state that the resurrection of the dead occurs "first" (before the living go to meet the Lord). Perhaps Paul was meditating on Jesus' statement that the angels "will gather his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other" (Matt. 24:31; cf. Mark 13:27). Or perhaps Paul knew more from oral apostolic tradition or direct revelation.

<span id="page-301-10"></span><span id="page-301-2"></span>4:17 After the believing dead have been raised, the story shifts to the believers who remain alive at the time of Jesus' return. This verse has been the subject of much controversy, principally about what it means for living believers to be "caught up together with them in the clouds" and to "meet the Lord in the air." Many contend this provides the exegetical basis for the theology of a future "rapture," in which living believers are suddenly taken out of this world and are taken directly to heaven prior to the great tribulation that precedes a millennium believed to be yet in the future.

<span id="page-301-3"></span>Many also suggest an analogy with those "taken" in the time of Noah (cf. Matt. 24:40–41). Yet this analogy is problematic, since those "taken" in the time of Noah were taken by drowning unto death and judgment, while those who were left behind (namely Noah and his family) experienced the salvation of God.

<span id="page-301-9"></span><span id="page-301-8"></span><span id="page-301-5"></span>There are difficulties in 1 Thessalonians for the rapture theory. This interpretation would imply that Jesus' glorious descent is only partial, stopping in the clouds/air briefly in order to meet the raptured Christians before returning to heaven with them. It seems more likely that Paul expects Jesus' descent to continue from the heavens to the earth. Thus many have argued that the verb for "meet" in the phrase "meet the Lord in the air" is key to understanding these anticipated events. This Greek word for "meet" (*apantēsis*) appears in only two other NT texts. In the eschatological parable of Matthew 25:6, the virgins wait for the bridegroom, whom they "meet" and welcome back to the wedding feast. In Acts 28:15, Roman believers travel out to the Forum of Appius in order to welcome Paul and bring him back to Rome with them. In both Matthew 25 and Acts 28, the action of meeting involves going forth to greet an honored person, then promptly returning with the honored guest. Many instances of *apantēsis* in the Septuagint Greek OT follow a comparable pattern (e.g., Judg. 4:18; 11:31, 34; 19:3; 1 Sam. 13:10), and secular Greek writings use the word to speak of civic delegations going out to welcome a dignitary before returning in celebration to the city.

<span id="page-301-6"></span><span id="page-301-4"></span><span id="page-301-1"></span><span id="page-301-0"></span>This would imply that, at Christ's appearance, Paul expects the dead in Christ to be raised, followed by the lifting up of the living believers to welcome Jesus in the air, before Jesus descends to earth with his people in order to judge the world and establish fully his kingdom on earth. For Jesus' arriving "on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory," again see Matthew 24:30 (quoting Dan. 7:13; also Mark 13:26; Luke 21:27). Some have suggested that "in the air" metaphorically implies something like "out in the open," perhaps in the midst of the clouds that have descended all the way to earth with Jesus. However, it is more probable that Paul intends the "air" and "clouds" to be used to designate a physical space between the earth and the heavens.

In addition to emphasizing the resurrection of the dead, it is important to stress Paul's final clause in this verse. There, Paul expresses confidence in the eternal life of believers in the age to come: "and so we will always be with the Lord."

<span id="page-302-0"></span>4:18 Paul concludes this section with an imperative to encourage one another with this teaching. Believers in Thessalonica who were concerned about the fate of their dead brothers and sisters in the Lord should be comforted by Paul's teaching. Jesus himself had revealed that the dead in Christ are to be raised—even raised before the living have the privilege of meeting Christ. Therefore, Christians need not grieve without hope.

### *Response*

Modern Christians often study such passages in order to develop a detailed itinerary of Christ's return. While this paragraph does provide important information, we should first and foremost acknowledge that Paul has a different objective in mind. He primarily desires to comfort Christians in the loss of their loved ones.

The dead in Christ are merely asleep, awaiting the day of their resurrection at Christ's return. This hope is true, since the very essentials of the gospel (Jesus' death and resurrection) provide confidence that God will raise the dead, whom Christ has redeemed. We can grieve with hope!

It is not wrong to wonder about the itinerary of Christ's return. However, we should be cognizant that in these verses Paul presents only a selection of coming eschatological events (e.g., there is no mention of signs portending Jesus' return or of the final judgment). And we should admit that in these few short verses Paul speaks in such cursory fashion (likely assuming prior teaching in person among the Thessalonians) that it is difficult to fill in definitively all of the many other details we may wish to know. Christians should engage in debates about eschatology with great humility.

### <span id="page-302-1"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 5:1–11

5 Now concerning the times and the seasons, brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* you have no need to have anything written to you. **2**For you yourselves are fully aware that the day of the Lord will come like a thief in the night. **3**While people are saying, "There is peace and security," then sudden destruction will come upon them as labor pains come upon a pregnant woman, and they will not escape. **4**But you are not in darkness, brothers, for that day to surprise you like a thief. **5**For you are all children*<sup>2</sup>* of light, children of the

day. We are not of the night or of the darkness. **<sup>6</sup>** So then let us not sleep, as others do, but let us keep awake and be sober. **7**For those who sleep, sleep at night, and those who get drunk, are drunk at night. **8**But since we belong to the day, let us be sober, having put on the breastplate of faith and love, and for a helmet the hope of salvation. **9**For God has not destined us for wrath, but to obtain salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ, **<sup>10</sup>**who died for us so that whether we are awake or asleep we might live with him. **11**Therefore encourage one another and build one another up, just as you are doing.

1Or *brothers and sisters*; also verses 4, 12, 14, 25, 26, 27 2Or *sons*; twice in this verse

### *Section Overview*

Paul reminds the Thessalonians of what they already know: the timing of Jesus' second coming will be a surprise. Jesus himself taught that his appearance could be likened to a thief in the night, coming at a time when people do not expect it. Thus the Christian is called to be prepared at all times. In contrast to those who are in metaphorical darkness and do not follow Jesus, Christians are to be children of the light—walking in faith, love, and hope. The Christian destiny is salvation at Christ's return.

### *Section Outline*

IV.D. How Should Christians Prepare for Christ's Return? (5:1–11)

- 1. Christ's Return Will Catch People Unaware (5:1–2)
- 2. For Some People, Christ's Return Means Destruction (5:3)
- 3. Christ's Return Means Salvation for Those Equipped in Faith, Hope, and Love (5:4–10)
- 4. Mutual Encouragement in These Truths (5:11)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-303-5"></span><span id="page-303-2"></span><span id="page-303-1"></span><span id="page-303-0"></span>5:1 Many wish to know when Jesus will return to establish his kingdom fully. The disciples asked this very question (Matt. 24:3; Mark 13:4; Luke 21:7). In Jesus' reply, known as the Olivet Discourse, he affirms that, though signs will presage his return, the actual timing of his second coming is not for us to know (Matt. 24:36–44; Mark 13:32–37). Instead, believers should wait patiently and always be prepared for his appearance (e.g., Matt. 24:45–25:13; Luke 12:39–46). In 1 Thessalonians 5, Paul also answers questions about the timing of Jesus' return, and he carefully models his response on Jesus' teaching. It may be that a letter had arrived from Thessalonica or that Timothy had brought back news, thus signaling the Thessalonians' desire for more instruction on the timing of Jesus' second coming.

<span id="page-303-4"></span><span id="page-303-3"></span>Concerning "the times and the seasons," a similar expression occurs in Acts 1:7, where Jesus responds to the disciples' question about the timing of the restoration of the kingdom of God: "It is not for you to know times or seasons that the Father

has fixed by his own authority." Referring again to the church as "brothers," Paul reminds the church concerning instruction they had already received when Paul and his team were with them in Thessalonica. Rhetorically, Paul underscores that they "have no need to have anything written to you."

<span id="page-304-9"></span>5:2 Paul stresses again that they already know the answer to this question, employing the intensified pronoun "you yourselves" and stating that they are already "fully" (Gk. *akribōs*, "accurately") aware of the proper reply.

<span id="page-304-8"></span><span id="page-304-5"></span>Admittedly, this reply is perhaps disappointing to some: the timing of Jesus' return will be a surprise. Jesus compared his return to a "thief," who comes in the night at a time at which no one expects him (Matt. 24:43; Luke 12:39). In this verse, Paul references Jesus' own eschatological teaching, as he did earlier (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 1:10; 4:15; 4:16; 5:1). Jesus' "thief" aphorism was clearly well known in the apostolic tradition (cf. 2 Pet. 3:10; Rev. 3:3; 16:15). Throughout the NT, this thief saying appears in the context of warning and exhortation.
