The thief causes injury to the household; therefore, those unprepared for the Lord's return will suffer loss and destruction. This provides a helpful transition to the thought of 5:3–8.

<span id="page-304-14"></span><span id="page-304-11"></span><span id="page-304-3"></span><span id="page-304-0"></span>Paul draws on OT vocabulary for the "day of the Lord" (e.g., Isa. 13:6, 9; Jer. 46:10; Ezek. 30:3; Joel 2:31; 3:14; Amos 5:18–20; Zeph. 1:7–18; Mal. 4:5) to depict the day on which the Lord Jesus will appear to bring final judgment on his enemies and vindication for his people (1 Cor. 1:8; 5:5; 2 Cor. 1:14; 2 Thess. 2:2; also 2 Pet. 3:10).

<span id="page-304-10"></span><span id="page-304-7"></span>5:3 Since Christ's return will come as a surprise, Paul warns that those who are not following Christ are in danger of being caught unaware. People may become so acclimatized to the status quo that they forget that Jesus will return to judge the living and the dead (cf. also 2 Pet. 3:4).

<span id="page-304-13"></span><span id="page-304-2"></span><span id="page-304-1"></span>Paul pictures someone who observes, "There is peace and security," and thus assumes the signs for Jesus' return and final judgment are still far off. Such a person fails to be prepared for Christ's appearance. Indeed, it may be at just such a moment that "sudden destruction" brings the final judgment. Following an OT metaphor for destruction (Isa. 26:17; Jer. 4:31; 6:24; Mic. 4:9–10; on the "day of the Lord," see esp. Isa. 13:8), Paul draws analogies to the labor pains of pregnancy, which can be agonizing and sudden. Labor pains also appear in various other eschatological metaphors from Jesus and Paul (Matt. 24:8; Mark 13:8; John 16:21; Rom. 8:22). Here the emphasis, as in the OT, remains merely on the pain itself, without reference to the joy of the birth. No one will be able to flee from the sudden judgment Christ brings (cf. Rom. 2:3).

<span id="page-304-12"></span><span id="page-304-6"></span><span id="page-304-4"></span>5:4–5 In contrast to the people mentioned in 5:3, the Thessalonian believers "are not in darkness" since they are followers of Jesus, seeking to walk according to his teaching. They already know to be prepared for Jesus' return. The contrast with 5:3 makes it likely that Paul was speaking in verse 3 about those who do not know Christ. Both "darkness" and "night" in these verses refer to those who have not yet experienced the illumination of the gospel's shining in their souls. In contrast, the "children of the light/day" are those who now see clearly enough to follow Jesus.

<span id="page-305-10"></span>This darkness/light metaphor provides Paul with multiple applications, especially in combination with Jesus' thief metaphor. Since thieves steal primarily at night (5:2), those who are children of the day/light will not be surprised by the thief. Their lives lived in faith, hope, and love (v. 8) show that they have obtained salvation in Christ (v. 9) as they live out their sanctification by walking in his lightfilled ways. In contrast, those who remain in spiritual darkness will be surprised with sudden destruction at Christ's return (v. 3).

<span id="page-305-15"></span><span id="page-305-13"></span><span id="page-305-11"></span>In verse 5 Paul and his colleagues shift subtly from talking about "you" to speaking about "us." They include themselves alongside the Thessalonian believers as children of light, increasing the sense of fellowship with one another.

<span id="page-305-14"></span>5:6–7 Paul now introduces two additional related metaphors. When he says, "Let us not sleep," he certainly does not mean it literally. Sleep connotes a passive, callous disregard for the need to be prepared. Drunkenness further suggests such irresponsibility. Paul elsewhere commends physical sobriety and avoidance of drunkenness (Gal. 5:21; Eph. 5:18; 1 Tim. 3:3; Titus 1:7), but here the reference is metaphorical (cf. 1 Cor. 15:34). In context, sleep and drunkenness make one illprepared to encounter the surprise of a "thief" during the night.

<span id="page-305-5"></span><span id="page-305-3"></span><span id="page-305-1"></span>Connecting these metaphors to the preceding discussion (1 Thess. 5:4–5) of darkness and light, Paul observes that those who sleep and those who get drunk both inhabit the space of night and darkness. In contrast, the children of light will be found awake and sober and thus prepared for Christ's return (cf. John 12:35–36; Eph. 5:8–14). Thus the directives to "keep awake" and "be sober" refer to being watchful and ready for Christ's appearing.

<span id="page-305-7"></span>Some have understood the wakefulness of the children of light here to relate to cognition, implying that such "children" have studied the Scriptures and thus know the signs well enough to predict Christ's return. However, these images do not work in that way. The ongoing sobriety and wakefulness of the children of light has to do with how they conduct themselves as those living in the day. And, in 5:8, Paul will indicate specifically what such sobriety involves: faith, love, and hope.

<span id="page-305-12"></span>5:8 This verse further explains what Paul's images in 5:4–8 have been pointing toward. What does it look like to be prepared for Christ's return? Preparedness means to conduct our lives in faith, love, and hope in Christ. Note that Paul had previously mentioned this triad of faith, hope, and love (1:3; cf. 1 Cor. 13:13; Gal. 5:5–6; Col. 1:4–5).

<span id="page-305-9"></span><span id="page-305-8"></span><span id="page-305-6"></span><span id="page-305-4"></span><span id="page-305-2"></span><span id="page-305-0"></span>Paul adopts the image of God's heavenly armor from Isaiah 59:17 (in Isaiah, it is the Lord God who wears such armor). In another well-known passage (Eph. 6:14–17), Paul expands on the "armor of God," applying it there, as here, to the armor that God furnishes to equip his saints. Some interpreters (especially of the Ephesians text) tend to wax eloquent on why each concept (such as faith or hope) is matched with a particular piece of Roman military equipment. However, we should be more constrained in our discussions of this imagery, since Paul varies the labels for each piece of equipment in 1 Thessalonians and Ephesians. Thus the <span id="page-306-11"></span><span id="page-306-0"></span>"breastplate" is "righteousness" in Ephesians 6:14 (following Isa. 59:17), whereas in 1 Thessalonians 5:8 the "breastplate" refers to both "faith and love." The broader imagery is Paul's main point: faith, love, and hope are likened to armor that protects believers and prepares them for spiritual battle.

<span id="page-306-12"></span>5:9–10 Paul mentions the "hope of salvation" in 5:8. Verses 9–10 proceed to discuss how God's gracious salvation and redemption in Christ delivers such hope to believers, assuring us that our destiny will not be God's wrath and eternal destruction but rather eternal salvation. While believers are in some sense "saved" in the present, in this particular context "salvation" is juxtaposed with future wrath and judgment, and thus Paul looks forward here to the final salvation of Christ's people in the resurrection.

<span id="page-306-15"></span><span id="page-306-13"></span>Such salvation is obtained (cf. 2 Thess. 2:14) only through the work of Jesus, who is declared both the eternal "Lord" and "Christ." In a brief summary of the gospel (1 Thess. 5:10), Paul reminds the church that Jesus' death was "for us," signifying that his death made atonement for our sins. Moreover, Jesus' resurrection provides the hope that someday we shall live with him—our resurrection lives having been made possible through our union with the risen Christ (cf., e.g., 1 Cor. 15:20–28).

<span id="page-306-10"></span><span id="page-306-9"></span><span id="page-306-5"></span>Paul's mention of "whether we are awake or asleep" affords at least two possible interpretations. It could draw on the concept of sleep/wakefulness found in the immediate context (1 Thess. 5:6–7), but then verse 10 would be at odds with Paul's caution that those who sleep are in darkness and thus in peril of destruction (vv. 3–7). Rather, "whether we are awake or asleep" likely refers back to Paul's discussion at the beginning of his eschatological teaching (4:13–18), where "asleep" refers to the dead in Christ and thus "awake" would then indicate those believers who are presently alive. Concerning Jesus' followers, both the dead in Christ and the currently living believers await our final resurrection and eternal life with Christ.

<span id="page-306-14"></span><span id="page-306-8"></span><span id="page-306-7"></span><span id="page-306-4"></span><span id="page-306-3"></span>5:11 As at the conclusion of the preceding section (4:18), here Paul again invites the Thessalonians to mutual encouragement based on the gospel truths found in Paul's teaching. Alongside "encourage one another," Paul adds "build one another up," which is a further idiom for encouraging and strengthening others (cf. Acts 20:32; 1 Cor. 14:4). The importance of Christian community is here assumed, for if we (both individually and collectively) are to be built up in Christ, we need one another for mutual encouragement. In this verse and throughout the epistle, Paul affirms that the Thessalonians are already following Christ ("just as you are doing"; cf. comments on 1 Thess. 1:6–10; 3:6–7; 4:1); that in itself was one way Paul "encouraged" and "built up" the churches: he commended them for what they were doing well.

### <span id="page-306-6"></span>*Response*

<span id="page-306-2"></span><span id="page-306-1"></span>Many today, as in centuries past, desire to know the precise timing of Jesus' return. Yet in truth, the timing of Christ's appearance will be a surprise (Matt. 24:36–44; Mark 13:32–37; Acts 1:7). Jesus himself teaches this, as does Paul. That is not to say that no signs will precede his return. The difficulty is that many of the signs Jesus <span id="page-307-1"></span><span id="page-307-0"></span>mentions (such as wars, rumors of wars, famines, earthquakes, betrayals, and false prophets; cf. Matt. 24:6–13; Mark 13:7–13) are matters witnessed in every generation, and the moment of final fulfillment of other more definitive signs (such as the gospel's being preached to all nations or the appearing of the abomination of desolation; cf. Matt. 24:14–22) appears difficult to interpret. Discussing such matters can be worthwhile, but everyone should be humble in the conclusions they draw, and no one should seek a day, month, or year for Christ's appearing. Only after Christ has returned will we look back and know clearly the "times and the seasons" (1 Thess. 5:1). Most importantly, Jesus warns that his coming will be like a thief and will take people unaware.

<span id="page-307-3"></span>Jesus and Paul encourage Christians to be simultaneously ever-waiting and ever-ready. We should be prepared for Christ to appear on the clouds of heaven tomorrow, and we should also be willing to wait for his return to be years, decades, or centuries away (cf. Matt. 24:36–25:30).

<span id="page-307-2"></span>What does being prepared for Christ's return look like? Paul's answer is actually rather straightforward: living our lives in faith, hope, and love in Christ. In fact, as we study most of the end-time passages in the NT, we realize a striking continuity in terms of authorial intent. The NT authors encourage Christians to persevere in this world primarily by living out the essential ethics of Christ's kingdom in response to the gracious salvation we hold through Christ's death and resurrection. The timing they leave to God.

Therefore our response to these verses is essentially this: faith, love, and hope. We already know Christ's salvation in the present and have confidence about the future culmination of this salvation at Jesus' return. Believers will indeed be raised to be with our Lord, whose appearance we eagerly await. We do well to encourage and build up one another in these foundational truths.

### <span id="page-307-4"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 5:12–22

**<sup>12</sup>**We ask you, brothers, to respect those who labor among you and are over you in the Lord and admonish you, **<sup>13</sup>** and to esteem them very highly in love because of their work. Be at peace among yourselves. **14**And we urge you, brothers, admonish the idle,*<sup>1</sup>* encourage the fainthearted, help the weak, be patient with them all. **<sup>15</sup>** See that no one repays anyone evil for evil, but always seek to do good to one another and to everyone. **16**Rejoice always, **17**pray without ceasing, **18**give thanks in all circumstances; for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus for you. **19**Do not quench the Spirit. **20**Do not despise prophecies, **21**but test everything; hold fast what is good. **22**Abstain from every form of evil.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-308-7"></span>Having just mentioned the mutual edification of believers (1 Thess. 5:11), Paul now turns to a series of admonitions to the church. These directives are united in how they seek the welfare of the whole church.

Paul begins by asking that church leadership be treated with respect and that peace reign in the church. He moves to address care for troubled members in the congregation, distinguishing between the idlers, the fainthearted, and the weak. Then Paul enjoins continual joy, supplication, and thanksgiving. Finally, he directs the church not to extinguish the work of the Spirit in its midst, applying this especially to how the church receives prophecies and avoids evil.

### *Section Outline*

IV.E. Further Admonitions (5:12–22)

- 1. Esteem Church Leaders (5:12–13)
- 2. Seek to Do Good to All (5:14–15)
- 3. Rejoice and Pray (5:16–18)
- 4. Do Not Quench the Spirit (5:19–22)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-308-8"></span>5:12–13 Paul first directs believers to respect church leadership. From this letter alone, it is difficult to identify what leadership positions (both formal and informal) existed in the Thessalonian church, and we do not know precisely how much time Paul had in Thessalonica to institute a leadership structure. In other communities, Paul regularly established two formal leadership roles—elders/overseers and deacons (e.g., Phil. 1:1; 1 Tim. 3:1–13; 5:17–20; Titus 1:5–9; also Acts 14:23; 20:17, 28). Yet Paul also informally included other coworkers in Christ among his esteemed fellow workers (e.g., Rom. 16:1–16; Phil. 4:2–3).

<span id="page-308-11"></span><span id="page-308-10"></span><span id="page-308-9"></span><span id="page-308-6"></span><span id="page-308-5"></span><span id="page-308-4"></span><span id="page-308-3"></span><span id="page-308-2"></span><span id="page-308-1"></span><span id="page-308-0"></span>Paul depicts these leaders' roles in terms of three responsibilities (all three are participles in Greek, connected by a single definite article): they "labor," "are over you," and "admonish." Paul himself had labored diligently in his ministry prior to leaving Thessalonica (1 Thess. 2:9; 3:5), and he often referred to the ministerial labor of his fellow workers (Rom. 16:6, 12; 1 Cor. 16:16; Phil. 2:25; 4:3; 1 Tim. 5:17). In the second responsibility ("over you"), Paul employs a term (Gk. *proistēmi* ) that he uses elsewhere for leaders directing the churches (Rom. 12:8; 1 Tim. 5:17). When Paul coaches Timothy concerning the selection of church leaders, he engages this term for how someone "manages" his household, arguing that the managing of the church is analogous to the managing of a Roman household (1 Tim. 3:4–5, 12). This term ( *proistēmi* ) can also have connotations of "help" and "devotion" (Titus 3:8, 14). We may thus infer that these leaders have been called to manage the church with the same care they give to their own families. The third responsibility ("admonish you") refers especially to the leaders' role in providing instruction to the church (1 Thess. 5:14; also Rom. 15:14; 1 Cor. 4:14; Col. 3:16). In sum, these leaders work diligently at managing and instructing the church.

In response to these leaders, Paul instructs the congregation to "respect" and "esteem" them "very highly." Such esteem ought to flow from a love for these leaders and a recognition of the labors they perform (note Paul's exact words: "Esteem them very highly *in love because of their work*"). Paul knows well that churches can fight and divide when people undermine the leadership of others (e.g., 1 Cor. 1:10–13), so in other epistles Paul similarly emphasizes the importance of believers honoring their leaders (e.g., 1 Cor. 16:16, 18; Phil. 2:29–30; 1 Tim. 5:17; cf. Heb. 13:17; 1 Pet. 5:5).

<span id="page-309-16"></span><span id="page-309-9"></span><span id="page-309-8"></span><span id="page-309-4"></span><span id="page-309-2"></span><span id="page-309-1"></span>The final admonition in 5:13 states, "Be at peace among yourselves." Similar words were also spoken by our Lord (Mark 9:50), and Paul will elsewhere emphasize the importance of churches dwelling together peacefully (Rom. 12:18; 14:9; 2 Cor. 13:11). In 1 Thessalonians, this admonition appears to be connected with the preceding discussion of attitudes toward leaders—both thematically and by how the discourse shifts substantially after this admonition (i.e., with "we urge you" in 5:14). As Paul says elsewhere, church harmony results from mutual humility combined with a unified focus on Christ (cf. Phil. 2:1–11; 4:2–3).

<span id="page-309-12"></span>5:14 Paul now shifts to discussing how the church ought to respond to its more troubled members. Paul wisely divides these troubled personalities into three categories.

<span id="page-309-15"></span><span id="page-309-13"></span>Those who are "idle" and refuse to work need to be instructed firmly to labor diligently (1 Thess. 4:11–12). In a subsequent letter, Paul provides more detailed instructions on dealing with those who refuse to work (2 Thess. 3:6–12). For a discussion of the word "idle," see comment on 2 Thessalonians 3:6.

<span id="page-309-14"></span><span id="page-309-0"></span>Those who are "fainthearted" should be "encouraged." The Greek word for "fainthearted" (*oligopsychos*) implies someone of lowly spirit who is discouraged or grieved (cf. LXX Prov. 18:14; Isa. 35:4; 54:6; 57:15). And the term for "encourage" ( *paramytheomai*) bears a stronger correlation to "consolation" than do some of Paul's other words for encouragement. Those who are discouraged should be consoled.

<span id="page-309-6"></span><span id="page-309-5"></span><span id="page-309-3"></span>Those who are "weak" need someone to help them. "Weakness" can appear in various contexts in Paul: concerning those of weak conscience (e.g., Rom. 15:1; 1 Cor. 8:7–13), those who are ill (1 Cor. 11:30), or those who are without honor or are deemed weak in other ways by their culture (1 Cor. 1:26–29; 4:10; 9:22). It is difficult to decide on which of these meanings of "weak" best applies in this verse, but perhaps Paul is thinking of a whole range of ways in which someone can be in need both physically and spiritually.

<span id="page-309-11"></span><span id="page-309-10"></span><span id="page-309-7"></span>In a summative way, Paul exhorts the church to "be patient with them all." This certainly encourages patience with those who are troubled in the congregation (whether lazy, fainthearted, or weak), but it likely also commends patience more broadly with everyone in the church. For Paul, patience is a Christian virtue, associated with love (1 Cor. 13:4; cf. also 2 Cor. 6:6), and is to be practiced regularly among church members (Eph. 4:1–3; Col. 3:12–15). Ultimately, the Spirit produces patience in the life of the believer (Gal. 5:22–23). Patience brings church unity, promotes love for one another, and follows the model of longsuffering that God himself constantly exhibits. Since God has been patient with us, we should be patient with one another.

<span id="page-310-18"></span><span id="page-310-17"></span>5:15 In line with the preceding call to patience (5:14), Paul directs these believers to break the cycle of retribution and revenge so common in society. When they receive harm and "evil" from another, they are not to "repay" the offense. Similar instructions are found elsewhere in Paul (Rom. 12:14, 17; 1 Cor. 4:12) and Peter (1 Pet. 2:23; 3:9).

<span id="page-310-23"></span><span id="page-310-3"></span>In contrast to any actions of retribution, the Christian should always pursue the good of those in the Christian communion and beyond. We should seek their welfare (cf. Gal. 6:10).

<span id="page-310-14"></span><span id="page-310-9"></span><span id="page-310-0"></span>5:16–18 This block of verses supplies directives concerning prayer. Paul himself modeled this kind of prayer to the churches—rejoicing in all circumstances (Phil. 1:4, 18; 2:17), praying without ceasing (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 1:2–3; 3:9–10; also Rom. 1:9; 2 Thess. 1:11; 2 Tim. 1:3), and giving thanks on every occasion, especially when he prayed for the churches (1 Thess. 1:2; 2:13; also 1 Cor. 1:4; Eph. 1:16; Phil. 1:3; Col. 1:3; 2 Thess. 1:3; 2:13; Philem. 4).

<span id="page-310-15"></span><span id="page-310-10"></span><span id="page-310-8"></span><span id="page-310-5"></span><span id="page-310-2"></span>Elsewhere Paul commends Christians always to rejoice in the Lord (Phil. 4:4; cf. 2 Cor. 13:11; Phil. 3:1) and to "rejoice in hope" (Rom. 12:12). Paul often rejoices even amid suffering, sorrow, and persecution (e.g., 2 Cor. 6:10; 7:4; Col. 1:24). Paul joyfully looks for ways in which God is at work around him, especially in the churches. Moreover, by "rejoicing in the Lord," Paul indicates that the benefits of salvation and relationship to the Lord Jesus always provide him opportunity for joy, even in the most challenging of circumstances. It is God who fills the believer with joy (Rom. 15:13; Gal. 5:22–23).

<span id="page-310-16"></span><span id="page-310-13"></span><span id="page-310-11"></span><span id="page-310-4"></span>Constancy in prayer follows a common Pauline refrain (Rom. 12:12; Eph. 6:18; Col. 4:2). Paul also repeatedly encourages continual thankfulness to God (Eph. 5:20; Col. 1:11–12; 3:17). As noted in the remarks on 1 Thessalonians 1:2–3, this need not imply that every waking moment is spent in prayer and thankfulness; rather, prayer is a reflexive habit that believers engage in regularly throughout the day. Such moments of prayer also call for expressions of thanksgiving to the Lord for his many good gifts and his saving work in our midst. As with Paul's directive to "rejoice always," believers should find ways to be thankful in the circumstances before us, knowing that even suffering is light and momentary (2 Cor. 1:3–7; 4:16–18) and that final deliverance and eternal good await us at the Lord's return.

<span id="page-310-20"></span><span id="page-310-19"></span><span id="page-310-7"></span><span id="page-310-6"></span>Paul assures us that this approach to prayer (1 Thess. 5:16–18) is according to "the will of God in Christ Jesus" (v. 18). Often people seek after knowledge of God's will, and here there is an explicit statement about what the Lord's will entails (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 4:3; cf. Rom. 12:2; Eph. 6:6; Col. 4:12).

<span id="page-310-22"></span><span id="page-310-21"></span><span id="page-310-12"></span><span id="page-310-1"></span>5:19 In verses 19–22, Paul directs believers not to "quench the Spirit." The verb translated "quench" here typically refers to the putting out of a fire (Eph. 6:16). <span id="page-311-4"></span><span id="page-311-2"></span><span id="page-311-1"></span>The metaphor is appropriate, for the Spirit can be compared to a fire (Matt. 3:11; Luke 3:16; esp. at Pentecost, Acts 2:2–4). However, Paul certainly does not imply that the third person of the Trinity can be extinguished. Rather, the point is that the *work* of the Spirit in the life of the believer and in the church may be smothered and quenched. This is similar to "grieving" or "resisting" the Holy Spirit (Eph. 4:30–32; Acts 7:51; cf. Isa. 63:10; Ps. 78:40). To borrow Paul's language from other epistles, rather than fighting against the Spirit's work, believers and churches ought to "walk by the Spirit" (cf. Rom. 8:4; Gal. 5:16–18, 25–26) and "be filled with the Spirit" (Eph. 5:18), thus continuously exhibiting the "fruit of the Spirit" (Gal. 5:22–23).

<span id="page-311-23"></span><span id="page-311-20"></span><span id="page-311-17"></span><span id="page-311-16"></span><span id="page-311-15"></span><span id="page-311-9"></span>Given that the next two verses refer to prophecy, in which the Spirit works as an active agent, it seems that in 1 Thessalonians 5:20–21 Paul presents representative ways of quenching the Spirit. This likely continues into verse 22, since embracing evil involves fighting against the Spirit's work (Gal. 5:16–26). Thus 1 Thessalonians 5:20–22 help us understand further what it means to quench the Spirit.

<span id="page-311-24"></span><span id="page-311-21"></span><span id="page-311-13"></span><span id="page-311-12"></span><span id="page-311-11"></span><span id="page-311-6"></span>5:20–21 According to Paul, the primary purpose of prophecy in the church is to encourage believers (esp. 1 Cor. 14:1–5, 22–25, 29–40; also Rom. 12:6; 1 Cor. 11:4– 5; 12:10, 28–29; 13:2, 8–9; 1 Tim. 1:18; 4:14). Paul lists NT-era prophets alongside the apostles (and others) as foundational to the building up of the early church (Eph. 2:20; 3:5; 4:11; cf. Luke 11:49), although elsewhere he alludes to the primacy of the apostolic teaching over church prophets (1 Cor. 12:28; 14:37–38; 2 Thess. 2:2). Some NT-era prophets and/or prophetic moments are mentioned in the book of Acts (Acts 11:27–30; 15:32; 19:6; 21:9–14). Notably, Paul and Barnabas are named among the "prophets and teachers" at Antioch (Acts 13:1–3). Throughout these instances, it was assumed that the Spirit still employed prophetic words for the edification of the church. Thus Paul instructs these first-century believers, "Do not despise prophecies" (1 Thess. 5:20). Similarly, he encourages the Corinthians to desire earnestly to prophesy (1 Cor. 14:39).

<span id="page-311-25"></span><span id="page-311-22"></span><span id="page-311-19"></span><span id="page-311-18"></span><span id="page-311-14"></span><span id="page-311-10"></span><span id="page-311-8"></span><span id="page-311-7"></span><span id="page-311-5"></span><span id="page-311-3"></span><span id="page-311-0"></span>Paul also affirms, however, that any such prophecy must be tested (1 Thess. 5:21). Elsewhere he advocates testing and discernment (Gk. *dokimazō*) in the Christian life as a means of proving the genuineness of instruction or conduct (e.g., Rom. 12:2; 1 Cor. 11:28; 2 Cor. 8:8, 20; 13:5; Gal. 6:4; Eph. 5:10; Phil. 1:10); indeed, Paul and his message have been tested by God himself (1 Thess. 2:4). Tests for prophets were similarly important in the OT (Deut. 18:20–22). Testing undoubtedly included submitting the prophetic words to the authority of the OT Scriptures and the NT apostolic witness, evaluating prophetic utterances based on known revelation and consistency with the theology and ethics Jesus handed down through the apostles. Only that which was "good" was to be retained earnestly (on "hold fast," see 1 Cor. 11:2; 15:2; cf. Luke 8:15; Heb. 3:6, 14; 10:23). There was always a danger that false prophets would arise (e.g., Matt. 24:24; 1 John 4:1; 2 Pet. 2:1), so such testing was necessary to prevent destructive beliefs <span id="page-312-8"></span><span id="page-312-2"></span><span id="page-312-0"></span>and practices from being introduced (cf. Matt. 7:15–20; 1 Cor. 12:1–3, 10; 1 John 4:1–3; Rev. 2:2). Many commentators would see Paul's words here as focusing primarily on avoiding such false prophets and heretics, yet Paul also appears concerned that *believers* may speak errant words (1 Cor. 14:29) or that the import of their prophetic statements may be misapplied (cf. Acts 21:11–15). Paul believes such prophetic moments are subsidiary to, and must be tested by, the OT prophets and NT apostolic witness.

<span id="page-312-1"></span>Theologians continue to debate the cessationist position, that prophecy ceased after the close of the NT canon. In theological traditions where continuing prophecy is pursued, it must be with the appropriate instruction that such prophecies should be tested, that they should be viewed as limited in scope, and that they should not serve the revelatory and normative function of Scripture. Yet we must also be careful to allow the Spirit's voice to be heard.

<span id="page-312-4"></span>5:22 Paul closes these verses on "quenching the Spirit" with the command, "Abstain from every form of evil." This coheres with Paul's decree in Galatians not to gratify the desires of the flesh, which are at odds with the good fruit the Spirit grants those who walk by the Spirit (Gal. 5:16–26). The fundamental means of quenching the Spirit is to engage in wicked thoughts, words, and actions. In contrast, the central trait of persons and churches led by the Spirit is that they overflow with the fruit of "love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control" (Gal. 5:22–23).

<span id="page-312-7"></span><span id="page-312-6"></span><span id="page-312-5"></span><span id="page-312-3"></span>The general aphorism of 1 Thessalonians 5:22 provides a fitting conclusion to the immediate series of church admonitions (5:12–22) as well as an appropriate end to the broader Pauline instruction of 4:1–5:22. Such abstinence from evil is not truly possible without the Spirit's working in the hearts of believers, who by God's grace have found their salvation and only hope in Jesus Christ.

### *Response*

NT authors consistently endorse the need for church leadership. Such leaders are called to manage and instruct congregations lovingly. All church members should convey respect and esteem for such leaders. At the same time, the leaders are responsible before God to lead the church into faith, hope, and love—modeling such Christian virtues among themselves and before the congregation. Everyone is to seek the peace and welfare of Christ's body. These instructions seem straightforward, but harmonious congregations full of humble and God-honoring leaders (as well as faithful and respectful parishioners) are strikingly rare. It is thus incumbent on us all to examine how we conduct our church lives, repenting and seeking forgiveness when we injure others. Ultimately, we are called to love all in the church, respecting leaders and caring for everyone.

As we care for the most troubled among us, great wisdom is required. Many need physical assistance, while others need encouragement. However, some require rebuke, lest they exploit church resources when they could be working. Anyone who has served in diaconal ministry knows the great challenge of balancing compassion with wisdom. Paul acknowledges that tension as well. The goal is ultimately the good of the Christian brother or sister; sometimes this necessitates reproof, while on other occasions prayer and a helping hand are best.

As we seek the good of others, we must also break the cycle of retaliation so prevalent in our culture. For example, many a church has been divided by two (or more) sides' refusing to forgive the other. Instead, Jesus calls us to love.

Christians regularly struggle with prayer, perhaps in part because we think it should be easy. Yet regular prayer necessitates cultivating a habitual reflex to turn to God in joy, petition, and thanksgiving. Through prayer we also learn better to rejoice in how God works among us, even in difficult times.

<span id="page-313-0"></span>The church is called to walk in step with God's Spirit, constantly open to his work in our midst. His leading, though, may also be confused by the many voices around us; thus we must be studied in Scripture so that we can test everything for consistency with the revealed Word of God. Moreover, we cannot walk by the Spirit and hold on to the fruit of the flesh (Gal. 5:16–26). Such evils are often subtle, captivating us in ways we do not recognize. Thus we should be regularly repentant and constantly intent on living out the Spirit's good fruit, all to Christ's glory.

### <span id="page-313-2"></span>1 THESSALONIANS 5:23–28

**<sup>23</sup>**Now may the God of peace himself sanctify you completely, and may your whole spirit and soul and body be kept blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ. **24**He who calls you is faithful; he will surely do it.

**<sup>25</sup>**Brothers, pray for us. **<sup>26</sup>**Greet all the brothers with a holy kiss.

**<sup>27</sup>** I put you under oath before the Lord to have this letter read to all the brothers.

**<sup>28</sup>**The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-313-1"></span>Paul commonly closes his letters by varying the standard epistolary forms of his day in order to communicate important final truths to the church. He often includes a benediction, prayerfully invoking on the church the blessing of God the Father and the Lord Jesus (1 Thess. 5:23–24). In these final verses, Paul directs the church to pray for his ministry, to greet one another with a sign of friendship and brotherhood, and to read his letter aloud to the whole church. As he does in all his epistles, Paul ends with an invocation of God's grace.

### *Section Outline*

- V. Benediction and Epistolary Closing (5:23–28)
	- A. Benediction (5:23–24)
	- B. Epistolary Closing (5:25–28)
		- 1. Request for Prayer (5:25)
		- 2. Call for Mutual Greeting (5:26)
		- 3. Public Reading of the Epistle (5:27)
		- 4. Invocation of Grace (5:28)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-314-11"></span><span id="page-314-10"></span><span id="page-314-8"></span><span id="page-314-4"></span>5:23–24 Paul's concluding benedictions typically ask for blessing on the churches to whom he writes (e.g., Eph. 6:23; 2 Thess. 2:16–17; 3:5, 16–18). Paul had previously closed the long first half of this epistle with a benediction addressing (as here) God the Father and the Lord Jesus (1 Thess. 3:11–13). In both benedictions of this epistle, Paul prays for the believers' sanctification in light of Jesus' second coming, thus resonating with the letter's eschatology (4:13–5:11). Differences between the two benedictions, however, also indicate that each is crafted to fit its immediate context and to convey particular emphases. Thus the benediction in 3:11–13 requests that God both grant Paul opportunity to return to Thessalonica and also enable the congregation to grow in mutual love—themes key to the context of chapters 2–3.

<span id="page-314-12"></span><span id="page-314-9"></span><span id="page-314-7"></span><span id="page-314-6"></span><span id="page-314-1"></span>In these verses, Paul prays that the "God of peace" will sanctify the believers "completely." Paul addresses the "God of peace" frequently (e.g., Rom. 15:33; 16:20; Phil. 4:9), and in a related way he often invokes (especially at the beginning of his letters) grace and peace on his readers "from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ" (cf. comment on 2 Thess. 1:2). Sanctification is mentioned earlier in the epistle, especially in the context of sexual purity (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 4:3). Most often in Paul, sanctification refers either to how God renders the believer positionally holy through union with Christ (cf. 1 Cor. 1:2; 6:11; Eph. 5:26) or to how God causes the believer to grow in holy conduct in his or her everyday life. In this verse, the focus appears to be on the church's growth in holy conduct, since this makes best sense of the word "completely" and of the subsequent request that the church be "kept blameless."

<span id="page-314-2"></span>Parallel to his request that God "sanctify you completely," Paul asks for these believers to be kept "blameless" in every aspect of life ("spirit, soul, and body"). There is clear overlap between "sanctify" and being "kept blameless," since both refer to the purity and holiness of the believers.

<span id="page-314-13"></span><span id="page-314-5"></span><span id="page-314-3"></span><span id="page-314-0"></span>Some have pressed "spirit and soul and body" to indicate that human beings are tripartite (also referencing Heb. 4:12), with three distinct parts to our person. However, the NT elsewhere speaks of the whole of a person simply as "spirit and body" (cf. 1 Cor. 5:3; 7:34; 2 Cor. 7:1; Col. 2:5; James 2:26) or alternately as "soul and body" (Matt. 10:28). Indeed, Paul can employ the terms "spirit" and "soul" somewhat interchangeably (cf. Phil. 1:27). Moreover, even if in death our souls are for a while separated from our bodies, humans were created from the beginning to be whole beings, and our resurrection hope is that our souls will find an eternal home in glorified bodies. Thus we need to be careful about developing theories about the nature of our humanity based on such brief passages of Scripture. The broader point here is that Paul asks God to make the church and its individual members holy and blameless in every aspect of their being and lives.

<span id="page-315-7"></span><span id="page-315-0"></span>Paul expresses in a wonderful way his confidence that God is at work in the church. God "calls" his people (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 2:11–12; 4:7) and is "faithful" (e.g., Deut. 7:9; Isa. 49:7; 1 Cor. 1:9). Since God is faithful, he will perform in these believers the sanctifying work to which he called them.

<span id="page-315-10"></span><span id="page-315-4"></span>5:25 Cognizant of the many challenges in ministry, and aware of the importance of prayer, Paul invites congregations to pray with him for his team's mission (e.g., 2 Cor. 1:11; Col. 4:3; 2 Thess. 3:1; cf. Phil. 1:19; Philem. 22). This also connects with his earlier broader directive to "pray without ceasing" (1 Thess. 5:17).

<span id="page-315-11"></span><span id="page-315-9"></span><span id="page-315-5"></span><span id="page-315-3"></span><span id="page-315-2"></span>5:26 In keeping with another common Pauline closing exhortation, Paul asks the congregants to greet one another with a "holy kiss" (cf. Rom. 16:16; 1 Cor. 16:20; 2 Cor. 13:12; cf. 1 Pet. 5:14). Kisses in the first century were performed regularly as greetings between close friends and family (e.g., Luke 7:45; 15:20; Acts 20:37). Similar greetings remain common in Middle Eastern cultures today. When Judas saluted Jesus deceitfully with a kiss, he heinously violated this standard greeting of peace (Mark 14:45).

<span id="page-315-1"></span>Paul commonly calls this greeting a "holy kiss," likely to emphasize its distinctively Christian application among fellow believers, whom Paul often addresses as saints ("holy ones"). A clear desire for unity is conveyed in such greetings between "all the brothers." In ways that connect well with our particular cultures, we should seek to institute forms of greeting and fellowship that promote further unity and lead to the edification of the congregation.

<span id="page-315-12"></span>5:27 Paul desired that all in the church would hear his letter, and thus he delivers this oath. Paul assumes a formal church gathering, likely connected with a worship service. Probably some in the congregation were illiterate. More importantly, books were expensive, and few possessed their own copies of Scripture. Thus the OT was read aloud regularly in church services for the benefit of all. Circulating apostolic letters would receive similar treatment (cf. Col. 4:16; Rev. 1:3).

<span id="page-315-8"></span><span id="page-315-6"></span>Paul shifts suddenly to the first-person singular ("I put you under oath"), perhaps as a way of emphasizing the letter's origins (cf. Introduction: Author). Paul's concern that everyone at Thessalonica should hear the letter may indicate a fear that not all would have the opportunity to do so, and many commentators suggest that Paul was worried about divisions in the community, finding hints of disunity in verses like 1 Thessalonians 4:6; 5:13–15, 20. It is possible that such tensions existed, but Paul does not provide enough direct evidence to know this with certainty.

<span id="page-316-2"></span><span id="page-316-0"></span>5:28 Just as Paul opened his letter by invoking God's grace on the Thessalonians (1:1), so he closes it in a similar way. With varied wording, all of Paul's epistles conclude with an invocation of grace. Although this is Paul's standard way of signing off, it also communicates a true desire for the church to abide in God's grace.

### *Response*

Following Paul's benediction, we do well to pray that God through his Spirit will enable us to walk more in step with his will, in response to his gracious forgiveness and calling in Christ. Ultimately, we know that complete sanctification will be ours only at the coming of Christ, but we should still always seek to walk blamelessly before the Lord, comforted by the forgiveness we have in Christ, even as we stumble every day.

<span id="page-316-1"></span>Finally, Paul again encourages prayer (cf. 5:16–18), with supplication directed especially on behalf of ministry and missions. Following Paul's lead (5:28), another wonderful prayer of the church would be to petition God to grant his grace to all among us. As salvation is by grace through faith in Christ, so also the whole Christian life flows from God's gracious work through his Spirit in our midst.

# 2 THESSALONIANS

*David W. Chapman*

## <span id="page-319-5"></span>INTRODUCTION TO 2 THESSALONIANS

### *Overview*

Paul and his colleagues again write to the fledgling church in Thessalonica, encouraging them to continue persevering amid a society opposed to Christ. They also address particular concerns within this church, notably by opposing any teaching that the Lord's return has already occurred and by admonishing church members to work diligently.

### *Author*

<span id="page-319-2"></span><span id="page-319-1"></span>Like 1 Thessalonians, this epistle lists its authors as Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy. The letter typically employs first-person plural references to all three authors. However, as in 1 Thessalonians, Paul is clearly the lead author, since he twice switches to first-person singular ("I" in 2:5; 3:17). Moreover, Paul concludes this letter with his personal word to the congregation, signing the epistle himself. The reasons Paul authors this epistle with his colleagues are similar to those behind 1 Thessalonians. All three missionaries had been present at the founding of the church (Acts 17:1–10), and Timothy had at one point returned to Thessalonica to encourage the believers (1 Thess. 3:1–10).

<span id="page-319-7"></span><span id="page-319-6"></span><span id="page-319-4"></span><span id="page-319-3"></span><span id="page-319-0"></span>The epistle affirms Pauline authorship (2 Thess. 1:1), follows Pauline style, and was universally accepted in the early church as Paul's epistle. However, some modern scholars debate Paul's contribution to the letter. Those objecting to Pauline authorship argue that the theology does not include some standard Pauline themes; that the letter appears to draw extensively on 1 Thessalonians for source material; that the epistle seems less personal than 1 Thessalonians; and that the eschatological material in 2 Thessalonians 2:1–12 (expecting clear signs to precede Jesus' return) is at odds with 1 Thessalonians 5:1–11 (where Jesus' return comes as a surprise). Responses to these objections include: (1) Since Paul wrote each of his epistles to audiences with different needs, not every letter contains every major Pauline theme. (2) Simultaneously, overlap in content and style between 1 and 2 Thessalonians would be expected from the same author writing to the same audience, yet variations in tone and content also testify to the shifting situation at Thessalonica (cf. Date and Occasion). (3) Most importantly, the eschatological questions at Thessalonica changed between the writing of these two letters,

<span id="page-320-10"></span>requiring Paul to lean into the same material in different ways. (4) Jesus himself taught both that his return would come like a thief and that it would be presaged by signs (cf. comment on 2 Thess. 2:3–4); thus Paul follows Jesus' approach to eschatology in both letters. Thus, none of these objections warrants abandoning the self-testimony of the letter and the early church's strong support for Pauline authorship.

### *Date and Occasion*

<span id="page-320-0"></span>This epistle was penned after 1 Thessalonians, apparently while Paul was still engaged in his second missionary journey (while Silas and Timothy were still with him), though a date early in the third journey cannot be ruled out. Nevertheless, a date in the early to mid-50s AD seems most likely. For Paul's interaction with the Thessalonians prior to this letter, cf. Introduction to 1 Thessalonians: Date and Occasion.

<span id="page-320-11"></span><span id="page-320-6"></span>Three developments in Thessalonica apparently caused sufficient concern to Paul and his colleagues for them to pen this second letter. First, the need for continued endurance amid persecution receives repeated attention (1:4; 2:13–15, 17; 3:3–5, 13). Second, a false belief had arisen claiming that the sequence of events leading to Christ's return had already begun (2:1–12). Third, the problem with idleness in the community, already identified in the previous letter (1 Thess. 4:11–12; 5:14), required a firmer reprimand (2 Thess. 3:6–12).

### <span id="page-320-2"></span><span id="page-320-1"></span>*Genre and Literary Features*

Paul adopts many Greco-Roman epistolary conventions, though he modifies them to his missionary purposes. Thus his opening greeting and epistolary closing have been fitted to his Christian theology of grace and peace rooted in the living God and the lordship of Christ.

<span id="page-320-9"></span><span id="page-320-3"></span>The opening thanksgiving and prayer signals topics to which Paul and his colleagues will return (cf. Overview of 2 Thess. 1:1–12). The bulk of the central section addresses whether the day of the Lord has already arrived (2:1–12). The final chapter provides directives for Christian living, especially concerning the problem of idleness in the church (3:6–12). Paul closes with a benediction and an invocation of grace.

### *Theology of 2 Thessalonians*

<span id="page-320-8"></span><span id="page-320-7"></span><span id="page-320-5"></span><span id="page-320-4"></span>Many standard Pauline theological themes appear here in condensed form. He references frequently the grace and glory of God the Father and the Lord Jesus in the lives of the believers (1:2, 9, 12; 2:14, 16; 3:16, 18). God is just and faithful (1:5; 3:3). God has sovereignly chosen the church for salvation by faith through the sanctifying work of the Spirit (2:13). Believers respond to God's grace in faith and love (1:3–4, 10–11; 2:10, 12, 13–14; 3:2, 5). Then, as the church of those sanctified by God's grace, their salvation issues forth into the performance of good works (1:11; 2:17; 3:13–15).

<span id="page-321-6"></span><span id="page-321-5"></span><span id="page-321-4"></span>The church can be confident that their just God will overcome the enemies of Christ's church (1:5–10; 2:8–12). This confidence is rooted in the hope of Jesus' return (1:7–10; 2:1–12), which will be preceded by the rise of the man of lawlessness (2:3–12). In fact, the world already experiences the satanic influence of lawlessness (2:7). Nonetheless, God remains sovereign over the time and manner of divine judgment on those who align with Satan (2:6, 8, 11–12).

<span id="page-321-9"></span><span id="page-321-8"></span><span id="page-321-7"></span><span id="page-321-3"></span><span id="page-321-2"></span>Paul's theology springs forth into ethics, especially encouraging the church to endure present affliction (1:4; 2:13–15, 17; 3:3–5, 13). Paul models thanksgiving and prayer (1:3, 11–12; 2:13, 16–17; 3:16, 18), inviting the church to pray for and with him (3:1–2). He also emphasizes the importance of Christians' earning their own livelihood (3:6–12).

### <span id="page-321-10"></span>*Relationship to the Rest of the Bible and to Christ*

<span id="page-321-1"></span>This epistle often connects thematically with Paul's other letters, but a particularly close relationship exists with 1 Thessalonians, especially in themes of endurance, diligent work, and eschatology. As in his previous letter, Paul's thought is indebted throughout to the teaching of the OT and of Jesus. This is especially obvious in the eschatological section, where concepts of the "day of the Lord" and the "man of lawlessness" overtly employ OT prophetic concepts and Jesus' eschatological instruction (esp. Matthew 24–25; Mark 13; Luke 21).

### <span id="page-321-0"></span>*Preaching from 2 Thessalonians*

Expository preaching of this letter should enable the modern audience to empathize with its ancient readers, drawing out contemporary analogs to the challenges the Thessalonians faced. The theme of endurance amid opposition should feature strongly in preaching this epistle. Paul's own model of Christian living calls for imitation. Also, we should be humble in our preaching regarding eschatological controversies, since the original readers, who had experienced Paul's eschatological teaching in person, were in a better position than we are to understand what Paul has left unsaid in this letter (cf. comments on 2:1–12). For further ideas, cf. Introduction to 1 Thessalonians: Preaching from 1 Thessalonians.

### *Interpretive Challenges*

As noted already, scholars have debated the issue of Pauline authorship. Discussions about the possible rhetorical structure of the letter have influenced commentaries on both 1 and 2 Thessalonians (cf. Introduction to 1 Thessalonians: Interpretive Challenges for 1 Thessalonians).

However, the bulk of interpretive questions in 2 Thessalonians focus on the central eschatological section (2:1–12). As noted above, some academics have emphasized differences between the eschatological teaching in 1 and 2 Thessalonians, though this supposed tension is best explained by the changing nature of the questions that arose in the Thessalonian church (cf. above <span id="page-322-3"></span><span id="page-322-1"></span><span id="page-322-0"></span>under Author, also Date and Occasion). One prominent commentary recently suggested that 2 Thessalonians was actually written *before* 1 Thessalonians, with the serious eschatological concern of 2:1–12 giving way to lesser issues later in 1 Thessalonians 4:13–5:11.1 Against this, however, 2 Thessalonians implies the existence of a previous letter (2:15), while 1 Thessalonians does not. More importantly, it is quite conceivable that some in this young church became influenced by heightened eschatological expectations between the penning of 1 Thessalonians and the present letter. We need not assume that a great deal of time was required for such eschatological fervor to arise, since false views can develop quickly in the early life of a church (as testified by the many heretical movements Paul confronted in his ministry).

The sequence of end-time events implied by the epistle has been a matter of debate over the centuries. We should recognize that part of this debate springs from how Paul speaks in condensed language to the Thessalonians, since they had previously heard him teach more fully in person on such matters; thus Paul could abbreviate his discussion about such issues as the "man of lawlessness" and the "restrainer," even if we today might wish for more information (cf. comments on 2 Thess. 2:1–12).
