The central paragraph calls for church members not to fall into idleness but to work heartily. Returning to themes from earlier in the letter, this section concludes with an exhortation not to grow weary in doing good works and a warning against any who disregard the apostolic teaching.

### <span id="page-347-0"></span>2 THESSALONIANS 3:1–5

3 Finally, brothers,*<sup>1</sup>* pray for us, that the word of the Lord may speed ahead and be honored,*<sup>2</sup>* as happened among you, **<sup>2</sup>** and that we may be delivered from wicked and evil men. For not all have faith. **3**But the Lord is faithful. He will establish you and guard you against the evil one.*<sup>3</sup>* **<sup>4</sup>**And we have confidence in the Lord about you, that you are doing and will do the things that we command. **5**May the Lord direct your hearts to the love of God and to the steadfastness of Christ.

1Or *brothers and sisters*; also verses 6, 13 2Or *glorified* 3Or *evil*

### *Section Overview*

Paul and his colleagues ask the Thessalonians to pray on behalf of the Pauline mission in order that the gospel would spread and that their ministry would be protected. Paul also reminds the church that the faithful Lord will defend them. He expresses confidence in the Thessalonians, focusing on their obedient response and on how the Lord will root them in love and endurance.

### *Section Outline*

- IV. Final Admonitions (3:1–15)
	- A. Request for Prayer, and Confidence in the Church (3:1–5)
		- 1. Prayer Request for Paul's Ministry (3:1–2)
		- 2. The Lord Will Establish the Church (3:3–5)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-348-10"></span><span id="page-348-6"></span>3:1–2 As in their earlier letter (1 Thess. 4:1), Paul and his colleagues transition via the word "finally" from a mid-letter benediction to a series of admonitions. This use of "finally" in the middle of the letter serves to shift the discourse and to introduce important new material (also Phil. 3:1; cf. comment on 1 Thess. 4:1).

<span id="page-348-8"></span><span id="page-348-7"></span><span id="page-348-3"></span>Paul requests the brothers and sisters in the church to "pray for us" (cf. 1 Thess. 5:25). As Paul and his colleagues pray regularly for the Thessalonians (2 Thess. 1:11), so they also invite the church to pray on their behalf. Church members (vocational ministers and laity alike) should participate regularly in mutual prayer for one another.

<span id="page-348-5"></span><span id="page-348-4"></span><span id="page-348-0"></span>Paul first invites the Thessalonians to pray that "the word of the Lord" would be spread through the ministry of Paul and his team (cf. Col. 4:3). The word of the Lord is the good news of Christ, focused on Jesus' teaching, death, and resurrection (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 1:8–10; 4:15). Specifically, Paul asks that the word of the Lord would both "speed ahead" and "be honored." The Greek word for "speed ahead" (*trechō*) refers literally to running; Paul requests via this idiom for the gospel to progress quickly through the Roman world (cf. Ps. 147:15). The term for "be honored" (Gk. *doxazō*) anticipates that this gospel would be extolled as glorious by those who receive it (cf. 2 Thess. 3:1 ESV mg.). Thus Paul petitions that the gospel of Christ would spread far and deep, penetrating throughout the empire and being embraced fully by the recipients. Paul also inserts a reassuring remark to the Thessalonians ("as happened among you"), indicating that he and his colleagues—the Thessalonians' fathers in the faith—affirm gladly that the word of the Lord is active and honored in the Thessalonian church.

<span id="page-348-13"></span><span id="page-348-12"></span><span id="page-348-11"></span><span id="page-348-9"></span><span id="page-348-2"></span><span id="page-348-1"></span>Second, Paul asks that he and his colleagues "may be delivered from wicked and evil men" (3:2). This word for "wicked" (Gk. *atopos*) is somewhat rare in the NT. It designates something that is out of place; idiomatically, it may refer to perverse and twisted behavior (cf. Luke 23:41; Acts 25:5). Paul knows the present age is "evil" (Gal. 1:4; also Eph. 5:16), filled with opposition to God and under the influence of the Evil One (2 Thess. 3:3), even while the Lord steadily builds his church. In the age to come, God will deliver his people from evil and grant them eternal salvation (2 Tim. 4:18), but Paul's concerns here are more immediate. Throughout Paul's missionary travels, he and his colleagues encountered much opposition to the gospel,

<span id="page-349-14"></span><span id="page-349-2"></span>as the Thessalonians would recall (Acts 17:5–10). With apparent understatement, Paul remarks in verse 2 that "not all have faith." Paul and his colleagues ask for prayer that their ministry might go forth amid such human opposition, even as the Lord provides times of deliverance in their daily lives and mission.

<span id="page-349-17"></span>Sometimes God's deliverance results in immediate relief from opposition; on other occasions, however, our ability to perceive God's rescuing hand requires a long-range view of God's work both in this world and to eternity (e.g., 2 Tim. 3:10–13; 4:15–18). We often require God's wisdom to recognize and appreciate the surprising directions that his providential deliverance follows.

<span id="page-349-9"></span><span id="page-349-8"></span><span id="page-349-7"></span>3:3 In contrast to the faithlessness of the unbelievers in this world (3:2), the Lord is faithful (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 5:23–24). He is trustworthy, for he always acts consistently with his holy, just, and loving character. Since "Lord" is a biblical title for both God the Father and Jesus Christ, it can be difficult to know for certain in some contexts whether Paul refers to the first or second person of the Trinity (e.g., 2 Thess. 1:9; 2:2, 13; 3:1, 3, 4, 5, 16). Concerning this verse, we note that Paul most commonly applies the term "Lord" to Jesus in this epistle (1:1, 2, 7, 8, 12; 2:8, 14, 16; 3:6, 12, 18; cf. also comment on 1 Thess. 1:1); on the other hand, Paul typically speaks of God the Father as "faithful" (1 Cor. 1:9; 10:13; 2 Cor. 1:18). Thus the interpretive evidence goes in different directions. Of course, Paul affirms the faithfulness and universal lordship of both of these members of the Trinity, and in Paul's benedictions he commonly invokes the sovereign work of both in the life of the believer (2 Thess. 2:16–17).

<span id="page-349-13"></span><span id="page-349-12"></span><span id="page-349-5"></span><span id="page-349-3"></span>Since the Lord is faithful, the Thessalonians can be assured that he will both "establish you" and "guard you against the evil one." Just a few verses earlier (cf. comment on 2:17), Paul had prayed for the Lord Jesus Christ and God our Father to "establish" the believers' hearts in "every good work and word." Thus Paul expresses confidence in 3:3 that the faithful triune God will indeed work in precisely the way Paul prayed for in 2:17.

<span id="page-349-18"></span><span id="page-349-15"></span><span id="page-349-10"></span><span id="page-349-6"></span><span id="page-349-1"></span><span id="page-349-0"></span>Paul informs the church confidently that God will "guard you against the evil one." The "evil one" is the Devil/Satan (e.g., Matt. 13:38–39; Eph. 6:11, 16; 1 John 3:8–12), the fallen angelic adversary of God's people (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 2:17–18). Jesus teaches us to pray for God's protection against the Evil One (Matt. 6:13; John 17:15), and Paul has previously affirmed the sovereignty of God over Satan (cf. 2 Thess. 2:6–12 and comments). Given the bleak truth about Satan's coming activity through the man of lawlessness (esp. 2:9–10), the Thessalonians must have been comforted by Paul's statement here, with its assurance of the Lord's work to establish and protect them.

<span id="page-349-16"></span><span id="page-349-11"></span><span id="page-349-4"></span>3:4 Paul and his colleagues continue to express confidence in the Lord on behalf of the church. Paul's confidence is not directly "in the church" but rather "in the Lord" (cf. Gal. 5:10; Phil. 2:24). Paul trusts the Lord to fortify his church unto obedience to the apostolic instruction. Note how he affirms their obedience both in the present and in the future. This statement of confidence encourages these believers in multiple ways, reminding the reader that they are "in the Lord," that the Lord is ultimately the agent who works obedience among them, and that Paul already appreciates their current obedience and has good reason to hope for their future Christian diligence. This verse also indirectly reminds the readers to follow Paul's apostolic teaching.

<span id="page-350-2"></span><span id="page-350-0"></span>3:5 Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy insert another brief benedictory prayer amid these admonitions. The "steadfastness of Christ" likely indicates the endurance Christ exemplified during his earthly ministry. Consequently, the parallel construction "love of God" speaks of God's love for the Thessalonians (cf. 2 Thess. 2:13, 16; cf. Rom. 5:5; 8:39; 2 Cor. 13:14). Thus Paul petitions the Lord to direct the Thessalonians' "hearts" (cf. comment on 2 Thess. 2:17) to contemplate both God's love for them and Jesus' endurance. Such contemplation will embolden them further in their own perseverance and love.

### <span id="page-350-1"></span>*Response*

Those in ministry should follow Paul's lead in inviting others to pray for our work. Similarly, it is a high calling to pray for others as they engage in gospel ministry, including missionaries, ministers, and ministry volunteers. Note how Paul's prayer desires both extensive and intensive growth of the gospel—that it would go to many places and grow deeply in the hearts of those who respond. This forms a wonderfully balanced vision for gospel expansion.

God is indeed faithful. Thus we need not fear human or demonic opposition, since the Lord establishes and defends his people. We should publicly express confidence in the work of God among believers around us, for such expressions provide great encouragement to others and follow the apostolic model (3:4). Finally, our Christian walk should be marked by hearts directed "to the love of God and to the steadfastness of Christ."

### <span id="page-350-3"></span>2 THESSALONIANS 3:6–12

**<sup>6</sup>**Now we command you, brothers, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you keep away from any brother who is walking in idleness and not in accord with the tradition that you received from us. **7**For you yourselves know how you ought to imitate us, because we were not idle when we were with you, **8**nor did we eat anyone's bread without paying for it, but with toil and labor we worked night and day, that we might not be a burden to any of you. **<sup>9</sup>** It was not because we do not have that right, but to give you in ourselves an example to imitate. **10**For even when we were with you, we would give you this command: If anyone is not willing to

work, let him not eat. **11**For we hear that some among you walk in idleness, not busy at work, but busybodies. **12**Now such persons we command and encourage in the Lord Jesus Christ to do their work quietly and to earn their own living.*<sup>1</sup>*

1Greek *to eat their own bread*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-351-7"></span>Some in Thessalonica refused to work (2 Thess. 3:11), so Paul and his colleagues remind the church of their previous instruction: those who can work should do so (vv. 10–12). Indeed, Paul and his team previously modeled an industrious approach to labor.

### *Section Outline*

The word "command" combined with "in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ" in the opening and closing verses of this paragraph forms an *inclusio* (repeating the same key terms at the beginning and end of a section for emphasis). For this reason, 3:6–12 likely forms a single coherent paragraph, with 3:13 beginning a new section.

<span id="page-351-9"></span>IV.B. Directive to Work and Cease from Idleness (3:6–12)

- 1. Keep Away from the Idle Brother (3:6)
- 2. Paul's Example (3:7–9)
- 3. Paul's Command (3:10)
- 4. Directive to the Idle Brother (3:11–12)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-351-4"></span><span id="page-351-3"></span><span id="page-351-2"></span><span id="page-351-1"></span>3:6 Several features emphasize the importance Paul attaches to these instructions. First, this paragraph receives more space than any other admonition in chapter 3. Second, Paul opens with the words "we command you," reminding the reader that only two verses earlier he has expressed confidence that the Thessalonians "are doing and will do the things that we command" (3:4). Third, Paul delivers this charge in verse 6 "in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ" (cf. 1 Cor. 5:4; 6:11; Eph. 5:20; Col. 3:17), adding extra solemnity to his words (cf., e.g., Acts 16:18). Fourth, Paul returns to the "command" vocabulary as an *inclusio* at the paragraph's end (2 Thess. 3:12), with such repetition highlighting the importance of his directives. Finally, the example of Paul and his team provides a model of the diligent behavior they demand in this passage (3:7–10).

<span id="page-351-8"></span><span id="page-351-6"></span><span id="page-351-5"></span><span id="page-351-0"></span>Verse 6 commands believers to avoid anyone in the church who refuses to work. The person to be avoided is specifically labeled a "brother." The verb translated "keep away" (Gk. *stellō*) is rare in the NT, but lexicons understand it to denote the shunning or avoidance of someone. The brother to be avoided walks in "idleness," with the Greek word (*ataktōs*) referring to behavior that is undisciplined, disorderly, or defying social convention. In context, this unruly conduct takes particular form in a person's refusal to work or earn his own living (esp. 3:10–12).

<span id="page-352-4"></span>This undisciplined idleness runs counter to the instruction Paul and his colleagues have delivered to the church ("the tradition that you received from us"). Paul and company taught in Thessalonica about the importance of dutiful work (3:10; also 1 Thess. 4:11), which they also modeled to the believers by apostolic example (2 Thess. 3:7–10). Moreover, the same directive had been restated in their previous letter (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 4:10–12; 5:14).

<span id="page-352-11"></span><span id="page-352-9"></span><span id="page-352-7"></span><span id="page-352-3"></span>This admonition to "keep away" from the idle brother, with notions of shunning and avoidance, may sound harsh to modern ears, yet Paul does not demand cutting them off from all forms of contact, since a few verses later he presumes that these idle brothers will be present in the congregation to hear this instruction (3:12). Moreover, Paul is concerned that the church could be pressured into providing assistance to people who are fully capable of working. This would draw resources away from the truly needy (cf., e.g., 1 Tim. 5:3, 9–10) and would enable the freeloaders to busy themselves in ways morally destructive to them and damaging to others in the church (cf. comments on 2 Thess. 3:10–12). Also, these loafers have been previously instructed to find employment, and their refusal to heed the apostolic mandate points to deeper spiritual problems. Therefore, the church must avoid supporting them in any way, and believers should be careful in their interactions with such people in order to discourage their slothfulness and moral indolence (cf. also 3:14–15).

<span id="page-352-10"></span><span id="page-352-8"></span><span id="page-352-6"></span><span id="page-352-5"></span>A number of commentators attempt to link this problem of idleness with eschatology, another major concern in 2 Thessalonians. Some have speculated that an apocalyptic millenarian fervor, especially one assuming that the day of the Lord was already upon the believers in Thessalonica (2:2), had led some church members to forsake their work in civil society, under the assumption that such work would be unnecessary when Christ returns. Paul himself, however, makes no explicit connection between these instructions and his earlier discussion of eschatology.

<span id="page-352-2"></span><span id="page-352-1"></span><span id="page-352-0"></span>More importantly, Paul had been concerned from his earliest days in Thessalonica that some in the church were inclined to laziness and sloth, which is why he began instructing the congregation about this even while he was in Thessalonica (3:10). Such early instruction almost certainly occurred before any Christian apocalyptic speculation could have run rampant among these new believers. Furthermore, Paul and his colleagues addressed the issue of work and idleness in their first letter (1 Thess. 2:9–10; 4:11–12; 5:14), and there is little in that letter to suggest apocalyptic speculation had driven congregants toward an avoidance of work (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 4:10–12). It seems more likely that Paul is concerned that the Greco-Roman model of itinerant pagan philosophers may be promoting an avoidance of work, perhaps also demeaning those who engage in manual labor (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 2:9–10). Paul also encourages other congregations toward respecting manual labor (Eph. 4:28; Col. 3:23–24). Hence, this tendency to idleness at Thessalonica is likely tied to cultural assumptions in Greco-Roman society. Beyond that, the Scriptures have long recognized a sinful human propensity to sloth (Prov. 12:24, 27; 19:15; 31:27; Eccles. 10:18; Matt. 25:24–30; Titus 1:12).

<span id="page-353-14"></span><span id="page-353-9"></span>3:7–8 In contrast to the idlers, Paul reminds his audience of the diligent work he and his team displayed in Thessalonica, commending the church to imitate their industrious model (3:9). Imitation is a key theme in Pauline ethics (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 1:6), succinctly stated in his command to "be imitators of me, as I am of Christ" (1 Cor. 11:1). The moral example of believers to one another forms a key encouragement and pattern as all seek to follow Christ.

<span id="page-353-12"></span><span id="page-353-8"></span><span id="page-353-5"></span><span id="page-353-1"></span>In contrast to some lazy Thessalonians (2 Thess. 3:6), Paul and his colleagues "were not idle when we were with you." More specifically, they did not "eat anyone's bread without paying for it." Paul was a tentmaker (Acts 18:3) who probably plied his trade "with toil and labor" whenever time allowed (for "night and day," cf. 1 Thess. 2:9; 3:10). Much of this content overlaps with 1 Thessalonians 2:9–10, where Paul notes similarly that he and his colleagues sought not to be a "burden" to the congregation. However, the concerns in 1 Thessalonians focus more on distinguishing their missionary conduct from that of pagan itinerant teachers and philosophers (cf. comments on 1 Thess. 2:5–6; 2:9–10). Here the issue centers on the need to earn one's own living and not burden the church (3:10; cf. Acts 20:33–35).

<span id="page-353-16"></span><span id="page-353-10"></span><span id="page-353-4"></span><span id="page-353-2"></span><span id="page-353-0"></span>3:9 Paul and his team had a right to receive financial compensation from those to whom they were ministering (1 Cor. 9:8–14; 1 Tim. 5:17–18; cf. Luke 10:7–8), but they chose to abandon that right for the sake of the fledgling congregation (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 2:5–6; cf. 1 Cor. 9:3–18; 2 Cor. 11:7–13). Paul again emphasizes the importance of the church's imitating this example of industrious work (cf. 2 Thess. 3:7).

<span id="page-353-17"></span><span id="page-353-13"></span><span id="page-353-6"></span><span id="page-353-3"></span>3:10 Their example in Thessalonica also came with instruction: "If anyone is not willing to work, let him not eat." Paul is not rejecting the giving of alms to truly needy individuals or churches (cf., e.g., Acts 24:17; Rom. 15:25–28; 1 Cor. 16:1–3; 2 Cor. 8:1–5; 1 Tim. 5:3, 9–10), but he is concerned about those who are "not *willing* to work." Their refusal to labor should not be rewarded with church beneficence, lest they become habituated to donations when they could otherwise be productive. Everyone who can work should do so for their own welfare, their families, and the needs of others (Eph. 4:28; 1 Thess. 4:11; 5:14). Paul advises that the natural consequences of such idleness ("let him not eat"; contrast 2 Thess. 3:8) should motivate these idlers to work.

<span id="page-353-18"></span><span id="page-353-15"></span><span id="page-353-7"></span>3:11–12 Paul and his colleagues have received a report about people's "walking in idleness." In addition to causing individual spiritual harm and being a fiscal drain on the church, such refusal to work tends to spill over into other injurious behavior. Thus the idle become "busybodies" (Gk. *periergazomenoi* ), designating those who become intrusively engaged in the activities of others. They begin to meddle in other people's lives, leading to gossip, criticism, and disharmony in the community (cf. comment on 1 Thess. 4:10–12; also 1 Tim. 5:13).

<span id="page-353-11"></span>Paul closes by addressing the idlers directly. The combination of "we command and encourage" emphasizes the directive that follows, as does the solemnity of <span id="page-354-4"></span><span id="page-354-2"></span>"in the Lord Jesus Christ" (cf. 2 Thess. 3:6). They are to "do their work quietly," as Paul states the imperative both to work heartily and to avoid acting as gossiping busybodies or grumbling laborers (contrast 3:11). Paul directs them further to "earn their own living," with the Greek literally indicating that they should "eat their own food" (contrast 3:10).

### <span id="page-354-3"></span>*Response*

Those charged with diaconal ministry often face difficult decisions, since not everyone who asks for help is truly in need. Sponsoring the lazy can simply enable their propensity to avoid work. It may also provide them opportunity to follow unprofitable pursuits, such as gossip, excessive personal entertainment, drugs, sensuality, or other addictive behaviors. It is right and good to be careful about whom we give money and resources, lest those resources be squandered and the recipients ultimately harm themselves spiritually or injure others. At the same time, it is a wonderful ministry to help those who truly are in need. Some people simply cannot work, and they deserve our Christian care. Others need to be supported until they can function as capable workers—through medical assistance, training, counseling, etc.

<span id="page-354-1"></span><span id="page-354-0"></span>Our society sometimes admires the lazy. Movies, books, songs, and other aspects of popular culture can champion those who sit around all day, soaking up the sun, gaming the system for handouts, and playing it cool. Many would prefer not to work but to have every desire in life happily fall into their laps. Yet we must remind ourselves, and instruct others, that God gave mankind good and meaningful work to do even before the fall (Gen. 1:26–28; 2:5–25; cf. the Response section on 1 Thess. 4:9–12). Although humanity's fallen condition at times turns such labor into drudgery and challenge, diligent labor is still to be encouraged as a vital aspect of Christian ethics.

### <span id="page-354-5"></span>2 THESSALONIANS 3:13–15

**<sup>13</sup>**As for you, brothers, do not grow weary in doing good. **<sup>14</sup>** If anyone does not obey what we say in this letter, take note of that person, and have nothing to do with him, that he may be ashamed. **15**Do not regard him as an enemy, but warn him as a brother.

### *Section Overview*

Paul charges the church to persevere in their good works. Paul and his colleagues then underscore the previous instruction in the letter (especially the directives against idleness) by commanding the church to disassociate from those who disobey the apostolic teaching. However, such disobedient participants in the church are still to be considered brothers in the Lord, and they should be warned so that they may repent and experience the full benefits of following the Lord.

### *Section Outline*

IV.C. Do Not Grow Weary, but Warn Others (3:13–15)

- 1. Do Not Grow Weary in Doing Good (3:13)
- 2. Warn the Disobedient Brother (3:14–15)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-355-7"></span><span id="page-355-5"></span>3:13 This short verse forms a hinge between 3:6–12 and the following verses. Given the *inclusio* in 3:6–12 (cf. Section Outline discussion for 3:6–12), verse 13 likely begins a new short paragraph (3:13–15; cf. ESV).

<span id="page-355-3"></span><span id="page-355-2"></span><span id="page-355-0"></span>Paul redirects his address to the whole of the church ("as for you, brothers"; cf. Gal. 4:28; 1 Thess. 5:4). The prohibition here is against growing weary in doing good. The Greek verb for "grow weary" (*enkakeō*) refers to becoming discouraged or losing enthusiasm; it is elsewhere often translated "lose heart" (Luke 18:1; 2 Cor. 4:1, 16; Eph. 3:13). "Doing good" appears in a similar admonition in Galatians 6:9–10, referring to the performance of moral good on behalf of others, especially among believers.

<span id="page-355-8"></span><span id="page-355-4"></span>3:14–15 Paul and his colleagues insist that the church must obey their letter. To modern ears, this may seem overly confident or demanding, but Paul's letter bears apostolic witness that none today can claim. He is also well aware of this young church's tenuous situation amid persecution from their countrymen. Thus Paul rightly asserts the authority and import of his words.

<span id="page-355-9"></span><span id="page-355-1"></span>The Thessalonians are to "note" those who choose to defy the apostolic command and are to "have nothing to do" with them. In a manner akin to keeping away from the idle brother (3:6), they are to disassociate from such a disobedient person (cf. 1 Cor. 5:9, 11). As in 2 Thessalonians 3:6, such shunning does not mean considering the person an enemy or even disavowing the person as a believer (cf. Titus 3:10–11). Rather, the person is to be warned and rebuked. The church avoids such people for the purposes of (1) seeking their good, so that they will repent, and (2) seeking the welfare of the church in society, lest disrepute be brought on the church or other members be tempted to similar disobedience. The connection to 2 Thessalonians 3:6, as well as the context of 3:6–13, may indicate that this command is relevant particularly to the issue of those who refuse to work; however, it is likely that anyone who intentionally and flagrantly transgresses an apostolic command should be similarly warned and disassociated, especially those who teach or exemplify immoral behavior.

### <span id="page-355-6"></span>*Response*

We are not saved by good works, but we honor our crucified and risen Savior as we persevere in doing good for the sake of his name. Those who refuse to pay heed to the clear teaching of Scripture, on the other hand, need to be rebuked by the church, even as we pray for and love them. At times it becomes necessary to disassociate from others when they refuse repeatedly the loving admonition of fellow believers, although we always do so with the caring desire that such erring brothers and sisters may return to following Christ. We should not rush to disassociate from fellow believers, since we all need the mutual support of Christian fellowship in order to remain encouraged in our Christian walk.

### <span id="page-356-4"></span>2 THESSALONIANS 3:16–18

**<sup>16</sup>**Now may the Lord of peace himself give you peace at all times in every way. The Lord be with you all.

**<sup>17</sup>** I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand. This is the sign of genuineness in every letter of mine; it is the way I write. **18**The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.

### *Section Overview*

In these closing words, it is again evident that Paul has been the central author among his colleagues. He invokes peace on the congregation, assures them of his authorship of the letter, and concludes with his regular greeting of grace.

### *Section Outline*

- V. Benediction and Epistolary Closing (3:16–18)
	- A. Benediction (3:16)
	- B. Paul's Signed Greeting (3:17)
	- C. Invocation of Grace (3:18)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-356-5"></span><span id="page-356-3"></span><span id="page-356-2"></span><span id="page-356-1"></span><span id="page-356-0"></span>3:16 Paul closes with a word of benediction, the third in this letter (cf. 2:16–17; 3:5). With "Lord of peace" we again face the question of whether Paul is referring to the first or the second person of the Trinity (cf. comment on 3:3), though perhaps here the Lord Jesus Christ is most in view (3:18). Paul specifically requests the "Lord of peace" to grant the church that very "peace" that is essential to the Lord's nature. Paul similarly prays for peace to be upon the church in his conclusion to other letters (e.g., Gal. 6:16; Eph. 6:23), much as he often opens his epistles with a similar appeal (cf. comment on 2 Thess. 1:2). The Greek, like the English, emphasizes Paul's request for God to apply this peace to the church in a comprehensive way ("at all times in every way").

<span id="page-357-9"></span><span id="page-357-1"></span>In addition to requesting peace, Paul follows a traditional Jewish blessing by requesting the very presence of the Lord to "be with" everyone in the church (cf. Ruth 2:4; 1 Sam. 20:13; 1 Chron. 22:16; 2 Tim. 4:22). Assuming from the context that "the Lord" likely refers to the Lord Jesus (2 Thess. 3:12, 18), it is remarkable to compare this with the OT, where similar benedictions consistently refer to Yahweh, the covenant name of the Lord God (cf. Deut. 2:7; 20:1; Josh. 1:9; Judg. 6:12, 16; Jer. 42:11; Amos 5:14). Paul's use of a parallel expression for the Lord Jesus implies a very high Christology.

<span id="page-357-6"></span><span id="page-357-3"></span><span id="page-357-2"></span><span id="page-357-0"></span>3:17 Much correspondence in antiquity was written with the assistance of a secretary, or amanuensis, who was trained in penmanship and Greek (cf. Rom. 16:22). Paul, however, interposes text in his "own hand" in this closing greeting. As observed above (cf. comments on 2 Thess. 1:1; 2:5), this indicates that the letter is fundamentally the apostle's work, even though he includes Silvanus and Timothy as coauthors throughout. Paul may have feared that his opponents would attempt to falsify letters in his name (cf. 2:2), so he had developed this means of authenticating his letters (cf. 1 Cor. 16:21; Gal. 6:11; Col. 4:18; Philem. 19).

<span id="page-357-10"></span><span id="page-357-8"></span><span id="page-357-5"></span><span id="page-357-4"></span>3:18 Paul commonly closes his letters with a brief prayer for the Lord's grace to be with all of the church (cf. 1 Thess. 5:28). This standard closing would also serve as a mark of authenticity (like 2 Thess. 3:17). More importantly, Paul's last words in this letter reemphasize his opening focus on grace (1:2).

### <span id="page-357-7"></span>*Response*

Gospel ministers do well to imitate Paul's habit of invoking grace and peace on the people of God; thus church services often conclude with a benediction. However, we can all earnestly pray for peace and grace to be granted to one another. Moreover, in this epistle we are wondrously reminded that Jesus is present among us, since believers are in union with Christ.

# INTRODUCTION TO THE PASTORAL EPISTLES

*Denny Burk*

### *Overview*

<span id="page-359-1"></span>The Pastoral Epistles are so named because they focus squarely on pastoral issues. These epistles are concerned with the order of God's household, which Paul describes as "a pillar and buttress of the truth" (1 Tim. 3:15). They address the roles of men, women, elders, deacons, widows, slaves, and all of the other diverse personalities that contribute to the church's life and worship. These epistles discuss the self-discipline and teaching of church leaders and their responsibility to confront false teaching head-on in the name of Jesus and in the power of the Holy Spirit. Finally, these letters encourage the endurance required of faithful ministers as they pursue a "long obedience in the same direction,"1 as they suffer for the work of the ministry, and even as they face death as a result of preaching the Word.

The Pastoral Epistles are focused on the extraordinary power of the gospel carried out through the ordinary ministries of men who exhibit exemplary character and holiness. These letters are not just for pastors, however; they are for everyone who has a stake in the life and ministry of the local church. Pastors are not the only ones called to give themselves to the Word of God and to holiness. Rather, pastors are called to be examples of gospel fidelity and holy habits. Their lives are to be a template of faithfulness and perseverance for every single member of the congregation.

### *Title and Recipients*

No titles were originally attached to these books. But, like Paul's other canonical letters, these three books are named after their addressees—in this case Timothy and Titus. The contents of the two letters to Timothy indicate that 1 Timothy was

<span id="page-359-0"></span><sup>1</sup> Eugene H. Peterson, *A Long Obedience in the Same Direction: Discipleship in an Instant Society* (Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity Press, 2000).

<span id="page-360-1"></span>written before 2 Timothy, and that order is reflected in the various titles that have been assigned to these letters.

These letters have been known collectively as the "Pastoral Epistles" since at least the eighteenth century.2 Some have suggested that "pastoral epistles" is a misnomer because these three books are by no means "manuals of pastoral theology."3 It is true that these letters are not systematic treatises on pastoral theology, but there are nevertheless reasons for considering them together. First, significant linguistic and conceptual parallels tie these three books together. Second, these are the only books in the Pauline corpus addressed to individuals rather than to churches.4 Third, their subject matter is filled with "pastoral advice" concerning how Timothy and Titus should lead the churches in Ephesus and Crete.

Timothy and Titus are not "pastors" in the usual sense of the term. They do not fill the office of elder/overseer, although they will enforce qualifications for the men who do. Timothy and Titus are more aptly understood as apostolic delegates—both of them sent by Paul to address specific concerns in Ephesus and Crete, respectively.

As apostolic delegates, Timothy and Titus bear a unique authority in their oversight of the churches to which Paul sent them. Certain aspects of their ministries, therefore, may be unique to their own calling and may not have a direct correspondence to ordinary pastoral ministry. As delegates of Paul, they possess a unique authority that no pastor living today could possibly claim for himself.5 Having said that, we can see that some of the responsibilities given to Timothy and Titus overlap directly with the responsibilities of elders/overseers, chief among them being the responsibility to oversee a congregation and to instruct God's people in sound doctrine.

That is, in part, why their teaching and oversight are often regarded as models for pastoral ministry. Timothy and Titus helped to prepare their churches for the transition from the apostolic era to the post-apostolic era, in which churches would be led exclusively by elders and overseers.6 So, while Timothy and Titus do not occupy the office of elder/overseer per se, they do undertake pastoral functions in Ephesus and Crete. This may explain why early church tradition regarded them both as bishops: "Timothy is related to have been the first appointed bishop of the diocese of Ephesus, as was Titus of the churches of Crete" (Eusebius, *Ecclesiastical History*, 3.4.6). Early tradition also suggests that Timothy and Titus returned to Ephesus and Crete later in life to serve as bishops in those places.7

<sup>2</sup> Donald Guthrie notes that the term "pastoral epistles" was first used by D. N. Berdot in 1703 and popularized by Paul Anton in 1726. See Donald Guthrie, *New Testament Introduction*, 4th ed. (Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity, 1990), 607.

<sup>3</sup> Ibid., 1.

<span id="page-360-2"></span><sup>4</sup> Note that Paul's epistle to Philemon is addressed not only to Philemon but also "to Apphia our sister, and to Archippus our fellow soldier, and to the church that meets in your house" (Philem. 2 AT). Even though the Pastorals are formally addressed only to Timothy and Titus, however, it is clear that Paul intends for the letters to be read to the entire congregation (cf. comments on 1 Tim. 6:20–21; 2 Tim. 4:19–22; Titus 3:15). 5 Walter L. Liefeld, *1 and 2 Timothy, Titus*, NIVAC (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 1999), 23.

<span id="page-360-0"></span><sup>6</sup> Andreas J. Köstenberger, *Commentary on 1–2 Timothy and Titus*, Biblical Theology for Christian Proclamation (Nashville: B&H, 2017), 8.

<sup>7</sup> See Arthur Cushman McGiffert's discussion in notes 7 and 8 in Eusebius of Caesarea, "The Church History of Eusebius," trans. Arthur Cushman McGiffert, in *NPNF2* 1:136.

In the commentary that follows, references to Timothy and Titus in pastoral terms are designed to highlight their pastoral function (not their office) as apostolic delegates and as exemplars to those who would become elders/overseers.8

### *Author*

<span id="page-361-0"></span>The letters to Timothy and Titus all claim to have been written by the apostle Paul (1 Tim. 1:1; 2 Tim. 1:1; Titus 1:1). Until recent times, this claim was virtually uncontested. From the earliest days of the Christian church, these letters' authenticity has been widely assumed. Evidence demonstrates that these letters were known and used by Polycarp, Clement of Rome, Justin, Heracleon, and others. The letters also appear in the Muratorian Canon as part of the Pauline letters. Their absence from Marcion's canon and from the Chester Beatty Papyri (P46) is not nearly as significant as critics suggest. Marcion was known for deleting sections of Scripture that failed to fit his theological agenda. The missing leaves from P46 are hardly dispositive.9 All in all, the overwhelming testimony from the earliest witnesses is that the letters to Timothy and Titus were authentically Pauline. This testimony, however, is often eclipsed by the critical mass of modern scholars that denies Pauline authorship. Yet the current majority view is not nearly as impressive when set against what G. K. Chesterton called the "democracy of the dead"—the faith of the church throughout the ages. There can be no question that the democracy of the dead has cast a weighty vote in favor of Pauline authorship.

Nevertheless, this tradition has been vigorously challenged in the modern period. Today, the majority view among scholars is that the Pastoral Epistles were written by a single author under a false name—a practice called pseudonymity. Donald Guthrie summarizes the case against Pauline authorship under four headings: (1) the historical problem, (2) the ecclesiastical problem, (3) the doctrinal problem, and (4) the linguistic problem.10

<span id="page-361-3"></span><span id="page-361-2"></span><span id="page-361-1"></span>(1) The historical problem with Pauline authorship is the alleged difficulty of reconciling historical allusions in these letters to data of the Acts account of Paul's ministry. According to 1 Timothy 1:3, Paul left Timothy to lead the church in Ephesus when the apostle was on his way to Macedonia. Likewise, in Titus 1:5 Paul says that he left Titus in Crete to set things in order there. In 2 Timothy 1:16–17, Paul says that Onesiphorus sought him while he was imprisoned in Rome. Critics allege that these trips to Ephesus and Crete followed by a final Roman imprisonment cannot be reconciled with what we know of Paul's life and ministry from the book of Acts. But this skepticism seems unfounded.

There have been two main approaches to reconciling these historical allusions to Paul's ministry in Acts. One approach says that these historical allusions may be understood within the Acts framework. Those who take this view say that there

The other approach (and the one adopted in this commentary) posits a second Roman imprisonment of Paul after the narrative of Acts ends. On this view, Paul was released from the Roman imprisonment recorded at the end of Acts. After his release, Paul would have engaged in further ministry and travels, including the trips to Ephesus and Crete. Eventually, Paul was rearrested and put in prison, from which he wrote 2 Timothy while anticipating execution. Although some critics claim that a second Roman imprisonment is an expedient to preserve Pauline authorship, Philip Towner cautions that "the scenario of a release from a first Roman imprisonment should not be too quickly dismissed."11 There is clear evidence that Paul engaged in missionary activity after being released from a Roman captivity (cf. *1 Clem.* 5.7; Muratorian Canon; *Acts of Peter* 1.1; Eusebius, *Ecclesiastical History* 2.22).12

(2) The ecclesiastical problem with Pauline authorship alleges that the letters to Timothy and Titus emphasize church order and office in a way that Paul's earlier, undisputed letters do not. Paul's earlier letters seem to expect an imminent return of Christ. The Pastorals reflect a period in which the imminent return of Christ is no longer expected and in which the church is settling in for the long haul by setting up institutional structures that will preserve the apostolic tradition. In Bart Ehrman's words, "The clerical structure of these letters appears far removed from what we find in the letters of Paul, but it is closely aligned with what we find in proto-orthodox authors of the second century."13

<span id="page-362-4"></span><span id="page-362-3"></span><span id="page-362-0"></span>But the so-called ecclesiastical problem is overblown. Philippians is one of the undisputed letters of Paul, and yet Philippians begins with an address to the "overseers and deacons" (Phil. 1:1). This would be a strange way to address the Philippians if "overseers and deacons" did not become fixtures until the second century. Also, Luke's account of Paul's ministry shows him appointing elders *during* his missionary journeys (cf. comment on Titus 1:5). We note a three-part pattern that Paul pursues in his church-planting efforts in Acts 14:21–23: (1) Paul makes converts through preaching the gospel, (2) he strengthens new believers through discipleship and instruction, and (3) he provides for the appointment of pastors/ elders "in every church" (v. 23) to carry on the work after he is gone. Indeed, one of the most poignant scenes in all of Scripture is Paul's farewell to the Ephesian elders in Acts 20:17–38. Among other things, Paul reminds these elders of the "whole counsel of God" and of their responsibility to "pay careful attention to yourselves and to all the flock, in which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to care for the

<sup>13</sup> Bart D. Ehrman, *The New Testament: A Historical Introduction to the Early Christian Writings*, 4th ed. (New York: Oxford University Press, 2008), 399.

<span id="page-363-0"></span>church of God, which he obtained with his own blood" (Acts 20:27–28). Unless we are to reject the reliability of Luke's account, we must conclude that from the very beginning of Paul's ministry he was concerned with establishing sound apostolic doctrine through the appointment of elders.

<span id="page-363-5"></span>(3) The doctrinal problem with Pauline authorship alleges that the Pastorals reflect a period in which the Christian faith was becoming a fixed body of doctrinal truth, and that period of concern for confessions and orthodoxy did not emerge until the second century. For example, the emphasis in the Pastorals on "the teaching" suggests a well-defined body of truth conveyed by the apostle and needing to be preserved (e.g., 1 Tim. 4:16; 6:3; 2 Tim. 3:10; 4:3). Likewise, references in the Pastorals to "the faith" suggest a discrete set of Christian truths to be known and propagated (e.g., 1 Tim. 1:10; Titus 1:9, 13). According to Ehrman, this "propositional" use of the term "faith" contrasts with the "relational" emphasis of faith in the undisputed letters. Ehrman concludes, therefore, that the Pastoral Epistles must have been written in a generation after Paul's.14

<span id="page-363-4"></span><span id="page-363-2"></span><span id="page-363-1"></span>There really is no doctrinal problem if one simply observes that Paul's undisputed letters also show Paul's interest in the apostolic faith. In Galatians 1:23, the Christians once persecuted by Paul are recorded as saying of him, "He who used to persecute us is now preaching *the faith* he once tried to destroy" (emphasis mine). In 1 Corinthians 16:13, Paul exhorts the Corinthian believers to "be watchful, stand firm in *the faith*" (emphasis mine). To believe that *faith* is only a "relational" term in the undisputed letters requires the reader to set aside clear evidence to the contrary (cf. "faith" in Eph. 4:5; Phil. 1:27; Col. 2:7).

<span id="page-363-3"></span>(4) The linguistic problem alleges that the vocabulary and style of the Pastorals is so different from Paul's language in the undisputed letters that the Pastorals could not have been written by him. P. N. Harrison, e.g., contends that the linguistic peculiarities of the Pastorals "are the work of one mind, and that mind, another than Paul's."15 Harrison contends further that the style reflects the language of the second century, not the first.16

The alleged linguistic problem is based on fairly unreliable criteria. I refer readers elsewhere for a fuller response to Harrison's work.17 Here it will suffice to say that there is nothing about the linguistic peculiarities of the Pastorals that cannot be explained by the ordinary observation that a single author is capable of a multitude of expressions. And sometimes the purpose and nature of the writing itself accounts for differences of style between discrete literary works from the same author. One will notice, e.g., a marked difference between a letter I might compose as a cover letter for a résumé and an e-mail that I may write to my wife. The Pastorals are, after all, the only letters in the Pauline corpus addressed to single individuals. Should we not expect some differences of vocabulary and style based on that fact alone?

<sup>15</sup> P. N. Harrison, *The Problem of the Pastoral Epistles* (London: Oxford University Press, 1921), 17.

<sup>16</sup> Ibid., 67–68.

<sup>17</sup> Guthrie, *New Testament Introduction*, 633–636.

The case against Pauline authorship is not as strong as some scholars suggest. In fact, the weight of the evidence remains in favor of the traditional view that Paul is the author of the letters to Timothy and Titus.

### *Date and Occasion*

The letters of 1 Timothy and Titus are occasioned by the fact that false teachers have found a foothold within the Ephesian and Cretan congregations. Paul writes to Timothy and Titus to exhort these pastors to oppose those false teachers with the apostolic gospel. This is why Paul is urgent in calling Timothy and Titus to identify qualified elders who will likewise oppose false teaching and join the work of shepherding the flock. In 2 Timothy, the fact that Rome is likely to execute Paul in the near term gives his words added impetus. Paul's words in 2 Timothy, therefore, have an urgent appeal for Timothy to stay faithful to preaching the Word after the apostle has died.

<span id="page-364-2"></span>As mentioned above, this commentary agrees with the view that Paul experiences a second Roman imprisonment not included in the book of Acts. After Paul is released from the imprisonment recorded at the end of Acts, he engages in further ministry, including trips to Ephesus and Crete (mentioned respectively in 1 Tim. 1:3 and Titus 1:5). Eventually, Paul is rearrested and placed in prison, from which he writes 2 Timothy while anticipating execution. The evidence suggests that Paul arrived in Rome the first time around AD 59–60. If we allow a few years for the first Roman imprisonment, then he would have been released around AD 62. That means that 1 Timothy and Titus would have been written sometime around the middle 60s.18 If we follow Eusebius's dating of Paul's martyrdom to AD 67, then Paul likely would have written 2 Timothy in AD 66 or 67. However, most modern scholars date his execution to AD 64 or 65, and so an earlier date is possible as well.19

### *Genre and Literary Features*

The letters to Timothy and Titus are clearly personal letters of the sort that were quite common in antiquity. Such letters, as seen in the NT, typically bore a fourfold format:

- *Salutation*: The salutation consists of a reference to the sender, a naming of the recipients, and a greeting (e.g., "grace and peace").
- *Thanksgiving* and/or *Prayer*: This section typically expresses thankfulness to God for the recipients.
- <span id="page-364-0"></span>• *Body*: This is the main part of an NT letter. Sometimes the body is divided between theological and ethical instruction (e.g., Rom. 1:18– 11:36 versus 12:1–15:33).
- <span id="page-364-1"></span>• *Conclusion*: The conclusion can include items such as a wish for peace, an expression of affection, a concluding autograph, a benediction, a doxol-

ogy, greetings to various individuals, greetings from those accompanying the sender, prayers, prayer requests, and news about travel plans.20

That the letters to Timothy and Titus exhibit all the hallmarks of a first-century letter is uncontroversial. What is controversial is whether these letters are pseudonymous, i.e., written in another person's name. If the Pastorals are pseudonymous, then Paul is not actually the author, and we can only speculate about who in fact is. Belief that the Pastorals are pseudonymous is the majority view among scholars today. I. Howard Marshall describes the scholarly landscape:

The reigning . . . hypothesis is that the letters were written much later than Paul by some unknown person who was using Paul's authority to say what he believed that the church of his day needed to know. He chose to use Paul's name and hide himself behind it because for him Paul was the only apostle and the source and foundation of the teaching which he believed that the church needed.21

Many of those who hold the Pastorals to be pseudonymous also believe that the author intended to deceive his readers into thinking that the letters derived genuinely from Paul. Bart Ehrman, e.g., argues that these letters are "forgeries." There were no copyright laws in the ancient world and no means of mass-producing literature. For that reason, some authors attached false names to their writings in order to "get a hearing for one's own views."22 Whatever the reason, most scholars believe that the practice of pseudonymity—however well-intentioned—involved the intent to deceive.

It is here that pseudonymity presents a moral contradiction to Christian notions of truth. It also raises an argument against these letters' being pseudonymous. Marshall explains:

This type of pseudonymity involves an intent to deceive the readers into the belief that it was the apostle himself who was writing. This conflicts with the fact that there was a high regard among early Christians and in the NT for truth and truthfulness. . . . People so motivated would have been unlikely knowingly to write or accept deceptive, pseudonymous works. The composition of Christian writings and the intent to deceive were not compatible. . . . Consequently, it can be argued on the basis of the early church's attitude to truth that the practice of deceptive pseudonymity in the first century by defenders of orthodox Christianity is extremely improbable.23

22 Ehrman, *New Testament*, 381.

<sup>20</sup> My discussion of this fourfold format combines material from Robert H. Stein, *A Basic Guide to Interpreting the Bible: Playing by the Rules*, 2nd ed. (Grand Rapids, MI: Baker, 2011), 190; and Robert L. Plummer, *40 Questions about Interpreting the Bible*, 40 Questions Series (Grand Rapids, MI: Kregel, 2010), 279–280.

<sup>21</sup> I. Howard Marshall, *A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on the Pastoral Epistles*, ICC (London/New York: T&T Clark, 1999), 80.

<sup>23</sup> Marshall, *Pastoral Epistles*, 83–84. Marshall himself does not believe that Paul wrote the Pastoral Epistles. Nevertheless, he finds the alleged acceptance of pseudonymity among early Christians to be morally and historically dubious. He therefore suggests an alternative approach, which he calls "allonymity."

All of the arguments in favor of the Pastorals' being pseudonymous rely in part on the idea that pseudonymity was a well-known and accepted literary convention of the day. But this claim is highly suspect. As Towner has shown, pseudonymity is "better attested in Intertestamental Judaism and in the Greco-Roman philosophical schools than in early Christianity."24 In fact, the evidence shows that where Christians recognized pseudonymity, they rejected it.

<span id="page-366-0"></span>The apostle Paul himself rejects pseudonymity by warning his readers not to be misled by a "letter seeming to be from us" (2 Thess. 2:2). The Muratorian Canon (2nd century) lists two books "forged under the name of Paul . . . and also several others which cannot be received into the Catholic Church, for it is not suitable for gall to be mingled with honey" (*Fragments of Caius*, in *ANF* 5:603). Serapion, Bishop of Antioch (2nd century), explains why he rejects the so-called *Gospel of Peter*: "We receive both Peter and the other Apostles of Christ; but as experienced men we reject the writings falsely inscribed with their names, since we know that we did not receive such from [our fathers]."25 Tertullian (3rd century) rejects "writings which wrongly go under Paul's name" and tells of a presbyter who was removed from office after confessing and being convicted of falsely writing a book in Paul's name (Tertullian, *On Baptism* 17, in *ANF* 3:677). Concerning the early Christian period, Donald Guthrie rightly concludes that "where the pseudonymous device was recognized it was not merely not tolerated but emphatically condemned."26 It is simply not plausible to contend that early Christians accepted pseudonymity either in the apostolic period or afterward.

### *Theology of the Pastoral Epistles*

### THEOLOGY OF 1 TIMOTHY

<span id="page-366-7"></span><span id="page-366-4"></span><span id="page-366-1"></span>Paul intends to confront the false teaching proliferating at Ephesus with the gospel of Jesus Christ. He intends for Timothy to lead this charge by opposing these false teachers directly and by appointing elders who will also contend for the faith (3:1–7). Paul says that the goal of such confrontation is to rekindle love in the hearts of the false teachers (1:5). Until they turn back from their error, they risk not only their own souls but also those of the whole congregation (1:19–20). Because of this, Paul tells Timothy that his ministry will be like "warfare" against the false teachers he must openly oppose (1:18). Paul says that he himself is the chief of sinners but has tasted the mercy of God in salvation through Christ (1:15). Paul intends for Timothy and the Ephesian Christians to pray for conditions conducive to others being able to hear the gospel message and experience that same mercy (2:1–7). For this reason, men and women need to behave in worship together in a way that brings credit to that message (2:8–15). And the church must present

<sup>25</sup> Serapion's remarks are preserved in Eusebius's *Ecclesiastical History* 6.12. See Eusebius, *The Ecclesiastical History*, trans. J. E. L. Oulton, vol. 2, The Loeb Classical Library 265 (Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1932), 41. The translation above is from Brooke Foss Westcott, *A General Survey of the History of the Canon of the New Testament*, 4th ed. (London: Macmillan, 1875), 386.

<sup>26</sup> Guthrie, *New Testament Introduction*, 1019.

<span id="page-367-3"></span><span id="page-367-2"></span>itself in the world for what it is—a "pillar and buttress of the truth" (3:15). Even though many apparent believers will apostatize (4:1–4), Paul says that Timothy must pay close attention to himself and to his teaching. Timothy's perseverance in this regard will culminate not only in his own eschatological salvation but also in the eschatological salvation of those to whom he is ministering (4:15–16).

#### <span id="page-367-4"></span>THEOLOGY OF 2 TIMOTHY

<span id="page-367-9"></span><span id="page-367-8"></span><span id="page-367-7"></span><span id="page-367-6"></span><span id="page-367-5"></span>Paul exhorts Timothy not to be ashamed of Paul's imprisonment for the gospel. On the contrary, Timothy must share in and embrace this same vocation of affliction for the sake of the gospel (1:8). Salvation is, after all, a benefit that comes to sinners by grace and not by works, according to the eternal plan of God through Christ Jesus (1:9–12). For this reason, Timothy must follow the pattern of sound words that Paul has taught him and must guard the gospel in the face of those who would oppose it (1:13–15). As a good soldier of Christ Jesus, Timothy must pass the gospel on to the next generation (2:1–7), because even though Paul is bound, the gospel is not bound (2:8–10). Therefore, Timothy's vocation is to be a faithful workman who handles rightly the word of truth (2:15). In order to avoid the unfaithfulness of false teachers (2:17–19), he must "flee youthful passions and pursue righteousness" (2:22–23), all the while seeking to persuade his opponents (2:24–26). Paul warns Timothy of godlessness in the last days (3:1–9) and of the necessity of holding fast to Scripture as God's Word (3:10–17). As Paul contemplates his forthcoming execution, he exhorts Timothy to preach the Word and to endure until the very end (4:1–8).

### <span id="page-367-15"></span><span id="page-367-14"></span><span id="page-367-13"></span><span id="page-367-12"></span><span id="page-367-11"></span><span id="page-367-10"></span>THEOLOGY OF TITUS

<span id="page-367-19"></span><span id="page-367-18"></span><span id="page-367-17"></span><span id="page-367-16"></span>Paul instructs Titus to appoint elders in the church who will be able to do two things: (1) "give instruction in sound doctrine" and (2) "rebuke those who contradict it" (1:5–9). These kinds of pastors must take their stand in the church because of the looming threat posed by false teachers (1:10–16). Titus is to instruct every age and gender group in the church to be faithful to sound doctrine (2:1–10), because the grace of God *must* transform the lives of those it touches (2:11–15). Paul instructs Titus and the congregants in Crete to cultivate healthy relationships with those outside the church and to realize that they too were once sinners on the outside (3:1–3). But because of the mercy of God in Christ, they have been brought near (3:4–7). Paul says that the good works of believers will be "profitable" for those outside the church, but their internal disputes will not be (3:8–9). That is why the "person who stirs up division" must be cast out if he does not repent (3:10–11).

### <span id="page-367-23"></span><span id="page-367-22"></span><span id="page-367-21"></span><span id="page-367-20"></span>*Relationship to the Rest of the Bible and to Christ*

<span id="page-367-1"></span><span id="page-367-0"></span>The Pastoral Epistles are like a capstone to the Pauline corpus. Elsewhere, Paul has explained in masterful detail how the gospel of Jesus Christ is the fulfillment of OT revelation (e.g., Rom. 1:1–7) and has taught that all of the old covenant promises are "Yes" and "Amen" in Christ Jesus (2 Cor. 1:20). Paul teaches that Gentiles who

<span id="page-368-3"></span><span id="page-368-2"></span><span id="page-368-1"></span>believe in Christ have been grafted into the rich root of Israel and now partake of the promised blessings to Abraham (Rom. 11:17). As a result, both Jews and Gentiles are now a part of one people of God—the church (Eph. 2:11–22). This church is built on a foundation consisting of the apostolic and prophetic messages, which derive from Jesus himself (Eph. 2:20). Paul's aim in the Pastorals is the continued maintenance of that apostolic foundation amid challenges from false teachers.

### *Preaching from the Pastoral Epistles*

Two recommendations can help those planning to teach on the Pastoral Epistles. The first is to preach these letters in order: verse-by-verse, line-by-line, word-byword. It is possible to construct a topical series from these books, but the structure of Paul's argument and meaning is often lost in such an approach. A topical approach may be fruitful in other sections of Scripture (e.g., the Proverbs), but a verse-by-verse exposition of the Pastorals will be the most fruitful way to bring forth the whole message and argument of Paul in these books.

<span id="page-368-5"></span><span id="page-368-4"></span><span id="page-368-0"></span>Second, even though these books are called the Pastoral Epistles, they are not intended only for pastors. When Paul wrote letters, he intended them to be read aloud to the entire congregation (the "you" is plural in 1 Tim. 6:21; 2 Tim. 4:22; Titus 3:15; cf. also 1 Thess. 5:27; Col. 4:16). This means that Paul intended his pastoral instructions to Timothy and Titus to benefit each of their respective congregations. These letters do not merely command pastors to be faithful in creed and in conduct for their own sake; rather, the pastors are supposed to be exemplary in this regard so that the entire congregation may walk in the same paths of faithfulness. Contemporary exhortations to Christian congregations must have the same focus.

### *Interpretive Challenges*

The question of pseudonymity is perhaps the most decisive interpretive watershed of the Pastoral Epistles. Those who view these works as pseudonymous tend to treat these letters as a distinct corpus, separate from the other Pauline letters. While there are many reasons that people adopt such a "corpus" approach to reading the Pastorals, Philip Towner highlights the downside to this method:

Their net effect in modern scholarship has been to isolate these letters from the other Pauline letters and consign them rather rigidly to their own corpus. Consequently . . . these three letters have struggled in recent times for a place in discussions about Pauline theology.27

Not every such approach to reading the Pastorals leads to a complete disjunction of the Pastorals from Pauline theology, but the ones that presuppose pseudonymity certainly do. It is commonplace among pseudonymous readings to view the Pastorals as a distinct and even contrary development of Pauline theology. Such

<sup>27</sup> Towner, *Letters to Timothy and Titus*, 1.

readings observe a difference between the perspective of the authentic Paul in the undisputed letters and the pseudonymous "Paul" of the Pastorals.

<span id="page-369-2"></span><span id="page-369-1"></span>For example, Bart Ehrman argues that the authentic Paul expressed an egalitarian sensibility as seen in texts like Galatians 3:28: "There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is no male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus." Nevertheless, Paul's teaching retains a certain ambivalence, as he still urged the continuance of some social distinctions (e.g., 1 Cor. 11:3ff.). The pseudonymous "Paul," however, is alleged to reflect a later period in the history of the church in which the subordination of women was emphasized at the expense of Paul's more egalitarian themes.28 According to this point of view, the Pastorals reflect not Pauline theology but later developments. In this way, the Pastoral Epistles should be treated as a distinct corpus, not as in any way a reflection of authentic Pauline themes.

<span id="page-369-0"></span>This commentary takes a contrary point of view. As argued above, the case against pseudonymity and for Pauline authorship is compelling, and thus we must view these letters within the context of Paul's other writings. What Paul says in the Pastorals about gender issues, e.g., should inform what he has said elsewhere on the topic (e.g., Galatians and 1 Corinthians). And what Paul has said elsewhere on the topic should be taken into account when reading what Paul says on the same subject matter in the Pastorals. Tom Schreiner is correct: "Paul . . . wrote thirteen letters (in my view), and so we have a larger corpus from which to construct his thought."29 Whatever affinities there may be among the Pastorals that may justify calling them a "corpus," such affinities should not lead to a hermeneutical disjunction from the rest of Paul's letters. The thirteen canonical letters of Paul issue from a single author and offer complementary perspectives, not contradictory ones.
