### <span id="page-456-2"></span>2 TIMOTHY 1:1–2

1 Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God according to the promise of the life that is in Christ Jesus, **<sup>2</sup>**To Timothy, my beloved child: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-456-0"></span>As in 1 Timothy, the first two verses of 2 Timothy constitute the opening greeting of the letter. In these kinds of first-century letters, the opening would typically consist of three parts: (1) reference to the sender, (2) reference to the recipient, and (3) a greeting. Paul uses this form throughout his letters, and 2 Timothy is no exception, although Paul has put his own spin on the form and adapted it for his own Christian purposes (table 7.1).

### TABLE 7.1: Paul's Three-Part Salutation in 2 Timothy 1:1–2

| Sender    | Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God according to the<br>promise of the life that is in Christ Jesus, |
|-----------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Recipient | To Timothy, my beloved child:                                                                                        |
| Greeting  | Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.                                               |

The opening contains material that is key to interpreting the rest of the book. Paul Christianizes a standard expression of greeting (*chairein*) by transforming it into "grace, mercy, *and* peace" (*charis*, *eleos*, and *eirēnē*).

### *Section Outline*

- I. Pastoral Courage for Suffering (1:1–18)
	- A. Opening Greeting (1:1–2)
		- 1. Sender (1:1)
		- 2. Recipient (1:2a)
		- 3. Greeting (1:2b)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-456-3"></span><span id="page-456-1"></span>1:1 The first word identifies Paul as the sender and author of the letter (cf. discussion of authorship in Introduction to the Pastoral Epistles: Author). As in other letters, Paul identifies himself and his office in order to reiterate his authority as an apostle (for more on the office of apostle, see comment on 1 Tim. 1:1).

Paul says that he is "an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God." Jesus charged Paul as an apostle in an expression of the singular divine will. Paul's authority is grounded in the purposes of God the Father, announced by the ministrations of Jesus, and empowered by the Holy Spirit (cf. 2 Tim. 1:7, 14). Trinitarian authority empowers Paul's ministry.

<span id="page-457-2"></span><span id="page-457-0"></span>The last phrase in verse 1 tells us the "object and intention"1 of Paul's apostleship: "according to the promise of the life that is in Christ Jesus." The promise of life is God's promise to bring salvation and life through the Messiah Jesus (e.g., Gal. 3:16). Paul was to be an authoritative proclaimer of Christ's resurrection from the dead, which was and is the guarantee of our salvation. This "promise of . . . life" is all the more relevant to Paul's own situation as he himself faces death as he writes this letter (2 Tim. 4:6–8).

<span id="page-457-4"></span><span id="page-457-3"></span><span id="page-457-1"></span>1:2 Paul addresses this letter to Timothy (cf. comment on 1 Tim. 1:2). It is clear that Paul has a warm affection for Timothy—he asks Timothy to come to see him as soon as possible (2 Tim. 4:9). Calling Timothy "my beloved child," Paul the beat-up apostle uses a term of endearment as he issues one last set of instructions to his young protégé. Paul thus begins this letter with a declaration of his own authority and a word of tender concern for Timothy. The source of "grace, mercy, and peace" in verse 2 is the same as the source of Paul's apostleship in verse 1: "God the Father" and "Christ Jesus."

### *Response*

We need Paul to remind us of his authority because we are facing the very same things Timothy faced — challenges to God's authority. Paul will command Timothy to hold fast to the faithful Word in the face of false teachers who oppose it. He is telling us to do the same. But our willingness to do so will depend entirely upon whom we recognize as our authority. Before we are able to fight the good fight to which God is calling us, we must settle in our heart now the question of who or what will be our authority.

<sup>1</sup> George W. Knight III, *The Pastoral Epistles: A Commentary on the Greek Text*, NIGTC (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 1992), 364.

### <span id="page-458-3"></span>2 TIMOTHY 1:3–7

**<sup>3</sup>** I thank God whom I serve, as did my ancestors, with a clear conscience, as I remember you constantly in my prayers night and day. **4**As I remember your tears, I long to see you, that I may be filled with joy. **<sup>5</sup>** I am reminded of your sincere faith, a faith that dwelt first in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice and now, I am sure, dwells in you as well. **6**For this reason I remind you to fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you through the laying on of my hands, **<sup>7</sup>** for God gave us a spirit not of fear but of power and love and self-control.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-458-5"></span><span id="page-458-2"></span>The thanksgiving in 2 Timothy 1:3 stands immediately prior the body of the letter. It is important to remember Paul's situation as he writes this letter. He writes from prison in Rome, where he knows he is soon to be executed (2 Tim. 4:6–7). Paul has been in many difficult situations before writing this letter, but he seems to indicate that this time is different. He knows that this may be the end. Paul writes to Timothy what may very well be his last words to him.

### *Section Outline*

- <span id="page-458-4"></span>I. Pastoral Courage for Suffering (1:1–18) . . .
	- B. Thanksgiving (1:3–7)
		- 1. An Apostle's Thanksgiving (1:3–5)
		- 2. An Apostle's Command (1:6–7)

### *Comment*

1:3 Verse 3 tells us to *whom* Paul directs his thankfulness. Verse 4 tells us *what* Paul longs for as he thanks God. And verse 5 tells us the *reason* he thanks God. So in these three verses Paul unfolds the *who*, the *what*, and the *why* of his thanksgiving.

<span id="page-458-6"></span><span id="page-458-1"></span><span id="page-458-0"></span>Paul thanks God, which is remarkable in itself given Paul's condition. In the ancient world, prisoners were not provided with basic necessities. They were often dependent on other people's kindness and help for the essentials—Paul later asks Timothy to "bring the cloak" (4:13). Yet, in this condition of confinement, deprivation, and abandonment, Paul still thanks God. He is doing what he told the Ephesians to do in Ephesians 5:20, where he said that being filled with the Holy Spirit means "giving thanks always and for everything to God the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ" (cf. Col. 3:17).

Paul refers to God as the one "whom I serve, as did my ancestors, with a clear conscience." Paul's prison cell does not constrain him from serving God in the most desperate of conditions. His friends may have deserted him, but God has not. Paul continues to serve God "with a clear conscience," walking faithfully before the Lord. He is not falling away from Christ because of being cast aside in a prison cell.

Paul is serving God "as did my ancestors" (lit., "from [my] ancestors"). He has received from his forefathers a pattern and example of faithfulness. This remarkable statement gives us a glimpse into the way Paul thinks about his Jewish forebears. He serves God just as Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and David did. Paul rightly believes that the gospel of Christ is the fulfillment of the promises made to his forefathers. What his forefathers trusted in anticipation, Paul now trusts in fulfillment. Christianity and Judaism—rightly understood—are not two different religions. They are two stages of one religion, with an unfolding revelation. The faith of the OT is what the seed is to the flower, what the foundation is to the building, what the boy is to the man.

<span id="page-459-2"></span>1:4 The *who* that Paul thanks is God. The *what* that he experiences while thanking God is to "long to see you, that I may be filled with joy." Paul's longing is made even more poignant by the fact that he remembers the last farewell, in which Timothy was so overcome with emotion that he wept for Paul ("as I remember your tears"). Readers can only imagine what the memory of those tears must mean to Paul as he languishes in prison. Demas, Crescens, and Titus have all moved on (4:10). Everyone has either deserted Paul or gone on to do something else (except for Luke; cf. 4:11), and yet Paul remembers one man who was not eager to leave him but who could part from him only in tears. The memory of Timothy's love and affection shines like a light in the shadows of Paul's wretched condition. For that reason, Paul wants to see this "beloved child" (1:2) once again.

<span id="page-459-5"></span><span id="page-459-4"></span><span id="page-459-3"></span><span id="page-459-1"></span>1:5 Paul next mentions the *why* of his thanksgiving: "I am reminded of your sincere faith, a faith that dwelt first in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice and now, I am sure, dwells in you as well." Paul is thankful because he knows that Timothy's faith is authentic and real. It is a faith in Christ that has been tested by suffering and has been proved in faithfulness to Paul. But Paul also links the genuineness of Timothy's faith to the ones who taught it to him—his grandmother, Lois; and his mother, Eunice. It may be that Paul knows these women personally (Acts 16:1). In any case, he knows that they are the genuine article, and their testimony gives Paul confidence that Timothy is too. These women have not handed to Timothy a false gospel but have passed on the true one. They have handed on no hypocritical way of life but a real one. Paul is grateful to God for the integrity of faith that Timothy inherited from his mother and grandmother.

<span id="page-459-0"></span>In this way, Paul invites readers to ponder the singularly powerful impact that mothers and grandmothers can have on children. Timothy's father apparently was not a believer and had no Christian influence over his son (Acts 16:1). These women, however, have made their mark on Timothy. Even though the work of childrearing can be mundane and thankless, the seeds these women of God planted have grown into an oak of righteousness. The boy they raised has become the man that the great apostle Paul relies on in his most desperate hour.

<span id="page-460-2"></span>1:6 "For this reason" introduces the command Paul is about to give. Because he is so certain that Timothy's faith is genuine, he commands him to "fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you through the laying on of my hands." The "gift of God" refers not merely to the gift of the Spirit received at salvation; it is a gift that Timothy received with the "laying on of . . . hands." This is the language of Timothy's ordination, mentioned also in 1 Timothy 4:14. It is no contradiction for Paul to mention "my hands" here while reminding Timothy of the role of all the elders in 1 Timothy 4:14. In 2 Timothy, Paul simply means to emphasize his own role in Timothy's ordination and launch into ministry.

<span id="page-460-1"></span><span id="page-460-0"></span>When elders lay hands on a man, they are not magically investing him with powers. Nor are they mechanically filling him with the Spirit. The laying on of hands is a public recognition of giftedness based on what the Holy Spirit has already done in an individual. In that sense, it is a church's commissioning of someone to the work of ministry (cf. Acts 6:6; 13:3). The norm for ordination, therefore, is not merely a self-realization concerning gospel ministry but a community-wide realization of a person's fitness for the work. The church's affirmation is essential for beginning the work, which is why Paul says that Timothy received the gift "through the laying on of my hands."

No person can give himself the gift of pastoring God's people, but he *can* allow his gifting to languish and atrophy. Timothy must not let this happen. On the contrary, he must "fan into flame the gift of God," which means that he must do that which he has already been gifted to do but can grow stronger in. The ministry of the Word is a like muscle that can either strengthen through frequent exertion or atrophy through neglect and disuse. Perhaps the potential neglect of Timothy's ministry has been due to fear and intimidation, which would explain what Paul says in verse 7.

<span id="page-460-3"></span>1:7 Paul grounds the command of verse 6: "For God gave us a spirit not of fear but of power and love and self-control." The "spirit" Paul has in view here is the Holy Spirit, and that Spirit does not engender fear. Some translations render the phrase as "spirit of timidity," but that is misleading. The term translated "fear" indicates cowardice, which is not merely an experience of fear. Many people experience fear who are not cowards. A coward is one who lacks the courage to act against his fears in the face of opposition and danger. God has not given his people a spirit who meets opposition and danger and then slinks away. That certainly is not the kind of Spirit that Timothy has been given. For this reason, he is not to slink away from preaching the gospel when the going gets tough. God has supplied Timothy with ability through the Spirit to do what needs to be done. The Spirit causes love for God and neighbor to be the defining features of a disciple's character. The same

Spirit inspires self-control to overcome whatever must be surmounted in order to join the fight.

### *Response*

When gospel preaching meets opposition, often the temptation will be to back away from conflict. But Christians cannot do so, because they are not animated by that kind of spirit. This is true for all Christians in the work of evangelism, but especially for those with pastoral responsibilities. Preachers have to kindle afresh the gift, not cowering in fear but standing with the Word of truth in boldness and love.

### <span id="page-461-1"></span>2 TIMOTHY 1:8–18

**<sup>8</sup>**Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony about our Lord, nor of me his prisoner, but share in suffering for the gospel by the power of God, **9**who saved us and called us to*<sup>1</sup>* a holy calling, not because of our works but because of his own purpose and grace, which he gave us in Christ Jesus before the ages began,*<sup>2</sup>* **<sup>10</sup>** and which now has been manifested through the appearing of our Savior Christ Jesus, who abolished death and brought life and immortality to light through the gospel, **<sup>11</sup>** for which I was appointed a preacher and apostle and teacher, **12**which is why I suffer as I do. But I am not ashamed, for I know whom I have believed, and I am convinced that he is able to guard until that day what has been entrusted to me.*<sup>3</sup>* **<sup>13</sup>**Follow the pattern of the sound*<sup>4</sup>* words that you have heard from me, in the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus. **14**By the Holy Spirit who dwells within us, guard the good deposit entrusted to you.

**<sup>15</sup>**You are aware that all who are in Asia turned away from me, among whom are Phygelus and Hermogenes. **16**May the Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains, **17**but when he arrived in Rome he searched for me earnestly and found me— **18**may the Lord grant him to find mercy from the Lord on that day!—and you well know all the service he rendered at Ephesus.

1Or *with* 2Greek *before times eternal* 3Or *what I have entrusted to him*; Greek *my deposit* 4Or *healthy*

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-461-0"></span>This text should be read as the beginning of the "last words of Paul." Here at the very outset, Paul has called on Timothy to take up his quarrel with the foes of the faith who have infiltrated the church in Ephesus. He has also commanded Timothy to "fan into flame" his gifting (2 Tim. 1:6–7). Paul now exhorts Timothy

#### 2 Timothy 1:8–18 462

to have no shame in suffering together with Paul for the sake of the gospel (vv. 8–18).

### *Section Outline*

- I. Pastoral Courage for Suffering (1:1–18) . . .
	- C. Following Paul without Shame (1:8–18)
		- 1. Suffering without Shame (1:8–12)
		- 2. Ministry without Shame (1:13–14)
		- 3. Exemplars without Shame (1:15–18)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-462-4"></span><span id="page-462-3"></span><span id="page-462-2"></span>1:8 The verse begins with a prohibition: "do not be ashamed." "Therefore" means that the command is grounded in what Paul has said in verse 7. Because God has given Timothy not a spirit of cowardice but a Spirit of power and discipline, Timothy must not be ashamed. Paul is concerned with the way in which shame can undermine faithfulness to Christ (note the word "ashamed" in verses 8, 12, and 16). The *American Heritage Dictionary* defines shame as "a painful emotion caused by the belief that one is, or is perceived by others to be, inferior or unworthy of affection or respect because of one's actions, thoughts, circumstances, or experiences." The Spirit of Almighty God will not coexist with that kind of shame but drives it out. Therefore, Timothy must not be ashamed.

<span id="page-462-0"></span>Paul suggests at least two reasons why Timothy might feel shame: (1) because of the gospel, "the testimony about our Lord," and (2) because of Paul, a "prisoner." In Paul's day, many people looked down on Christians for their message about Jesus. Skeptics shamed Paul at Mars Hill when he began to preach about the resurrection, proving that the gospel is indeed "folly to those who are perishing" (1 Cor. 1:18). Apart from grace, the world thinks Christians to be rubes for believing what they believe. Paul knows that there is plenty of shame for those who would believe and preach the gospel.

There is also plenty of shame to go around for those willing to identify with gospel preachers. We can imagine how the unsanctified mind would have regarded Paul, in prison for preaching the gospel. It would have appeared foolish to throw one's life away on a fairy tale about a dead Jew named Jesus. It would surely have been difficult to associate with a man so shamed for the name of Christ. To do so would be to invite such shame upon oneself.

<span id="page-462-1"></span>It is striking that Paul does not call himself a prisoner of *Rome*. Instead he calls himself a prisoner of the Lord. Paul regards his shame not as his own but as Christ's. He belongs to Jesus, not the Romans. If the Romans despise his message, it is because they despise his master, Jesus. Paul sees his sufferings as nothing other than the sufferings of Christ lived out again in Paul's own body (Gal. 2:20). Being ashamed of Paul the Lord's prisoner is tantamount to being ashamed of Jesus—the one for whom Paul is imprisoned. And so he tells Timothy not to be ashamed of him, the Lord's prisoner. On the contrary, he commands, "Share in suffering for

the gospel by the power of God." The proof that Timothy is not ashamed must be revealed in his willingness to suffer.

The stakes are high in this text—associating with the imprisoned apostle could be risky. In the following verses, therefore, Paul describes for Timothy all that has been accomplished by the "power of God."

<span id="page-463-4"></span>1:9 Many commentators regard verses 9–10 as an early Christian hymn or confession (e.g., NA28), but that conclusion is by no means certain (e.g., UBS5 ).2 What is certain is that Paul introduces these two verses in order to remind Timothy of what the power of God has accomplished, things that Timothy himself has already experienced. If the power of God is sufficient to save sinners as described in verses 9–10, then certainly the power of God will enable Timothy to suffer together with Paul.

<span id="page-463-5"></span><span id="page-463-2"></span><span id="page-463-0"></span>The clause at the beginning of verse 9 specifies God as the one who "saved us." Verse 10 defines this salvation as rescue from "death" and the giving of "life and immortality." God's salvation involves both rescue from death and the giving of eternal life (Rom. 6:23). God breaks through hard hearts by calling his people to himself. This "holy calling" is effectual in the sense that it infallibly summons forth a response of faith (cf. "calling" in Rom. 8:30; 9:11, 24; 1 Cor. 1:9; Gal. 1:6; Eph. 4:1). God "calls" sinners to himself not because they deserve it or because they request it—it is "not because of our works." By nature, sinners are dead in their trespasses and sins. They do not seek for God, but he certainly seeks them, "because of his own purpose and grace." Elsewhere, Paul links "calling" with God's predestining "purpose" of grace (Rom. 8:28); this predestining purpose is likely what Paul has in mind here as well (cf. Eph. 1:11).

<span id="page-463-7"></span><span id="page-463-3"></span><span id="page-463-1"></span>The implication is that salvation through Christ is not rooted ultimately in human effort or ingenuity but in the purposes of God from all eternity. In this way, salvation is all of grace. Paul specifies that God's grace has been given to his people "in Christ Jesus before the ages began" (cf. Titus 1:2). Before the world began—even before anyone ever sinned—God's predestining goodness was aimed squarely at sinners to save them.

<span id="page-463-6"></span>1:10 This verse begins with a clause further expounding the "grace" mentioned in verse 9; this grace has been "now . . . manifested" through the redemptive work of Christ. Because of Christ, God's grace is no mystery. Its manifestation means that it has "become public knowledge" (BDAG, s.v. *phaneroō*). God's gracious purposes are not the ephemeral musings of a distant deity. He puts flesh and blood on his plans to save his people "through the appearing," that is, the incarnation, "of our Savior Christ Jesus." That appearing achieved salvation through his cross and resurrection. Through the cross, the Savior "abolished death." This does not mean that sinners no longer experience death; rather, their death sentence will be upended by their subsequent resurrection. Jesus' resurrection amounted to

<sup>2</sup> Cf. William D. Mounce, *Pastoral Epistles*, WBC (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 2016), 481.

the nullification of his own death. Likewise, his resurrection guarantees that the disciple's death will be nullified as well. This promise of "life and immortality" has been brought near to sinners through the message of the "gospel," which is being proclaimed in the world.

<span id="page-464-1"></span><span id="page-464-0"></span>1:11 "For which" looks back to the gospel mentioned at the end of verse 10. The Lord Jesus himself appeared to Paul and "appointed" him to be a "preacher and apostle and teacher." Each of these titles indicates that Paul's ministry was primarily to focus on the explication of the truth about Christ. As a "preacher," Paul proclaimed that message. As an "apostle," he was appointed by Jesus himself to be an inspired and authoritative bearer of that message. As a "teacher," Paul explained the meaning of God's revelation in Christ. In this sense, every aspect of Paul's ministry existed in order to set forth the gospel message, a message that brings "life and immortality" to all who believe in it.

<span id="page-464-2"></span>1:12 The first phrase of this verse links back to the "gospel" mentioned at the end of verse 10. A literal rendering might read, "on account of which [gospel] I suffer these things." "These things" refers to Paul's imprisonment mentioned in verse 8. As in verse 8, Paul says that he has been imprisoned for preaching the gospel. But even though he is in a shameful place (prison), Paul declares that he is not ashamed. Why? Because his confidence and trust are in Christ: "I know whom I have believed." Paul knows Christ, and so he has confidence in ultimate vindication. There is therefore no reason to be ashamed of his present circumstance.

Paul's confidence is not in his own ability to weather the storm. On the contrary, Paul writes, "I am convinced that *he* [God] is able." The power of God made Paul an apostle and preacher of the gospel, and that same power is now sustaining him in his misery. The very power of God is keeping Paul from being ashamed. He is confident that even if his captors take his freedom—or even his life—God is going to raise him up. This is what Paul means by saying that Christ can "guard" the life that has been "entrusted" to Paul. Paul knows that his life is not subject ultimately to the whims of his Roman captors; his life is hidden with Christ in God. Everything that he loses will be given back to him—and then some—on the last day (i.e., the day of resurrection).

<span id="page-464-5"></span><span id="page-464-4"></span><span id="page-464-3"></span>1:13–14 For Timothy, ministry without shame means being willing to associate with and suffer with Paul. But in these two verses, it also means being willing to stay faithful to Paul's message. Paul calls that message "the pattern of the sound words that you have heard from me" (v. 13) and "the good deposit entrusted to you" (v. 14). In both of these expressions, Paul accents the *given-ness* of the gospel message. It has discernible content and contours. It is more of a bounded set than a centered one. One's teaching can either conform to the gospel "pattern" or depart from the same. One's teaching can be taken either from the "deposit" or from somewhere else. In short, Paul asserts an apostolic standard that must guide Timothy's teaching ministry.

Paul issues two directives vis-à-vis this apostolic standard. He commands Timothy to "follow" the apostolic standard and to "guard" it. The first command ("follow") could also be rendered as "hold fast" (Gk. *eche*). In this context, to "hold fast" means to commit oneself to a matter of "transcendent importance" (BDAG). In this case, the item of transcendent priority is the gospel message. Thus holding fast to the pattern of sound words indicates Timothy's pastoral duty to preach and to live the apostolic standard before God's people.

Paul is interested not merely in what Timothy says but also in how he lives it out. Holding fast to this gospel must occur "in the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus." In order to preserve Paul's teaching, Timothy must exercise faith toward God and love toward others (cf. Matt. 22:36–40).

<span id="page-465-4"></span><span id="page-465-1"></span><span id="page-465-0"></span>The second command ("guard") refers to Timothy's pastoral duty to protect the standard from corruption by false teachers (cf. 1 Tim. 6:20; 2 Tim. 4:15). Here the standard is called "the good deposit"—an expression that parallels that of 1 Timothy 6:20 and refers to the apostolic message entrusted to him. Timothy's responsibility is not only to preach the message but to defend it (cf. Titus 1:9). This means that pastoral ministry necessarily involves confrontation, which Timothy is to undertake "by the power of the Holy Spirit." It is not Timothy's own resourcefulness that qualifies for the task but the presence of the Spirit who first indwelled Paul and now dwells powerfully within Timothy as well.

<span id="page-465-2"></span>1:15 "You are aware" means that Paul is referencing an event with which Timothy is well-acquainted. In this case it is that a group of believers, "all who are in Asia," has deserted Paul. It is difficult to identify this group of people with any certainty. "Asia" refers to the western part of modern-day Turkey, what was then the western part of the Roman province of Asia. But who are the "all" that Paul mentions? And when did they leave him? Some have suggested that "all" refers to all of the believers in Asia, but this seems unlikely. It is more likely that Paul has in mind members of some smaller group in Asia, all of whom have left Paul. Although we cannot definitively identify this group, it is possible that Paul mentions Phygelus and Hermogenes because they are among its leaders.

Paul says that they have "turned away" (Gk. *apostrephō*; in this context "turn away from by rejecting" [BDAG]). We might even render the term "reject" or "repudiate," indicating that these men have not left Paul for some small reason. They have done so because they were ashamed of him. They are negative examples of what Paul instructs Timothy to do, which is *not* to be ashamed. When the going got tough, they got going: they deserted Paul. Their faithfulness to Paul—and thus to his gospel ministry—was only as deep as their willingness to suffer. And there was not much depth there at all, so they left him.

<span id="page-465-3"></span>1:16–18 In contrast to Phygelus, Hermogenes, and "all" who were in Asia, there was Onesiphorus. Onesiphorus was not ashamed of Paul or his gospel. For this reason, Paul asks for divine mercy on his behalf. But notice that Paul refers not only to Onesiphorus but also to his entire "household," which likely refers to <span id="page-466-1"></span>his family. Why would Paul focus on Onesiphorus's family in this invocation of divine mercy? It may be that both Onesiphorus and his family have paid a price for Onesiphorus's association with Paul. Perhaps Onesiphorus has already died. This would explain Paul's reference to the last judgment (v. 18) and would also mean that Onesiphorus's family are the only ones left for Paul to pray for. The exact details are not clear, but what is clear is that there was a price for associating with Paul, and Onesiphorus's entire family may have paid it. Onesiphorus and his family sacrificed to be merciful to Paul, and now Paul is praying for them to receive mercy. In writing this, Paul may have in mind the words of Jesus himself, who pronounced, "Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy" (Matt. 5:7).

<span id="page-466-0"></span>Onesiphorus's unique honor was that he was not "ashamed" of Paul's chains. On the contrary, Onesiphorus sought Paul out, associated with him, implicated himself in Paul's shame, and took care of Paul's needs while he was imprisoned in Rome. When everyone else had refused Paul's shame, Onesiphorus embraced it even at the risk of his own family. Onesiphorus is an exemplar of ministry without shame in his faithfulness to Paul not only in Rome but also in Ephesus, which Timothy knows about as well.

### *Response*

Onesiphorus's legacy is instructive. It is one thing to ask a man to make sacrifices for the sake of the gospel. It is another thing to ask a man's family to make those same sacrifices. How many of us would be willing to do so? Onesiphorus thought it was worth it, and apparently so did his family. Paul prays for mercy on both of them. Do we believe that the mercy of God is sufficient for ourselves and for whatever sacrifice we or our families may be called on to make for the sake of the gospel?

### <span id="page-466-2"></span>2 TIMOTHY 2:1–13

2 You then, my child, be strengthened by the grace that is in Christ Jesus, **<sup>2</sup>** and what you have heard from me in the presence of many witnesses entrust to faithful men,*<sup>1</sup>* who will be able to teach others also. **<sup>3</sup>** Share in suffering as a good soldier of Christ Jesus. **4**No soldier gets entangled in civilian pursuits, since his aim is to please the one who enlisted him. **5**An athlete is not crowned unless he competes according to the rules. **<sup>6</sup>** It is the hard-working farmer who ought to have the first share of the crops. **7**Think over what I say, for the Lord will give you understanding in everything.

**<sup>8</sup>**Remember Jesus Christ, risen from the dead, the offspring of David, as preached in my gospel, **<sup>9</sup>** for which I am suffering, bound with chains as a criminal. But the word of God is not bound! **10**Therefore I endure

everything for the sake of the elect, that they also may obtain the salvation that is in Christ Jesus with eternal glory. **11**The saying is trustworthy, for:

If we have died with him, we will also live with him;

- **<sup>12</sup>** if we endure, we will also reign with him; if we deny him, he also will deny us;
- **<sup>13</sup>** if we are faithless, he remains faithful—

for he cannot deny himself.

1The Greek word *anthropoi* can refer to both men and women, depending on the context

### *Section Overview*

Verse 1 of chapter 2 brings a command: "be strengthened." Paul is calling Timothy to something that is beyond what he can do in his own strength. It will require divine enabling to carry out his ministry in the face of suffering and opposition. Paul has commanded Timothy not to be ashamed of the gospel or of Paul, the one imprisoned for the gospel. He has commanded Timothy to "follow the pattern of the sound words" that he has heard from Paul and to "guard the good deposit" (2 Tim. 1:13–14). Timothy cannot do any of this in his own strength. He must rely on God's help if he is going to continue on in the ministry to which God has called him.

### <span id="page-467-1"></span>*Section Outline*

- II. Pastoral Courage for Endurance (2:1–26)
	- A. Strengthened by the Grace of Christ (2:1–13)
		- 1. Strengthened for Propagation (2:1–2)
		- 2. Strengthened for Suffering (2:3–7)
		- 3. Strengthened for Enduring (2:8–13)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-467-2"></span>2:1 "You then" connects this verse to what Paul has just said at the end of chapter 1. Paul's logic is as follows: "Because of the work you have to do in Ephesus and because of Onesiphorus's exemplary, unashamed example, Timothy, you must be strengthened." The "strengthening" is in the passive voice—the strength Timothy needs is not something he can give to himself. It is something that must be given to him from the outside. It is understood that the *agent* of the strengthening is God. The *means* of the strengthening is the grace to be found only in Christ (cf. 2 Cor. 3:5).

<span id="page-467-3"></span><span id="page-467-0"></span>2:2 Timothy needs strength in order to carry out the work of gospel ministry, the work to which every pastor has to give himself. In a broader sense, this is the work to which every Christian must give himself or herself, because it is nothing less than the expansion of Christ's kingdom through the propagation of the gospel. The church grows and people are added to the number of the saved as Christians hand on the faith to the next generation. Paul is particularly concerned with Timothy's duty to pass on the gospel. But notice that this text has four generations in view:

```
1st generation = Paul ("from me")
2nd generation = Timothy ("what you have heard")
3rd generation = Timothy's disciples ("entrust to faithful men")
4th generation = Timothy's disciples' disciples ("others")
```
Timothy's ministry has a source and a goal: its source is the apostolic gospel contained in Scripture, and its goal is to pass on that message to the coming generations. Timothy is to reproduce himself in disciples who follow his teaching. And those disciples are to reproduce themselves in the disciples who follow their teaching.

<span id="page-468-1"></span>2:3 Timothy needs strength for ministry mainly because such work necessarily brings opposition. Sometimes this opposition results in suffering for the sake of the gospel. Timothy must, literally, "suffer together" (Gk. συγκακοπάθησον) with Paul if he is to be a faithful pastor. Suffering is a command, not an option, and it is shared. As Paul has already testified in this letter, he himself is suffering, and he is simply exhorting Timothy to follow in his footsteps. Even in this, Paul is not the trailblazer; Jesus is. Jesus suffered, and his disciples must share in his lot.

Timothy must suffer as a "good soldier of Christ Jesus." This is the first of three images illustrating the commitment that Timothy must exhibit. These three images each tell us something about what is required of one called to suffer for the sake of the gospel.

<span id="page-468-2"></span>2:4 The soldier illustrates single-mindedness. A soldier does not get "entangled in civilian pursuits"; he does not get distracted by things unessential to his mission. One commentator puts it this way: "The soldier's goal is to 'please' or satisfy the wishes of the commander, who expects nothing less than complete attention to duty so that the military objectives will be accomplished."3

<span id="page-468-3"></span>2:5 The athlete illustrates discipline to compete according to the rules. Paul's readers would be familiar with athletic contests such as the Isthmian Games in Corinth or the Olympic games in Olympia. Competing "according to the rules" refers either to the rules of the individual contests or perhaps to the ten months of training necessary to qualify for the games. In any case, the point is clear: the only way to win the prize is to compete according to the rules.

<span id="page-468-0"></span>The analogy to the Christian faith is simple. There is a "rule" when it comes to following Christ. One of the rules of following Christ is the willingness to suffer for him (Matt. 16:24). Anyone unwilling to endure this is unable to be his disciple. No one can receive the victor's crown if he will not be faithful in suffering.

<sup>3</sup> Philip H. Towner, *Letters to Timothy and Titus*, NICNT (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 2006), 493.

<span id="page-469-8"></span>2:6 The farmer illustrates hard work. If a farmer refuses to wake up early and put his shoulder to the plow, he will have no crop to harvest. To have no harvest is to have no share in the reward. Lazy people make bad farmers. They also make bad Christians. If someone would follow Christ, he must have a dedicated work ethic, a commitment to the task at hand. Anyone willing to undertake austerity and industry will have "the first share of the crops"—which in this case indicates fruitfulness.

<span id="page-469-9"></span><span id="page-469-7"></span><span id="page-469-2"></span>2:7 "Think over what I say" is a command urging Timothy to consider carefully the analogies of verses 4–6. The word translated "think" (Gk. *noei* ) does not denote mere passing interest but rather urges Timothy to "think over with care" or to "consider" (BDAG). This is the same term used in the Olivet Discourse to invite readers to "understand" the innermost meaning and implication of Jesus' prophecy (Matt. 24:15; Mark 13:14). It is this kind of insight that Paul wishes for Timothy to have regarding his words, "for the Lord will give you understanding in everything." The "Lord" in this case is likely God the Father rather than God the Son.4 As elsewhere, it is the Father who gives understanding and insight into spiritual things (cf. Prov. 2:6 LXX; Matt. 16:17; Eph. 3:2–4). Accordingly, Paul grounds his command on the guarantee that the Lord will help Timothy understand all of the implications of these illustrations of single-mindedness, discipline, and hard work.

<span id="page-469-10"></span><span id="page-469-1"></span>2:8 Paul commands Timothy to "remember" because this will be the means by which Timothy is strengthened to endure through suffering. Paul wants Timothy to remember specific things about Jesus:

<span id="page-469-3"></span>(1) Jesus is raised ("risen from the dead"). "Risen" is in the perfect tense; for Paul, Jesus' resurrection is not merely a past event but has results continuing into the present (cf. 1 Cor. 15:4, 12). The perfect tense indicates that Jesus was not only alive in the flesh when he appeared to his apostles in the upper room but also remains alive and in the flesh as seated at the right hand of the Father.

<span id="page-469-0"></span>(2) Jesus is King ("the offspring of David"). The phrase is literally "the seed of David," connecting directly to 2 Samuel 7:12–13, in which God promises to raise up the "seed" of David to rule over a kingdom that will last forever. This "seed" of David will be God's own Son (cf. Gal. 3:16, 19). By remembering this, Timothy can remain single-minded.

<span id="page-469-5"></span>(3) Jesus is truly taught ("as preached in my gospel"). When Paul refers to "my gospel," he is inviting Timothy to remember that Christ himself had appointed Paul to be an apostle. The way Paul preaches Jesus is the standard for preaching Jesus. Those who preach a Jesus that does not match up with the one Paul preached are in the wrong (cf. 2 Cor. 11:4).

<span id="page-469-11"></span><span id="page-469-6"></span><span id="page-469-4"></span>2:9 The antecedent of "for which" is the "gospel" in verse 8: the gospel is the reason for Paul's suffering (cf. 1:12). This also indicates that Paul's suffering in prison is current at the time of his writing. Even though Paul is enchained, however, the

<sup>4</sup> Cf. Knight, *Pastoral Epistles*, 396.

<span id="page-470-1"></span><span id="page-470-0"></span>"word of God" is not. As elsewhere, the "word of God" is the gospel (cf. 1 Cor. 14:36; 2 Cor. 2:17; 4:2; Eph. 6:17; Col. 1:25; 1 Thess. 2:13). This gospel word is alive and active and cannot be restrained by prisons or chains: "The word of God is not bound." This verb is in the perfect tense, indicating that the gospel has not been bound in the past and is not bound now. The gospel word is the power of God unto salvation, and it is not subject to the weaknesses and limitations of the ones carrying it. They can be imprisoned; God's word cannot be.

<span id="page-470-3"></span>2:10 To "endure" means to "maintain a belief or course of action in the face of opposition" (BDAG, s.v. ὑπομένω). In the Greek text, "endure" is modified by two prepositional phrases: "On account of this, I endure on account of the elect." It is crucial to notice how the "on account of" statements connect Paul's endurance both to what comes before verse 10 and to what comes in the latter half of verse 10. The ESV correctly renders "on account of this" as "therefore." Paul endures suffering *because* the word of God is not bound (v. 9). His own apparently sad situation is no limitation on the word of God, which continues to go forth in power. Paul's confidence in the word motivates him to endure suffering faithfully.

He also suffers "for the sake of the elect." This second basis for Paul's endurance is not unrelated to the first; in fact, the two must be understood together. "On account of" is a prospective basis for Paul's endurance—that God's chosen people ("the elect") might hear the gospel and be saved and inherit eternal life (i.e., "eternal glory"); hence the ESV's "for the sake of." Because the word of God is not bound, Paul does not shrink back amid his suffering.

<span id="page-470-4"></span><span id="page-470-2"></span>2:11 The phrase "the saying is trustworthy" appears several times in the Pastorals (cf. comment on 1 Tim. 1:15). Here it seems to introduce a gospel word that has the earmarks of an early Christian hymn, which is why the ESV indents it like poetry on the page. The trustworthy (or "faithful") saying is this:

for:

If we have died with him, we will also live with him;

- **<sup>12</sup>** if we endure, we will also reign with him;
- if we deny him, he also will deny us;
	- **<sup>13</sup>** if we are faithless, he remains faithful—

for he cannot deny himself.

<span id="page-470-5"></span>Notice the word "endure" in verse 12, which links the hymn to Paul's word concerning endurance in verse 10. The verbal connection shows that Paul intends the truths conveyed in this hymn to be further grounds for endurance through suffering.

Some commentators interpret "died with him" as a reference to martyrdom those who have physically died for the gospel just as Jesus physically died. But that is probably not what Paul has in mind here. It is more likely that Paul has in <span id="page-471-2"></span>mind the same kind of "dying with" Christ that he refers to in Romans 6:8–11. That passage speaks not of the believer's own physical death but of his union with Christ's death and resurrection. Believers are joined to Christ by faith and through the Spirit. Their union with Christ results in his death's counting for them: he died as their representative and substitute. In that sense believers have "died with him," and this is likely what Paul has in mind here as well. All Christians are joined to Christ's death through faith. If we have died with him, we will also live with him—we will know new life now through the Holy Spirit.

In the same way, believers will also live with Christ. "Live" is in the future tense, which may anticipate the believer's future resurrection from the dead. Believers have new life in the present through the Holy Spirit. But the *future* life is a physical resurrection that will be just like Jesus' resurrection (cf. Rom. 8:11; 1 Cor. 15:20–23).

<span id="page-471-5"></span><span id="page-471-3"></span>2:12 The key term in this verse is "endure," which as noted above means to "maintain a belief or course of action in the face of opposition." The suffering that Paul has endured (v. 10) is the lot of every faithful Christian in the face of trials. "Endure" is present-tense, probably implying that ongoing endurance is the key. "If we are enduring" would be the sense, indicating that perseverance is the condition for blessedness in the age to come. In this text, such blessedness refers specifically to reigning with Christ in the age to come. Failure to endure certainly means that one will not reign. As the old saying goes, there is no crown without a cross. As it was with Christ himself, so it is also with those who would come after him.

<span id="page-471-1"></span><span id="page-471-0"></span>The text also warns that if we deny him now in the face of opposition, he will deny us at the judgment. This warning resembles what Jesus himself said about those who deny his lordship: he will deny them at the judgment (cf. Matt. 10:33; Luke 12:9). To be denied at the judgment is the ultimate devastation, but such is the cost of a definitive and unwavering denial of Christ.

<span id="page-471-6"></span><span id="page-471-4"></span>2:13 Some interpreters define "faithless" as "without faith." On this view, "faithless" describes a condition of settled unbelief. As a result, God's faithfulness here must refer to his faithfulness to punish those who do not believe (2 Thess. 1:8). There is, however, a better way to understand this term. "Faithless" is not a condition of settled unbelief but refers to temporary *unfaithfulness* after which one might be renewed again to repentance. Thus God's faithfulness refers to his unwillingness to give up on his people even though their holiness is not as consistent as it should be. In that sense, God is faithful even when his people are not.

### *Response*

For Paul, the doctrine of election does not make him less evangelistic but more. He knows that the Word of God is not bound and that God has a people he has chosen for himself. These two truths combine to form a powerful motivation for evangelism because they guarantee that faithfulness leads to fruitfulness. One can know that God will work powerfully to accomplish his will and that he aims to use his people to achieve it.

If the doctrine of election makes someone less evangelistic, then that person has failed to grasp the doctrine properly. The doctrine of election is to fill the believer with confidence to preach the gospel no matter what opposition he meets. It is to fill him with the courage to speak when others shrink back because he knows that God will use his Word powerfully to save sinners. The evidence of a proper understanding of election is a passionate concern for evangelism.

### <span id="page-472-1"></span>2 TIMOTHY 2:14–26

**<sup>20</sup>**Now in a great house there are not only vessels of gold and silver but also of wood and clay, some for honorable use, some for dishonorable. **<sup>21</sup>**Therefore, if anyone cleanses himself from what is dishonorable,*<sup>3</sup>* he will be a vessel for honorable use, set apart as holy, useful to the master of the house, ready for every good work.

**<sup>22</sup>** So flee youthful passions and pursue righteousness, faith, love, and peace, along with those who call on the Lord from a pure heart. **23**Have nothing to do with foolish, ignorant controversies; you know that they breed quarrels. **24**And the Lord's servant*<sup>4</sup>* must not be quarrelsome but kind to everyone, able to teach, patiently enduring evil, **<sup>25</sup>** correcting his opponents with gentleness. God may perhaps grant them repentance leading to a knowledge of the truth, **<sup>26</sup>** and they may come to their senses and escape from the snare of the devil, after being captured by him to do his will.
