He must not be arrogant or quick-tempered or a drunkard or violent or greedy for gain, **8**but hospitable, a lover of good, self-controlled, upright, holy, and disciplined. **<sup>9</sup>**He must hold firm to the trustworthy word as taught, so that he may be able to give instruction in sound*<sup>4</sup>* doctrine and also to rebuke those who contradict it.

1Or *a man of one woman* 2Or *are faithful* 3Or *bishop*; Greek *episkopos* 4Or *healthy*; also verse 13

### *Section Overview*

Paul reminds Titus of the reason why he left him in Crete. He intended for Titus to ensure that the church was provided with qualified elder leadership. Paul charges Titus with seeing that this leadership is put in place, and he explains to Titus the character qualifications for such elders. Elders must not only have godly character; they must also be competent to teach the faith and to confront false teachers who oppose the faith.

### *Section Outline*

- I. Appointing Elders (1:1–16) . . .
	- B. An Elder's Qualifications (1:5–9)
		- 1. How to Appoint an Elder (1:5)
		- 2. How to Recognize an Elder (1:6–9)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-502-2"></span><span id="page-502-1"></span><span id="page-502-0"></span>1:5 Paul's saying that he left Titus in Crete suggests that Paul himself had visited Crete. Even though Acts 27 notes Paul's brief stop in Crete on the way to Rome, Acts provides no record of Paul's missionary work in Crete. For that reason, the visit referred to in Titus 1:5 seems to have taken place after the end of Acts but before Paul's final imprisonment and death. During that visit, Paul left Titus in Crete so that he could "put what remained into order, and appoint elders." Paul's assignment to Titus accords with a threefold pattern we observe in Paul's ministry recorded in Acts. For example, in Acts 14:21–23, Paul

- 1. makes converts through preaching the gospel,
- 2. strengthens new believers through discipleship and instruction, and
- <span id="page-503-3"></span><span id="page-503-2"></span>3. appoints pastors/elders "in every church" to carry on the work after he is gone. (Notice the plural "elders" in every single church, which suggests that each church should welcome a plurality of elders; cf. Acts 20:17, 28; Phil. 1:1; 1 Thess. 5:12, 13; 1 Tim. 5:17).2

Paul's instructions to Titus should be interpreted in light of this threefold pattern. To "put what remained into order" means to set in order the third and final item in Paul's church-planting pattern: appointing pastors/elders.

Some have viewed Titus's assignment as evidence that elders are a selfperpetuating leadership body, appointed by fellow elders. For that reason, they believe congregational votes regarding church leadership to be unbiblical. They understand the biblical pattern as one qualified pastor's appointing a new one. But that is not likely what Paul intends by commanding Titus to appoint elders.

Paul instructs Titus to appoint elders, but he does not specify in this text *how* this appointment process is to unfold. However, other texts help us to see more clearly a pattern for how qualified candidates are to be "appointed" to official church office.

<span id="page-503-1"></span>In Acts 6:3, the apostles discuss how they will appoint the first seven deacons to serve the church in Jerusalem.3 The deacons are an official church office, and it is possible that the apostles are establishing a pattern for appointment to the other church office—that of elder—as well. The apostles provide a model for us when they say the following to the "full number of the disciples" (Acts 6:2):

<span id="page-503-0"></span>"Pick out from among you seven men of good repute, full of the Spirit and of wisdom, whom we will appoint to this duty." (Acts 6:3)

The word for "appoint" is the same as in Titus 1:5, and thus these appear to be parallel situations of church leaders installing individuals into official church office. In Acts, the "appointment" to office and the "laying on of hands" are the end of a process that includes the congregation "pick[ing] out" the candidates. The "whole gathering . . . chose" the seven deacons and brought them to the apostles (Acts 6:5–6), and then the apostles laid hands on them (Acts 6:6). So the process moves in at least three steps: (1) church leadership recognizes a need for an office to be filled; (2) church leadership calls on the congregation to recognize and select qualified candidates; (3) church leadership prays and lays hands on the candidates to install them into office.

<span id="page-503-4"></span>1:6 "Above reproach" translates a Greek term meaning "blameless" or "irreproachable." The term indicates a "man [who] would not be open to attack or criticism in terms of Christian life in general or in terms of the characteristics that Paul goes

<sup>3</sup> For this and what follows, see ibid., 287–288.

<span id="page-504-1"></span>The elder must be the "husband of one wife." As explained in the comment on 1 Timothy 3:2, "husband of one wife" denotes a "one-woman man." The husband, therefore, must exhibit exemplary faithfulness and devotion to his wife. If a man is not faithful to love and lead his own wife like Christ does the church, then he cannot love and lead Christ's bride. Marriage is a proving ground of church leadership.

<span id="page-504-3"></span><span id="page-504-2"></span>The elder must also have children who are "believers" (Titus 1:6), or are "faithful" (cf. ESV mg.; cf. 2 Tim. 2:2). Using nearly identical language, both this text and 1 Timothy 3:4 state that an elder must have children who possess similar characteristics. In 1 Timothy, the elders' children must be "submissive," while in Titus his children must be faithful. Both texts denote faithfulness to a father's authority. An elder's children must be submissive and faithful and thus not "open to the charge of debauchery or insubordination."

<span id="page-504-4"></span>1:7 Paul repeats from verse 6 the word translated "above reproach" (Gk. ἀνέγκλητος), this time defining it in terms not of family but of character. Verse 7 lists five traits an elder must *not* exhibit, while verse 8 lists six an elder must possess.

<span id="page-504-5"></span>(1) "Must not be arrogant" means that the elder must not be prideful or "*selfwilled*" or "*stubborn*" (BDAG, s.v. αὐθάδης, italics original). (2) Not being "quicktempered" forbids an elder from being "*inclined to anger*" (BDAG, s.v. ὀργίλος, italics original). (3) Not a "drunkard" indicates that the elder must never become inebriated (cf. Eph. 5:18). (4) "Violent" denotes a "violent person who is a brawler,"5 thus forbidding an elder from being a bully. (5) Not being "greedy for gain" indicates that an elder must not be a lover of money.

<span id="page-504-7"></span><span id="page-504-0"></span>1:8 Paul now lists six positive characteristics an elder must possess: (1) "Hospitable" requires an elder's home to be open to caring for the needs of others (cf. Heb. 13:2). (2) "Lover of good" indicates that virtue is not merely doing the right thing; it also involves loving the right thing. (3) "Self-controlled" refers to one who is controlled not by his passions, lusts, or idolatries but by the Spirit. This term can have the nuance of sexual decency as well.6 (4) "Upright" (*dikaios*) describes one who lives according to God's standard of righteousness. (5) "Holy" is not the customary word for holiness, which means "set apart"; the term used here means "*devout, pious, pleasing to God*" (BDAG, s.v. ὅσιος, italics original). (6) "Disciplined" means that this person has his "emotions, impulses, or desires under control" (BDAG, s.v. ἐγκρατής).

<span id="page-504-6"></span>1:9 The elder must hold fast to sound teaching so that he can feed the sheep (i.e., "give instruction"). He must also have the ability through his teaching to protect the sheep: "to rebuke those who contradict" sound doctrine. Thus there is both the positive role of instruction and the negative role of confrontation. It has well

been said that "All that is necessary for the triumph of evil is that good men do nothing." Elders must not be "do-nothing good men." They must be willing to confront false teachers.

### *Response*

A congregational role in the recognition and appointment of church leadership finds warrant in Scripture. Indeed, there appears to be a role both for the elders and for the congregation in appointing church officers, roles that should be reflected in the actual polity of local churches. One way to do this would be for elders to receive recommendations for church officers from members of the congregation. The elders would then pray over the recommendations and vet them for the congregation. Then the elders would bring candidates to the congregation to approve by vote. After the congregation selected the candidates, the elders would pray over them and install them.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-505-0"></span>This paragraph addresses the need to confront false teachers. Titus 1:10 warns, "For there are many who are insubordinate, empty talkers and deceivers." The explanatory "for" introduces the reason for the instruction found at the end of verse 9, which outlined the faithful pastor's responsibility to "hold firm to the trustworthy word as taught," "to give instruction in sound doctrine," and "to rebuke those who contradict" God's Word. Verse 10 and the rest of this paragraph explain why this confrontation must take place: because there are already many within the church

- I. Appointing Elders (1:1–16) . . .
	- C. An Elder's Confrontation (1:10–16)
		- 1. Silencing False Teachers (1:10–11)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-506-3"></span><span id="page-506-0"></span>1:10 "Many" false teachers have already infiltrated the church in Crete. This development should not surprise us, because Jesus himself warned his disciples that it would be this way (Matt. 7:15–16). While the presence of false teachers might cause alarm, it should not be unexpected. Their presence simply means that the Cretan believers must be ever vigilant.

These false teachers are "insubordinate, empty talkers and deceivers." The term "insubordinate" is the same one used in verse 6 to describe what a pastor must not be. From this we see that one reason Paul says pastors must exhibit certain character traits is that false teachers display the opposite. "Insubordinate" refers to that which is "refusing submission to authority, *undisciplined, disobedient, rebellious*" (BDAG, s.v. ἀνυπότακτος, italics original). These false teachers are insubordinate to God's authority because they do not submit to his Word. In fact, they distort and contradict it.

<span id="page-506-2"></span>False teachers are "empty talkers" (*mataiologoi*; cf. *mataiologian* in 1 Tim. 1:6). Such men exhibit the kind of "irreverent babble" (*kenophōnias*) that 2 Timothy 2:16 says "will lead people into more and more ungodliness." These teachers are thus themselves disobedient, and their teaching leads others into disobedience as well, which is why Paul calls them "deceivers." They mislead people by giving them the impression they are following Christ while actually they are leading people away from him.

Finally, Paul refers to "especially those of the circumcision party," which suggests they are Jewish. But what else is known about this "circumcision party"? Paul does not provide a specific description of what this party is teaching, but commentator George Knight concludes that it is "concerned with Jewish myths and genealogies, which apparently set the tone for the way in which it handles the law. It is ascetic but also rebellious and disobedient, it opposes the apostolic teaching and turns away from it, and it is motivated by gain."7

<span id="page-506-4"></span>1:11 These false teachers must be silenced because their teaching does not address merely matters of theological indifference, or *adiaphora*; rather, they are "upsetting whole families." The only actual "commands" from false teachers mentioned in the

<sup>7</sup> Knight, *Pastoral Epistles*, 296.

<span id="page-507-1"></span>Pastorals are those in 1 Timothy 4:1–3, which records that the false teachers were prohibiting marriage and the eating of certain foods. Perhaps their prohibition of marriage had led to the termination of existing marriages.8 Whatever these men were teaching, it was destroying families. That they sought "shameful gain" indicates that they taught for money.

<span id="page-507-3"></span>1:12 In the first century, Cretans had a reputation for gross immorality. That sad truth is reflected in the writings of one of their own countrymen, a epic poet named Epimenides (6th century BC). Although a Cretan himself, Epimenides wrote famously that "Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, lazy gluttons." The work from which Paul quotes is no longer extant, but some early Christian writers—including Clement of Alexandria, Chrysostom, and Jerome—identify Epimenides as the source.9 As a Cretan, Epimenides would have had more credibility to speak critically about Cretans than Paul would have as an outsider. Paul references the quotation to show that the Cretan false teachers behave like stereotypical Cretans. They do not tell the truth. They behave like "evil beasts" and as such are vicious and unreasoning. They are "lazy gluttons" who live for their appetites. Such behavior is rotten, and Paul says that it is clearly evidenced by these false teachers. Knight concludes, "Paul is not making an ethnic slur, but is merely accurately observing, as the Cretans themselves and others did, how the sin that affects the whole human race comes to particular expression in this group."10

<span id="page-507-4"></span>1:13 When Paul declares that "this testimony is true," he is stating that the false teachers are living up to the Cretan stereotype. This sharp accusation may have been particularly galling to these false teachers if they thought of themselves as scrupulous Jewish Christians. Yet they are behaving not with Jewish integrity but with pagan insubordination. This is why Paul instructs Titus to "rebuke them sharply," to confront them with their wrongdoing in order to convince them of their error. The rebuke must be delivered "sharply," or "*severely, rigorously*" (BDAG, s.v. ἀποτόμως, italics original). The goal of this pointed reproof is "that they may be sound in the faith." In this way, Paul holds out hope that the false teachers might yet be won over to the truth. This is not the first time Paul has spoken of false teachers with such hopefulness. In 2 Timothy 2:24–26 he writes, "The Lord's servant must not be quarrelsome but . . . correcting his opponents with gentleness. God may perhaps grant them repentance leading to a knowledge of the truth, and they may come to their senses and escape from the snare of the devil, after being captured by him to do his will."

<span id="page-507-5"></span><span id="page-507-2"></span>1:14 To "be sound in the faith" (v. 13) is, in this context, to avoid being devoted to "Jewish myths" or the "commands of people who turn away from the truth." Titus's rebuke is intended to steer false teachers away from such error. What precisely does Paul mean by "Jewish myths"? In 1 Timothy 1:4, "myths" are linked

<span id="page-507-0"></span><sup>8</sup> Ibid., 297–298.

<sup>9</sup> Ibid., 298.

<sup>10</sup> Ibid., 299.

to "endless genealogies." In that light, perhaps the myths in Titus should be understood as fictional stories based on the genealogies of the OT.11 Whatever the precise meaning, the point is that these "myths" are just that—myths. They are not true, and no one should be listening to or believing them. As in 2 Timothy 4:4, to "wander off into myths" is to "turn away from listening to the truth." Paul's hope is that the false teachers would give up on their false teaching and return to the truth.

<span id="page-508-6"></span><span id="page-508-2"></span><span id="page-508-1"></span>The "commands of people" (i.e., "commandments of men") has a parallel in Jesus' statement in Matthew 15:9, "In vain do they worship me, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men" (cf. Isa. 29:13 LXX; Mark 7:7; Col. 2:22). In this text and elsewhere, the phrase "commandments of men" refers to "what is put in the place of obedience to God and what he requires."12 Titus must repudiate this error and call its proponents to repentance.

<span id="page-508-7"></span><span id="page-508-5"></span><span id="page-508-4"></span><span id="page-508-3"></span>1:15 "To the pure, all things are pure" may seem cryptic at first glance, but its meaning is perhaps not that difficult to understand. "All things" refers to creation. The statement simply asserts that "the pure"—those who have been cleansed by the blood of Jesus—know that God has given them all of creation to enjoy (cf. 1 Tim. 6:17). The "pure" know that "everything created by God is good, and nothing is to be rejected if it is received with thanksgiving, for it is made holy by the word of God and prayer" (1 Tim. 4:4–5). Thus, the pure do not regard the things forbidden by the false teachers as impure (cf. 1 Tim. 4:3, where Paul reveals that false teachers forbid "marriage" and "certain foods"). In that sense, to the pure, all things are pure. "But to the defiled and unbelieving, nothing is pure." In other words, there is nothing "pure" to the Jewish false teachers. "Their minds and their consciences" are defiled in the sense that they do not evaluate God's creation correctly. They forbid marriage and certain foods as impure. Nevertheless, marriage and food are actually happy and wholesome gifts from God to every disciple who has eyes to see the goodness of God's creation.

<span id="page-508-8"></span>1:16 The false teachers are deceptive. They "profess" to know the one true and living God. In terms of external appearances, they look and talk like Christians; their orthodox profession of faith enables them to dwell undetected among the faithful. They have all the appearances and religious performances of the faithful, but a closer look reveals that they "deny" God despite their words. Their "works" are antithetical to what they claim to believe. Their actions speak louder than their words.

<span id="page-508-0"></span>As a result, they are "detestable, disobedient, unfit for any good work." "Detestable" may be an echo of Proverbs 17:15: "He who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the righteous are both alike an abomination to the Lord." Likewise, the false teachers are detestable precisely because they forsake the commandments of God as if they were unrighteous while shilling for myths that are

<sup>11</sup> Ibid., 300.

<sup>12</sup> Ibid., 301.

transparently unrighteous. "Disobedient" refers to their defiance of God's will and revelation. "Unfit for any good work" means "unqualified" or "worthless" to produce works conforming to God's will. Their error keeps them from producing real spiritual fruit.

### *Response*

<span id="page-509-0"></span>False teaching harms God's people. It is neither wise nor loving, therefore, to allow false teaching to run unopposed in the church. If we love God's people, we will seek to spare them from what hurts them—and false teaching can destroy them spiritually. This is why Paul says that the false teachers must be "silenced."

### TITUS 2:1–10

2 But as for you, teach what accords with sound*<sup>1</sup>* doctrine. **2**Older men are to be sober-minded, dignified, self-controlled, sound in faith, in love, and in steadfastness. **3**Older women likewise are to be reverent in behavior, not slanderers or slaves to much wine. They are to teach what is good, **<sup>4</sup>** and so train the young women to love their husbands and children, **<sup>5</sup>** to be self-controlled, pure, working at home, kind, and submissive to their own husbands, that the word of God may not be reviled. **<sup>6</sup>**Likewise, urge the younger men to be self-controlled. **<sup>7</sup>** Show yourself in all respects to be a model of good works, and in your teaching show integrity, dignity, **<sup>8</sup>** and sound speech that cannot be condemned, so that an opponent may be put to shame, having nothing evil to say about us. **<sup>9</sup>**Bondservants*<sup>2</sup>* are to be submissive to their own masters in everything; they are to be well-pleasing, not argumentative, **10**not pilfering, but showing all good faith, so that in everything they may adorn the doctrine of God our Savior.

1Or *healthy*; also verses 2, 8 2For the contextual rendering of the Greek word *doulos*, see ESV Preface

### *Section Overview*

At the end of Titus 1, Paul explained to Titus what false teachers look like: "They profess to know God, but they deny him by their works." False teachers have a profession of faith but not the reality of faith; their inauthentic faith is demonstrated by the way in which they teach and how they live their lives. They display an external veneer of religious devotion, but their deeds make their disobedience plain. Having warned him of these false teachers, Paul exhorts Titus to be an example of good deeds. In particular, Titus must teach and live what is agreeable to sound doctrine. Titus's teaching should focus on practical instruction for older men, older women, younger women, younger men, and slaves.

### *Comment*

<span id="page-510-2"></span><span id="page-510-1"></span>2:1 In 1:10–11, Paul declared that the false teachers are "insubordinate, empty talkers and deceivers. . . . They must be silenced." In contrast, Titus is not to be like the false teachers: "But as for you, teach what accords with sound doctrine." The last phrase might even be translated as "healthy doctrine." The doctrine is healthy not in terms of being free from physical sickness but in terms of being free from spiritual error. Sound doctrine is the life-blood of Christian faith. It is the life-giving, authoritative deposit of truth.

Paul does not command Titus merely to "teach sound doctrine." He must "teach *what accords with* sound doctrine." Any minister of the gospel who knows sound doctrine but is unable to instruct God's people in how to live their lives *in accord* with such doctrine will not be an effective minister of the Word. Titus must be able to address believers in every station of life with practical instructions for godly living. Thus in the next verses Paul unpacks what it means for specific groups of people to live *in accord with* sound doctrine.

<span id="page-510-3"></span><span id="page-510-0"></span>2:2 Older men are to be "sober-minded." The men referenced here are not to be confused with those who hold the office of elder (cf. 1:5). The "older men" are those who literally have reached advanced age. These men must display several exemplary characteristics:

"Sober-minded" translates a term that means "very moderate in the drinking of an alcoholic beverage." Its figurative extension here means to "be free fr. every form of mental and spiritual 'drunkenness', fr. excess, passion, rashness, confusion." This is a call to be "restrained in conduct, *self-controlled, level-headed*" (BDAG, s.v. νηφάλιος and νήφω, emphases theirs).

"Dignified" refers to one "*worthy of respect/honor, noble, dignified, serious*" (BDAG, s.v. σεμνός, italics original). The dignified person is so self-possessed and in control of his temper and fears that he elicits admiration from those who know him.

Aristotle describes "self-control" as "avoidance of extremes and careful consideration for responsible action" (*Nichomachean Ethics* 3, 15; quoted in BDAG, s.v. σώφρων). For Aristotle, the "self-controlled" person is "intent on the what, the how, and the when of doing what should be done."

"Sound" usually refers to being "healthy," or free from sickness. The extension of that meaning here means "correct" or free from error. To be "sound" in faith, love, and endurance requires older men to *believe* in the right way, to *love* in the right way, and to *endure* in the right way.

<span id="page-511-1"></span><span id="page-511-0"></span>2:3 "Likewise" means that older women are to be godly exemplars just as older men are, and Paul lists some very specific attributes. "Reverent in behavior" indicates behavior worthy of a holy woman.13 There is a verbal link to that which "accords with sound doctrine" (v. 1). This descriptor calls for behavior "fitting with holiness." Paul zeroes in on two very specific besetting sins that are not in accord with holy behavior:

"Not slanderers" prohibits the verbal assassination of someone's character. Malevolent attempts to injure others with words is not in keeping with holiness. In fact, this term is one of the names the Bible uses of the Devil: *diabolos*. He is a slanderer. Slander is the Devil's work and is completely at odds with holy behavior.

"Slaves to much wine." The image of slavery is a vivid depiction of what too much drink can do to a person. This temptation can touch anyone, but perhaps Paul identifies a particular temptation for certain women whose vocation is at home and who therefore "have constant access to the food and drink of the household."14

The older women are to "teach what is good." Their steadiness and wisdom is to be a boon for younger women of the congregation.

<span id="page-511-2"></span>2:4 "So train the young women." To "train" renders the verb *sōphronizōsin*. In the surrounding verses, terms from the *sōphr-* word group appear three other times. In verses 2 and 5, older men and younger women, respectively, are to be *sōphronas*  ("self-controlled"). In verse 6, younger men are called to *sōphronein* ("to be prudent, with focus on self-control"; BDAG, s.v. σωφρονέω). Each of these occurrences places an accent on self-control and prudence, the only characteristic applied to all four groups—older men, older women, younger women, and younger men. For this reason, the verb form applied to the older women in verse 4 likely has a similar denotation. Thus the older women must not only "train" the young women but must also instruct them in prudence and self-control with respect to their duties in the home. Chief among those duties is the obligation to "love their husbands and children." Literally, the younger women must be husband-lovers and childrenlovers. Learning prudence and self-control enables these women to love their own family well.

<span id="page-511-3"></span>2:5 This verse begins with the virtue implied by the main verb of verse 4: "selfcontrol." Self-control enables the other virtues that follow. Some of these virtues are related specifically to women within the covenant of marriage. "Self-controlled" indicates "avoidance of extremes and careful consideration for responsible action" (Aristotle, *Nichomachean Ethics* 3, 15; BDAG, s.v. σώφρων). As mentioned above, this term appears in connection with each of the age and gender groupings, but the rest

<sup>13</sup> *Brill Dictionary of Ancient Greek* (Leiden: Brill, 2015), 968.

<sup>14</sup> Knight, *Pastoral Epistles*, 306.

of the characteristics mentioned in this verse relate uniquely to marriage. "Pure" denotes moral uprightness. In connection with women, the term often carries the idea of chastity (BDAG, s.v. ἁγνός). Sexual faithfulness requires chastity outside of marriage and fidelity within marriage.

<span id="page-512-1"></span><span id="page-512-0"></span>"Working at home." The wife has the particular assignment to care for and manage the home. Whatever else she does, she cannot shirk her primary duty to care for the home and those who live in it. Does this mean that she can never leave the house or work outside the home? The analogy of Scripture would lead us to answer that question in the negative. The virtuous wife of Proverbs 31:10–31, for example, is a woman who "considers a field and buys it" (Prov. 31:16) and earns an income for her family. This virtuous woman engages in a wide range of activities, some of which take her out of the home. Nevertheless, no matter what she does, she never deserts her duty to love her husband and children and to care for the home. "Kind" probably has specific application to the wife's relationships in the home. The term calls on her to have a "generous, sympathetic, . . . warm-hearted nature" (*American Heritage Dictionary*, s.v. "kind").

"And submissive to their own husbands." The term "submissive" requires one to recognize and follow the leadership and direction of a recognized authority. In this case, the wife is to submit not to all men but to one man—her "own" husband. It is important to notice what Paul does not say. He could have said, "Husbands, subject your wives to yourselves." In other words, he might have spoken in such a way that called on husbands to *compel* or *coerce* submission from their wives. Even though that would have fit with the patriarchal context of the first-century Greco-Roman world, that is not how Paul writes. Instead he calls on wives to submit *voluntarily* to their husbands. The primary responsibility falls to the wives to submit themselves, not to the husbands explicitly to make them submit. "That the word of God may not be reviled" indicates that failure to carry out this role gives outsiders grounds to criticize God's Word, which is something no Christian has permission to do.

<span id="page-512-2"></span>2:6 "Likewise" indicates that young men are to exhibit a quality of "self-control" just like the other age and gender groups listed (cf. above) are to exhibit. Paul gives Titus the responsibility to "urge" them to be such: he has a duty to preach the Word of God in such a way that younger men understand what is required of them. Just like Paul commanded the older men, older women, and younger women, now he is commanding the younger men to be self-controlled. Paul tells each of these groups to pursue self-control, which means "to be prudent, with focus on self-control, *be reasonable, sensible, serious, keep one's head*" (BDAG, s.v. σωφρονέω, italics original). The person with self-control is one who embodies all of the virtues previously named for the other age groups in this list.

<span id="page-512-3"></span>2:7–8 Paul turns directly to Titus and says, in essence, "You are to be a model of all the virtues that you preach to the others in the congregation." Titus cannot merely teach faithfully. He must *live* faithfully. If Titus cannot live faithfully as a <span id="page-513-0"></span>Christian, he is not qualified to teach others what he himself cannot do. He must be able to say to his congregation, "Be imitators of me, as I am of Christ" (1 Cor. 11:1).

<span id="page-513-4"></span><span id="page-513-3"></span><span id="page-513-1"></span>Paul specifies three characteristics of Titus's teaching by which he is to "show" himself to be a model: (1) "Integrity" means "incorruption" (BDAG, s.v. ἀφθορία). (2) "Dignity" indicates "*seriousness, probity, holiness*"; the Latin word for this is *gravitas* (BDAG, s.v. σεμνότης, italics original). (3) "Sound speech that cannot be condemned." Although this "speech" (*logos*) is possibly a reference to Titus's speech in general (cf. 1 Tim. 4:12), it refers most likely to his teaching in particular (cf. *hygiainousin logois*, 1 Tim. 6:3; *hygiainontōn logōn*, 2 Tim. 1:13). This teaching should have two characteristics. First, it must be "sound" or healthy in the sense of being uncorrupted and correct (BDAG, s.v. ὑγιής). Second, it must be "uncondemned." This is not to say that Titus's teaching may never be criticized or condemned. Rather, there must never be any proper basis for whatever condemnations may come. In short, a faithful minister of the Word must agree with the apostolic norm and must preach this Word with gravitas and weight.

The purpose of the preacher's exemplary conduct and teaching is "so that an opponent may be put to shame, having nothing evil to say about us." Titus must live and preach in such a way that there would be no just grounds for condemnation. The preacher's reputation is not the only thing on the line: Paul refers to "having nothing evil to say about *us*"; Paul's own reputation is also at stake in Titus's ministry. A pastor cannot make himself immune from criticism, but he is to teach and preach in such a way that everyone can see that there is no basis for any such condemnation.

<span id="page-513-5"></span><span id="page-513-2"></span>2:9–10 The word translated "bondservants" in the ESV is the Greek term *doulos*, the standard term for slaves used throughout the NT (cf. comment and excursus on 1 Tim. 6:1–2). Paul emphasizes four ways in which a bondservant might honor authority, and he arranges them chiastically. Two positive characteristics frame two negative ones: "they are to be well-pleasing, not argumentative, not pilfering, but showing all good faith."

"Well-pleasing" directs a slave to render "positive and winsome action in addition to passive submission."15 "Not argumentative" precludes the possibility of gainsaying a master with arguments or resistance. "Not pilfering" prohibits stealing or "skimming off the top" to take that which does not belong to the worker. Slaves might be tempted to steal whatever may not be missed in "small quantities and . . . might justify their actions" by claiming that the stolen goods were owed to them.16 In contrast, the Lord's worker is called to show "all good faith." Christian witness depends in part upon Christian workers being faithful to work and to honor authority. They must work in this way "so that in everything they may adorn the doctrine of God our Savior." To "adorn" God's doctrine means "to cause [it] to have an attractive appearance" (BDAG, s.v. κοσμέω).

<sup>15</sup> Ibid., 314.

<sup>16</sup> Ibid.

### *Response*

The Bible does not direct or give permission to husbands to coerce or manipulate the submission of their wives. If a husband ever finds himself trying to force his wife to follow his leadership, he must realize his error—especially if this is a pattern over the course of an entire marriage. He must ask himself, "Am I doing something to provoke a lack of confidence in my leadership?" The answer may be that his wife is in rebellion against God and his role for her in marriage. If this is the case, the husband can pray for her and tenderly exhort her. But often the reason she is not following is because he is being a poor leader. But no matter the reason for her failure to follow his leadership, a husband is never justified in coercing or manipulating submission. Obviously, he should never physically coerce his wife to do anything, but neither can he be verbally abusive or manipulative in order to get his way. If the husband feels he must verbally or emotionally intimidate his wife into submission, the problem is not with her but with him, and he must repent of his sin.

<span id="page-514-4"></span><span id="page-514-2"></span><span id="page-514-1"></span><span id="page-514-0"></span>The Christian wife is not called to submit to every man but to one man—her own husband. In Ephesians 5:22, God calls her to submit to her husband "as to the Lord," which means that she should view her submission to her husband as a part of her commitment to the Lord Jesus (cf. Eph. 6:1, 5, 7). For the Christian wife, the narrow road that leads to life (Matt. 7:13–14) includes submission to her husband.

### TITUS 2:11–15

**<sup>11</sup>**For the grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation for all people, **<sup>12</sup>** training us to renounce ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in the present age, **13**waiting for our blessed hope, the appearing of the glory of our great God and Savior Jesus Christ, **14**who gave himself for us to redeem us from all lawlessness and to purify for himself a people for his own possession who are zealous for good works.

**<sup>15</sup>**Declare these things; exhort and rebuke with all authority. Let no one disregard you.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-514-3"></span>"For" in Titus 2:11 indicates that Paul is now supporting the exhortations just given to specific groups of people in 2:1–10. The "grace of God" is the removal not only of judgment but also of the power of sin. Grace, therefore, enables sinners to live righteously in the present age. Jesus died to secure not only forgiveness for his people but also their faithfulness. Paul commands Titus to "declare" this kind of grace to the believers in Crete.

- II. Teaching Old and Young (2:1–15) . . .
	- B. Instruction about Grace (2:11–15)
		- 1. The Appearance of the Grace of God (2:11–13)
		- 2. The Cost of the Grace of God (2:14)
		- 3. The Preaching of the Grace of God (2:15)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-515-1"></span>2:11 The interpretation of verse 11 is complicated by some syntactical features in the Greek. The one subject "grace of God" has two predicates, one of which is a verb, "has appeared," and the other of which is a predicate adjective, "bringing salvation" (Gk. *sōtērios*). English translations have struggled to put all of this together. The King James renders *sōtērios* not as a predicate adjective but as attributive: "the grace of God that bringeth salvation." The NIV translates likewise, "the grace of God . . . that offers salvation," but these renderings are most likely incorrect. Notwithstanding a textual variant that includes the article before this adjective, *sōtērios* is in fact a predicate and should not be rendered as a simple modifier of "grace of God." Mounce suggests that the verb "has appeared" functions in this clause as an equative verb.17 If he is correct, then a helpful literal rendering might be, "For the grace of God has appeared as saving for all people."

The "grace of God" refers to God's "beneficent disposition" toward his people (BDAG, s.v. χάρις). It is the favor God bestows on sinners who do not deserve it. God's favor toward his people causes a salvific transformation that would not occur apart from grace. This grace of God "has appeared"—grace's *appearance* "refers to its unique historical appearance in Christ, which is communicated to us in the gospel."18

<span id="page-515-0"></span>"All people" does not imply universalism—as if God's grace guaranteed that everyone would be saved. Rather, "all people" refers to all classes of people who find themselves converted to Christ (cf. 1 Tim. 4:10). Verse 11 explains why *all* different kinds of believers—old men, old women, young women, young men, Titus, and slaves—are to live upright lives fitting with sound doctrine: such a life is the necessary outflow of experiencing the grace of God. If that kind of transformation is absent in a person's life, then so also is the grace of God absent.

<span id="page-515-2"></span>2:12 "Training" indicates discipline: "to assist in the development of a person's ability to make appropriate choices, *practice discipline*" (BDAG, s.v. παιδεύω, italics original). The point of such discipline is to teach believers how to live lives marked by ongoing repentance and faith. These are not merely the entry way into Christian life; they are the ongoing obligations of Christian living. Repentance requires one to "renounce ungodliness and worldly passions." In this context, "ungodliness" refers to "sacrilegious words and deeds" (BDAG, s.v. ἀσέβεια). "Worldly passions"

<sup>17</sup> Mounce, *Pastoral Epistles*, 422.

<sup>18</sup> Knight, *Pastoral Epistles*, 318.

<span id="page-516-4"></span>denotes the sinful desires that produce such deeds ("passions" = "desires," Gk. *epithymia*; cf. comment on 2 Tim. 2:22). Thus grace disciplines believers to deny both sinful deeds and sinful desires. Any notion of grace that fails to turn sinners away from evil is not the grace of God as taught by Paul.

<span id="page-516-6"></span><span id="page-516-5"></span>God's grace, however, not only prohibits sin but also commands and enables positive virtues: "to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in the present age." The term translated "self-controlled" is the same quality commended for each of the age and gender groups listed in Titus 2:2–10. The grace of God produces this virtue in *all* believers in some measure (cf. comment on the *sōphr-* word group at 2:4). "Upright" translates a term meaning "righteously." It indicates that the grace of God empowers the believer to live in accordance with divine norms. "Godly" indicates reverence and respect toward God. Grace enables and produces all of these virtues "in the present age." Even though Christians are not yet what they will be in the age to come, God's grace nevertheless has transforming effects on the sinner's character in advance of that day. Grace does not produce perfection in this life, but it does decisively change the direction of the sinner's life.

<span id="page-516-7"></span><span id="page-516-3"></span>2:13 "Waiting for our blessed hope" modifies the verb "live" in the previous verse. "Waiting" indicates that the Christian life is one of patient endurance, no matter the trial. Believers are able to endure because they have "hope." Hope is not wishful thinking; it is confident expectation that God will do as he has promised. Paul often uses the term to refer to the return of Christ and the renewal of all things that will accompany that return—including the believer's own resurrection from the dead (e.g., Rom. 5:2; Gal. 5:5; Col. 1:5, 27; 1 Thess. 4:13). The "blessed hope," therefore, is the happy confidence that every believer has regarding the return of Christ and the resurrection of the righteous. This is confirmed by the next phrase, which is an unambiguous reference to the return of Christ in his resurrection glory: "the appearing of the glory of our great God and Savior Jesus Christ." Paul's phrasing indicates the deity of Christ, who is himself called "our great God."19

<span id="page-516-8"></span><span id="page-516-0"></span>2:14 Christ "gave himself," a reference to his death on a Roman cross. That Christ gave himself means that no one took his life from him against his will; he laid his life down willingly (cf. John 10:18; Gal. 1:4; Eph. 5:2, 25; 1 Tim. 2:6). Paul assures the Cretan believers that Christ's death was "for us"—a phrase indicating substitution, "in place of us" (cf. John 11:50; 2 Cor. 5:14, 20; Gal. 3:13; 1 Tim. 2:5–6).20 Sinners deserve to die because of their sin (Rom. 3:23), but Christ suffered that punishment in their place.

<span id="page-516-2"></span><span id="page-516-1"></span>Christ gave himself for believers for two purposes—to redeem them and to purify them. To "redeem" means to free someone from an oppressive situation by paying a ransom. In this case, the oppressive situation is "lawlessness," the performance of sinful deeds. Thus Jesus' death paid for freedom not only from

<sup>19</sup> On the syntax of the underlying Greek, see Daniel B. Wallace, *Greek Grammar beyond the Basics*, 276. 20 See Murray J. Harris, *Prepositions and Theology in the Greek New Testament* (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan, 2012), 211–216.

the penalty of sin but also from the power of sin over believers' lives. To "purify" indicates cleansing from sin, and Christ purifies "for himself" his very own special people—a holy congregation marked by its being "zealous for good works." God's grace, therefore, is not cheap grace. Grace ensures freedom not only from sin's punishment but also from its power.

<span id="page-517-2"></span><span id="page-517-1"></span>2:15 Chapter 2 ends where it began, with Paul exhorting Titus to preach faithfully to God's people: "Declare these things." The term translated "declare" (Gk. *lalei* ) is the same term translated "teach" in verse 1. Thus Titus 2 is framed by an inclusio concerning what Titus is to teach. Paul commands him in verse 1 to teachonly what is fitting with sound doctrine. Paul then specifies in verses 2–10 what is fitting for each of the different age and gender groups of the church. He next articulates in verses 11–14 the grace that inspires godliness in the lives of God's people. It is no surprise, then, that Paul reiterates in verse 15 that Titus must continually teach "these things," referring back to the whole of chapter 2.

<span id="page-517-5"></span><span id="page-517-3"></span>Paul adds two more terms to clarify what Titus is to "declare" to believers in Crete: he must "exhort and rebuke." He must commend certain things and prohibit others. He must build up in the faith and confront departures from the faith, doing both of these "with all authority." As an apostolic delegate, Titus must conduct himself as one who has the authority to command. Titus himself must possess the character traits he is commending for others. If Titus fails to base his preaching ministry on God's revelation and on personal holiness, he will give his hearers grounds to ignore him, which is precisely what Paul is seeking to forestall by stating, "Let no one disregard you." The best way for Titus to command respect is to actually *be worthy of* respect. He must have a life of compelling holiness if he expects others to listen to him (cf. 1 Tim. 4:12).

### <span id="page-517-0"></span>*Response*

Paul's words regarding God's grace are an antidote to what Dietrich Bonhoeffer called "cheap grace."21 The "cheap grace" Bonhoeffer warned of is actually no grace at all. Nevertheless, this notion of grace has become all too common in many evangelical churches today. This is grace that promises to rescue us but not to renew us. It is grace that offers to save us from hell but not from our sins. It is grace that accepts all sinners into the church but offers no discipline for sin within the church. Any so-called grace that leaves a man a slave to his sin is really no grace at all, because grace is not merely deliverance from judgment. God's grace also provides deliverance from what makes us worthy of judgment. As Paul says it, the true grace of God teaches us "to renounce ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in the present age" (Titus 2:12).

<span id="page-517-4"></span>We must never adopt a view of grace and salvation that essentially leaves some people untransformed. Christians ought to live godly lives, but some professing

<sup>21</sup> Dietrich Bonhoeffer, *The Cost of Discipleship*, trans. R. H. Fuller and Irmgard Booth, rev. ed. (New York: Macmillan, 1959), 35–36.

<span id="page-518-3"></span><span id="page-518-0"></span>Christians resist this grace. It is possible for a person to have a *profession* of faith without the *reality* of faith, and such people will come up short at the judgment. We must not be this type of person. Have we really tasted the grace of salvation? We must "test ourselves" to see if we are of the faith (2 Cor. 13:5).

### TITUS 3:1–11

<span id="page-518-1"></span>3 Remind them to be submissive to rulers and authorities, to be obedient, to be ready for every good work, **<sup>2</sup>** to speak evil of no one, to avoid quarreling, to be gentle, and to show perfect courtesy toward all people. **3**For we ourselves were once foolish, disobedient, led astray, slaves to various passions and pleasures, passing our days in malice and envy, hated by others and hating one another. **4**But when the goodness and loving kindness of God our Savior appeared, **5**he saved us, not because of works done by us in righteousness, but according to his own mercy, by the washing of regeneration and renewal of the Holy Spirit, **6**whom he poured out on us richly through Jesus Christ our Savior, **<sup>7</sup>** so that being justified by his grace we might become heirs according to the hope of eternal life. **8**The saying is trustworthy, and I want you to insist on these things, so that those who have believed in God may be careful to devote themselves to good works. These things are excellent and profitable for people. **9**But avoid foolish controversies, genealogies, dissensions, and quarrels about the law, for they are unprofitable and worthless. **10**As for a person who stirs up division, after warning him once and then twice, have nothing more to do with him, **<sup>11</sup>**knowing that such a person is warped and sinful; he is self-condemned.

### *Section Overview*

<span id="page-518-4"></span><span id="page-518-2"></span>In Titus chapter 3, Paul directs Titus's attention to how believers in Crete should relate to the wider unbelieving world outside of their congregation. They must render submission to the governing authorities (v. 1) and graciousness to their unbelieving neighbors (v. 2). Because God has been gracious to undeserving sinners, Christians must likewise be gracious (vv. 3–8).

		- 2. Gracious to All People (3:2)
