- III. Appeal for Onesimus (vv. 8–21)
	- A. Explanation of Persuasion Rather Than Command (vv. 8–9)
	- B. Appeal on Behalf of Onesimus, Who Is Now Paul's Child (vv. 10–11)
	- C. Reasons for Sending Onesimus Back to Philemon (vv. 12–14)
	- D. Reflection on Possible Reason Why Onesimus Was Separated from Philemon (vv. 15–16)
	- E. Request That Philemon Receive Onesimus (v. 17)
	- F. Willingness to Compensate Philemon (vv. 18–20)
	- G. Certainty That Philemon Will Respond (v. 21)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-544-3"></span>8 Paul now addresses the delicate matter at hand. While we may not be able to gain absolute certainty regarding the circumstances in which Onesimus left Philemon and joined Paul (cf. the discussion in the Introduction), it is clear that Onesimus was a slave and, as such, was in an extremely precarious position. He, in common with all slaves in Greco-Roman society, was regarded as the possession of his master and, depending on the attitude of his master, could face violence and even death upon his return.24

In God's providence and care for Onesimus, however, it turns out that he had a gracious and skillful advocate in Paul. Paul's appeal to Philemon shows rhetorical skill as well as pastoral sensitivity. It would be unfair, however, to suggest that Paul manipulates Philemon. While it is true that Paul deals with the delicate situation very shrewdly, there is no reason to believe that anything Paul says is insincere or that he did not seek at all times to act in the best interests of *both* Onesimus *and* Philemon.

Paul begins with the Greek conjunction *dio* ("accordingly"), indicating that the strength of the relationship between Philemon and Paul just described is the foundation for how he is going to address this potentially awkward situation. Paul's style here is full of qualifications, designed to ensure that the communication between the two men is entirely clear in content and tone. Moo notes that verses 8–14 begin and end with Paul's desire for Philemon to act according to his free will, not by compulsion.25 The relationships between the main figures are key to the flow of this letter.

<span id="page-544-4"></span><span id="page-544-2"></span><span id="page-544-1"></span><span id="page-544-0"></span>Paul immediately inserts a qualification, asserting his boldness ( *parrēsia*). Paul uses this term seven times apart from this instance (2 Cor. 3:12; 7:4; Eph. 3:12; 6:19; Phil. 1:20; Col. 2:15; 1 Tim. 3:13). In some cases it refers to forthrightness and fearlessness in proclaiming the gospel, but it is also used in 2 Corinthians to refer to Paul's readiness within the Christian community to confront people frankly. This boldness is "in Christ." Paul is not simply claiming he can be asser-

<sup>24</sup> Murray J. Harris, *Slave of Christ* (NSBT; Leicester: Apollos, 1999), 25–45, 57–61; Thompson, *Colossians and Philemon*, 202–204; Pao, *Colossians and Philemon*, 348–351. 25 Moo, *Letters to the Colossians and to Philemon*, 399.

tive whenever he wants to be. Rather, he speaks from the context of his calling in Christ and the authority it entails.

<span id="page-545-1"></span>9 But Paul chooses another way. In verses 9 and 10, a key verb, *parakaleō*, is used twice in quick succession to describe Paul's manner of approach. Although this term may be used with a wide range of connotations, from a gentle encouragement to a strong exhortation (cf. BDAG, s.v. παρακαλεω), the context here shows that Paul contrasts this approach with the "boldness" he might have shown. I agree, therefore, with the classification of both occurrences by BDAG as meaning "to make a strong request for someth., *request, implore, entreat*," with "strength" understood as a matter of passion rather than of authority (italics original). The appeal Paul makes is "on account of [*dia* followed by the accusative] love." Paul does not specify whose love he refers to here. There is scope for a breadth of understanding that would include the love between Paul and Philemon, between Paul and Onesimus, and within the Christian community.

Paul's reference to his age is intriguing. There is a textual question regarding whether the reading should be "ambassador" (a difference of only one letter in Gk.), but the reading "old man" appears to fit the context better (cf. Moo26 and Metzger27). The whole passage suggests that Paul is appealing repeatedly to the value Philemon places on relationships and Christian love. Paul's reference to himself as an aged prisoner fits that context well.

<span id="page-545-4"></span><span id="page-545-3"></span><span id="page-545-2"></span>10 Paul speaks of Onesimus as his "child," adding the explanation, "whose father I became in chains" (AT). Onesimus is described in verses 10–13 using three relative clauses beginning with the relative pronoun *hon*. The first clause (v. 10b) describes a birth: "whose father I became." The new birth Paul speaks of here, while not explained, indicates a spiritual transformation accomplished by God, with Paul acting as agent (cf. 1 Cor. 4:15).

<span id="page-545-5"></span><span id="page-545-0"></span>11 Further elaboration of this relative clause describing Onesimus is provided by a parenthetical clause. Here Paul makes the well-known word play on Onesimus's name, which means "useful." Paul uses two adjectives, *achrēstos* ("useless") and *euchrēstos* ("useful"), related to the meaning of Onesimus's name to indicate that the spiritual transformation of Onesimus has not only fundamentally changed his character and relationship with Paul but has also transformed his relationship with Philemon. Pao suggests that it is not necessary to read "useless" in a particularly negative light, beyond a general contrast between the past and the present.28 If, however, Onesimus is understood to be a runaway slave, then the play on words becomes more relevant.

<span id="page-545-6"></span>12 The second relative clause describes Paul's sacrificial act in sending Onesimus back to Philemon. The depth of the relationship between Paul and Onesimus is

<sup>26</sup> Ibid., 404–405.

<sup>27</sup> Bruce M. Metzger, *A Textual Commentary on the Greek New Testament*, 2nd ed. (Stuttgart: UBS, 1994), 588.

<sup>28</sup> Pao, *Colossians and Philemon*, 388.

<span id="page-546-0"></span>expressed by the term *splanchna* ("heart"), the second of its three occurrences in this short letter (vv. 7, 12, 20; cf. comment on verse 7). It is remarkable that Paul can describe this new Christian brother, who comes from a very different social context than Paul the Roman citizen, as one who *is* his "very heart."

<span id="page-546-1"></span>13 The third relative clause describes Paul's desire to keep Onesimus with him. Paul appears to acknowledge that this would not be a normal situation. The purpose (expressed by *hina*, "in order that") of Paul's desire is that Onesimus might "serve" (*diakonē*) Paul on Philemon's behalf (*hyper sou*). It is striking that Paul comments on how Onesimus might have acted on Philemon's behalf, even though Philemon was a master who had slaves to serve him. This gets to the heart of the distinctive ethic of servanthood lying at the heart of Christian community.

<span id="page-546-2"></span>14 Paul has clearly and fully expressed his desire to keep Onesimus. Now he indicates that he has subordinated his personal wishes to the good of Philemon, so that Philemon might have an opportunity to do a good act (*to agathon sou*) freely. This attitude models the concern for the good of others that Paul has seen in Philemon previously (v. 7) and that he will now ask Philemon to show with respect to Onesimus.

<span id="page-546-3"></span>15 Paul speculates (using the cautious expression, *tacha*, "perhaps") regarding the situation. Paul's words do not permit us to clarify the precise circumstances of the parting of Onesimus and Philemon, but Paul reads these circumstances in the context of God's sovereign providence, knowing the circumstances have a distinct purpose. That purpose, suggests Paul, is for a temporary parting to be replaced by an eternal togetherness. This short statement is nicely balanced, the verb *echōristhē* ("parted") corresponding to *apechēs* ("have back") and the temporal phrase *pros hōran*  ("for a while") corresponding to *aiōnion* ("forever").

<span id="page-546-4"></span>16 This verse qualifies the apparent balance of verse 15, adding an element of discontinuity to the new situation. The designation "bondservant" was once the appropriate description of Onesimus, but that is no longer the case; now he is a "beloved brother." Onesimus is already a beloved brother to Paul, even if to nobody else ("especially to me"). This is a matter not simply of a subjective change of attitude but of a new birth. Paul now offers Philemon the opportunity to embrace that reality in his relationship to Onesimus, a relationship that, according to Paul, should be all the more transformed.

<span id="page-546-5"></span>17 The connective particle *oun* ("so") marks "continuity and development."29 Paul builds on what he has said so far but also pushes a little further with the only clear request (in fact, a command) in the letter: "Receive him [Onesimus] as me" (AT). This imperative is introduced by a conditional clause beginning with *ei*. In grammatical terms, this is a "first class" condition. The ESV is correct to translate this as a true condition: "If you consider me your partner." The first class condition construc-

<sup>29</sup> Steven E. Runge, *Discourse Grammar of the Greek New Testament: A Practical Introduction for Teaching and Exegesis* (Bellingham, WA: Lexham, 2010), 47.

<span id="page-547-4"></span>tion assumes the truth of the statement in the first clause (the protasis) *for the sake of argument*. That is to say, the protasis may or may not be correct in actual fact but is assumed to be so in the context of the discussion. As Paul has already referred to Philemon's partnership (v. 6), we can be confident he indeed believes Philemon to be his partner. However, the conditional construction challenges Philemon to draw for himself the appropriate conclusions regarding how he should now act.

<span id="page-547-6"></span><span id="page-547-1"></span>18 The conditional clause in verse 18 should also be treated as a real condition. The use of the first class conditional construction in Luke 11:19 (where Jesus says, "If I cast out demons by Beelzebul . . .") should put an end to the notion that the first class condition always assumes a factually true statement. Rather, it assumes a statement to be true *for the sake of argument*. While the grammar itself does not necessitate the conclusion that Onesimus owes a debt (cf. Moo30), the fact that Paul raises this issue may suggest he believes Onesimus does. His request that Philemon should charge any debt to Paul's account recalls the words (in sentiment, not in precise terminology) of the Samaritan in Jesus' parable (Luke 10:35). It is doubtless a genuine commitment on Paul's part.

<span id="page-547-7"></span><span id="page-547-3"></span><span id="page-547-2"></span><span id="page-547-0"></span>19 Paul's personal commitment is established by his own handwriting. This comment is similar to that of Galatians 6:11. Such references suggest strongly that Paul's normal practice was to have his letters physically written by a scribe (an "amanuensis"). This can be seen most vividly in Romans 16:22, where Tertius, "who wrote this letter," greets the readers with a direct address from the final page of Paul's letter. As Paul emphasizes his identity and personal commitment to provide for Onesimus, he also takes the opportunity to remind Philemon that his debt to Paul is far greater. That Philemon owes Paul "even [his] own self" implies that Paul was also the means by which Philemon came to faith in Christ and thus was his "spiritual father" as well.

<span id="page-547-8"></span><span id="page-547-5"></span>20 Just when Paul might be regarded as exerting considerable emotional pressure on Philemon, the tone changes markedly. Paul addresses him directly as "brother" and expresses a desire to experience refreshment from him, recalling the words of verse 7. By using this expression, Paul places himself in a position of dependence on Philemon. It seems this both reflects the reality of Paul's relationship with Philemon and serves a valuable rhetorical function at this critical point in the letter.

<span id="page-547-9"></span>21 Paul now expresses his confidence in Philemon's response of "obedience" or "compliance," further demonstrating the depth of their relationship. Paul is confident Philemon will do "even more" than he asks. Does he imply that Philemon should free Onesimus? Although this is an inference drawn by a number of commentators, it remains no more than an inference. Paul provides no further clues regarding what he may have meant by this expression, and interpreters should be careful not to put words into Paul's mouth. That said, the broad implication of everything Paul has said in this section of the letter is that God has accomplished something so significant in the life of Onesimus (and, indeed, in Philemon's life as well) that no human relationship could remain unaffected.

### *Response*

<span id="page-548-0"></span>Paul's appeal to Philemon appears to boil down to this: "Receive Onesimus [not according to what he deserves but now] as a Christian brother, just as you would receive me" (cf. vv. 16–17). This demands a remarkable commitment from Philemon to prioritize his Christian relationship to Onesimus over all expectations of society. Such commitment remains a fundamental issue for Christian believers in all parts of the world today. It is one thing to acknowledge Jesus Christ as Lord in our own lives. It is another to acknowledge that every person brought into the Christian church by God's grace also becomes a member of our family, someone to whom we are obligated. Many Christians live in social circumstances challenging this reality, whether because of racial prejudice or caste structures or class systems or socioeconomic circumstances. But the calling of every Christian is to receive any Christian from any circumstances in just the same way as he would receive his dearest friend. Only grace can bring about such recognition of how we have been accepted in Christ, enabling us to show such acceptance to others. And only the power of Christ at work in us can enable us to live out such a desire.

### <span id="page-548-1"></span>PHILEMON 22–25

At the same time, prepare a guest room for me, for I am hoping that through your prayers I will be graciously given to you. Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends greetings to you, and so do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my fellow workers. The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.

### *Section Overview*

In the final lines of his letter, Paul turns to fostering the relationships so central to all he has said so far.

	- C. Benediction (v. 25)

### *Comment*

<span id="page-549-7"></span>22 The final verses of this short letter are dominated by mention of positive relationships. I include verse 22 with the following verses because it highlights such a relationship. Paul asks Philemon to prepare a guest room (*xenia*) for him. This is quite a remarkable request for a prisoner to make! Did Paul know he would be released shortly, or is this an expression of faith? We do not have any evidence to confirm whether or not Paul's intentions were realized. Perhaps his reference to Philemon's prayers and the possibility that Paul might be "graciously given to" Philemon suggest optimism regarding future liberty. Perhaps they also hint that Philemon has already indicated his desire for Paul to visit him.

<span id="page-549-8"></span><span id="page-549-3"></span><span id="page-549-2"></span>23 The reference to Epaphras ties this letter closely to the letter to the Colossians, in which Epaphras is mentioned in 1:7 and 4:12. These are the only references to Epaphras in Paul's letters, yet we learn significant things about his character: Epaphras shared the gospel with the Colossians (Col. 1:7); he spoke positively about the Colossians to Paul (Col. 1:8); he was from Colossae (Col. 4:12); he is characterized as a "servant," or perhaps "slave," of Christ Jesus (4:12); he struggles for the Colossians in prayer (4:12); he worked hard on behalf of the Christians at Colossae and also at Laodicea and Hierapolis (4:13). Finally, Paul describes him here as a "fellow prisoner" (*synaichmalōtos*). Although Paul employs a different word here than the one used of himself in 1:1, we can assume both terms refer to the same imprisonment.

<span id="page-549-9"></span><span id="page-549-4"></span><span id="page-549-1"></span>24 The verb *aspazetai* ("greets"; v. 23) is singular and appears to relate primarily to Epaphras. The names of Paul's other four colleagues (v. 24) are simply appended after the description of Epaphras, however, so it is clear that the same verb is to be applied to them as well. Although a common name might well apply to more than one person, the NT writers generally provide some kind of clarification when there might be confusion. Thus, the names of Mark and Luke, without further detail, almost certainly refer to the men well known from other parts of the NT with the same names. Aristarchus is less well known, although he is mentioned in Acts 19:29 as a Macedonian companion of Paul. The name "Demas" introduces a somber note since this is probably the same person to whom Paul refers in 2 Timothy 4:10 as having deserted him.

<span id="page-549-10"></span><span id="page-549-6"></span><span id="page-549-5"></span><span id="page-549-0"></span>25 The final benediction repeats the emphasis on grace found in verse 3 and is a short variation on Paul's regular benediction. While Paul is consistent in praying for grace for his Christian brothers and sisters, the precise form of his blessings varies.

### *Response*

Although the closing verses of this short letter may appear to be rather mundane, they in fact reflect the theological heart of the gospel. In Jesus Christ, God creates a new humanity, in which those who were once estranged are now reconciled and brought into a new family. This new relationship will flourish only when it is nurtured. Christians should spend time together, pray for one another, show care for one another, and seek the Lord's blessing on one another.

In these final words, Paul models the kind of healthy Christian relationship he desires for Philemon and Onesimus. But the (apparently) sad case of Demas alerts us to our responsibility to be those who foster relationships in the Christian community instead of rupturing them. A more hopeful note is Paul's mention of Mark; their relationship had also been ruptured, but the possibility of restoration remained. The sad tale of Demas does not have the last word. Nor, indeed, does the tale of Onesimus and Philemon, the conclusion of which we do not know. The last word is a word of grace in the Lord Jesus Christ, who has accomplished ultimate reconciliation with us (cf. Col. 1:20–21). As believers seek to live out their union with Christ, they may pray with hope that their human relationships will be characterized by that same reconciliation.

<span id="page-550-0"></span>*(See Bibliography for Colossians and Philemon, at end of commentary on Colossians)*
